We are a leading provider of HR solutions in key European staffing markets, offering end-to-end temporary recruiting and outsourcing services. We supply specialized and niche staffing to primarily small and medium-sized enterprise (“SME”) clients in a diversified range of end-markets. We offer and tailor our services to the staffing needs of our clients through our engineering and consulting segment and specialized talent solutions segment, which are comprised of a well-developed portfolio of ten specialized business units, which we call Powerhouses, across various countries. We also offer digital recruiting through our dedicated platforms, using our digital tools, including, NOWJOBS, SWOP and Gighouse app, targeting low-skilled, high-volume markets with significant roll-out potential. Since our founding, we have expanded from a presence in only Belgium to more than 10 countries in Europe. Corresponding to our geographic expansion, we have also become more diversified in the endmarkets we serve, primarily through our acquisitions in recent years, which provide us with staffing capabilities in additional areas such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, life sciences, government and public administration and technology. As of September 30, 2022, we had 72,296 job candidates at work and approximately 40,858 productive people at work (meaning the number of our job candidates adjusted to reflect a 38 hour per week workweek) and 4,734 in-house full-time equivalent employees. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we had 31,456 unique clients, our Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue was €2,770.0 million and our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA was €330.5 million. Our engineering and consulting segment represents 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. This segment supplies staffing of highly-skilled professionals, such as engineering consultants and financial and insurance specialists, to fill specialized roles in a variety of end-markets, such as financial, industrial, logistics, infrastructure, public administration and construction, and, more recently, fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors such as energy, telecommunications, pharmaceuticals and technology. This segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals, Redmore, GRITT, Cohedron and SOLCOM Powerhouses and has the broadest geographic footprint, with its primary operations in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. The engineering and consulting segment assists clients in the search and selection of the right candidate, including for interim management and secondments, and such temporary client assignments generally last for months. The below chart illustrates in blue the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for our engineering and consulting segment. ----- Our specialized talent solutions segment represents 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. This segment supplies specialized staffing of high-demand mid-skilled workers for specialized positions, such as clerical positions, carpenters, nurses and machine engineers, as well as blue-collar workers to companies in certain sectors, including construction, retail, finance, food, healthcare and construction. This segment is comprised of our Accent, Covebo, TIMEPARTNER and TMI Powerhouses, with their primary operations in Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany, as well as branches in countries that form part of their international recruiting networks, which currently operate principally for this segment though we are planning to expand them for our engineering and consulting segment. These international branches provide us with the capability to source foreign candidates to bridge the large gap between the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates, especially as the labor market in our Addressable Markets has tightened over the past few years. The Specialized Talent Solution segment generally delivers job candidates through temporary agencies to clients in a fast and flexible way when they are shorthanded, with duration of job placements typically lasting for weeks, but they could also last hours or months depending on the needs of our clients. The below chart illustrates in pink the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for our Specialized Talent Solution segment. We serve as an intermediary between job candidates and their ultimate employer by matching up candidates that are looking to find a job, gain experience or find variety or flexibility with our clients that are looking for specialist skills, flexible employee arrangements, time and cost efficiencies or to cover peaks or sourcing for particular projects. We source and screen candidates, provide candidate matching services and present candidates to the client. We also assist with the hiring of the candidates by customers, client and candidate retention, provide timesheet, invoicing and payroll services, and regularly follow up with clients. We aim to help our clients at all stages of the recruiting process to relieve their management from the burden of having to seek appropriate job candidates for available positions. To ensure that we are able to tap into skilled workforces, we offer career coaching to job candidates in order to help them find career paths that align with their professional goals, and we provide in-house training to equip them to match the job profiles in which they are interested or that are scarce in the market to increase job candidates’ employability. We also offer support to foreign job candidates, including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance. We enter into employment contracts with the candidates and pay their salaries. We enter into placement contracts with our clients and bill our clients for our services. Our bill-pay spread is a key driver of our profitability and supports our industry-leading gross margins. We maximize bill-pay spread as a result of candidate scarcity, our niche focus, our SME and local customer focus, our premium service offering, our excellence in marketing candidates to jobs and non-solicitation or minimum fee/period protection for candidates in respect of clients. We have strong pricing power driven by contractual dynamics that ensure pass-through of salary increases. Our specialized talent solutions segment benefits from contractual dynamics which allow for an automatic pass-through to clients of price increases, and our business model also allows for limited bench risk because staffing contracts are back-to-back. In our engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with our clients, and we effectively manage to keep our bench time low by matching confirmed upcoming client assignments to candidates. The business model of these two segments has enabled us to establish a track record of margin stability even during challenging economic conditions such as the Covid-19 pandemic and in the inflationary environment in 2022. ----- For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we generated 27.6%, 39.8%, 26.0% and 5.5% of our Pro Forma_ Management Adjusted Revenue in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France, respectively. We have branches in the countries where we source job candidates, including Poland, Romania, Spain, Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal. As of September 30, 2022, we had a network of 742 branches and 18 recruitment offices. To complement our physical network of branches and reach new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies, including our SWOP application, our SWOP Recruiter application and our NOWJOBS platform. We have increased our focus on developing digital support growth initiatives for our primary operations to enable us to reach additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner. We support businesses by providing flexible staffing solutions that are used throughout all stages of the economic cycle, resulting in our resilience during economic downturns. While the economy is strong, the job market tightens meaning that our clients need help sourcing candidates. As markets soften, companies typically shift to a more temporary workforce and need staffing solutions and flexibility. When markets reach the bottom of the cycle, temporary staffing suffers but then is characterized by a quick recovery as temporary employment tends to recover faster than permanent employment. For example, during the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, our business recovered from the early losses in approximately three to six weeks. We also have a highly variable cost base and the ability to pass on wage inflation, which supports the stability of our gross margins. For example, our Like-for-Like Revenue growth (based on the December 31, 2021 perimeter) for 2019, 2020 and 2021 fluctuated significantly due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and were 2%, (9)% and 19%, respectively, but we were able to maintain a gross margin of approximately 28% throughout this period. Flexible staffing solutions proved instrumental in the global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, resulting in a full recovery of our sales during the year ended December 31, 2021. During the Covid-19 pandemic, the retail, food retail and hospitality sectors were severely impacted across all our key markets due to lockdowns and other restrictive measures, which led to a significant reduction in our staffing activities in these sectors. Certain sectors, such as logistics and education, however, proved to be less sensitive to the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic, and clients in these sectors continued to seek our services, particularly for high-skilled, specialized roles. In addition, demand for staffing services from municipalities and government agencies during the Covid-19 pandemic increased due to, among other developments, work related to the administration of government support measures, which we were able to capitalize on given our specialization in this end-market provided by the Cohedron Powerhouse in our engineering and consulting segment. We were founded in 1995 by Philip Cracco and Conny Vandendriessche along with a financial sponsor as a Belgium-based recruiting firm. Originally called Accent, we changed our name to House of HR in 2012. Over the course of 2012 to 2014, Naxicap, a French private equity firm, acquired a majority stake in our business, and we have expanded significantly to become a leading provider of specialized HR solutions in multiple European markets. On November 3, 2022, Bain Capital acquired a majority stake in the Group, with Naxicap, Conny Vandendriessche and management maintaining stakes. See “—The _Transactions.”_

Subsubsection Title: Operating in highly resilient markets with favorable tailwinds and structural demand dynamics
Subsubsection Text: The HR solutions market has historically shown quick recovery in demand following periods of economic downturns. The general temporary staffing market, as a whole, has a long-term positive GDP growth trajectory and tends to recover quickly after an economic downturn. Within this market, specialized staffing companies, like us, also benefit from higher resiliency than generalist staffing companies that rely on the low value-add mass labor market. Specialized staffing companies benefit from lower cyclicality compared to generalist staffing companies due to specialty profiles. Specialized staffing companies also benefit from increased penetration with clients compared to generalist staffing ----- companies due to more clients in these specialized sectors turning to staffing solutions providers like us to assist them with candidate searches and provide them with higher value-add solutions. The below graph demonstrates the relative resilience of the specialist temporary staffing companies: Note: Specialists include Alten, Amadeus, Assystem, Page and Robert Half, and Generalists include Adecco, Manpower, Randstad. European Union and national regulations applicable in the key countries in which we operate tend to reinforce protection of permanent workers, which can lead companies to favor temporary work and outsourcing solutions as employers often prefer to hire on a more temporary basis before offering an employee a permanent contract. This trend is especially evident in recovery periods after a trough in the economic cycle as companies seek to scale up their workforce. For example, we were able to quickly recover from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, with our sales fully recovering to pre-Covid 19 levels during 2021. At the same time, legislation in the countries in which we principally operate allows for multiple temporary staffing solutions, further supporting our business model. We believe that high job vacancy rates offer us strong protection from a potential downturn in the nearterm as there would still be significant numbers of unfilled positions even with a reduction in vacancies, which is similar to reductions that occurred during recent downturns. We offer our clients the ability to recruit job candidates with specific profiles for jobs that are particularly difficult to fill, including from abroad where needed, as we draw upon an international talent pool and provide required training. We operate in markets where fundamentals for businesses such as ours are improving over time, supported both by macroeconomic factors and positive structural demographic dynamics. Western Europe generally is experiencing a large, chronic and growing supply and demand gap for skilled employees, particularly related to technical engineering, specialized consulting and specialized blue-collar labor, obliging companies to look beyond traditional job candidate sourcing and seek the help of specialized staffing solutions providers like us. For example, unemployment rates in Germany were at 3.5% in 2021, as compared to 8.7% in 2007. In the Netherlands and Belgium, they were at 4.0% and 6.4%, respectively, in 2021 as compared to a recent peak of 7.4% and 8.5%, respectively, in 2014. Job vacancies in Belgium were at their highest in the second quarter of 2022 since 2012, and in Germany and the Netherlands were at their highest in the second and third quarters of 2022, respectively, since 2007. The staffing industry also benefits from a number of long-term underlying trends that have supported our industry’s historical and projected medium- to long-term growth. Demand for the types of solutions we provide is expected to continue growing in the future due to a number of positive secular trends, including: - Aging populations in our target markets and increasing competition for talent; - Technological changes to job candidates’ search for employment opportunities, including the switch to mobile technology, that are more challenging for employers to handle in-house; ----- - Workers increasingly prioritizing career mobility and focusing on smaller, entrepreneurial opportunities; - The need for workers to train or re-skill to adapt to changing work opportunities; - The desire of companies to address issues relating to diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility; - Workers placing an increased premium on quality of life and happiness at both a personal and professional level, and an increased preference for job flexibility, especially since the Covid19 pandemic, leading to increased job rotation; - Financial pressures resulting in increased outsourcing and offshoring; and - Increasing use of artificial intelligence, data mining and robotization, as well as technological change, all of which contribute to the skill supply-demand gap in labor markets. - Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower job security. As a result of these secular trends, both employers and workers increasingly turn towards flexible staffing models, driving demand for extended workforce solutions. According to an external consultant analysis, in Belgium, Netherlands and France, the number of workers that are part of the extended workforce (i.e., contractors and other freelancers) has grown from 2016 to 2021 at a CAGR of 3.9%, 2.5% and 4.4%, respectively. These growth rates are above those registered in the total working population, which over the same period has grown at a CAGR of 1.0% in Belgium, 1.3% in the Netherlands and 0.4% in France. This is also evidenced by the growth in penetration of the extended workforce as part of the total workforce, with penetration rates in 2021 ranging from 7.2% in France to 10.2% in the Netherlands. We believe we are well positioned to capture penetration in specialized extended labor. These underlying trends contribute to the complexity of job searches and encourage companies to turn to staffing solutions providers like us to help them fulfill their staffing needs. In addition, they make it more challenging for new market entrants to effectively compete with established providers like us. We have strategically positioned ourselves in geographic markets that are supported by macroeconomic factors and positive demand dynamics in order to take full advantage of favorable trends. We believe that the fundamentals of our Addressable Market remain strong in the medium-term and we believe that we are poised to continue growing at or above the industry average growth rate in the future due to our business model.

Subsubsection Title: Increasingly diversified exposure to resilient and profitable end-markets targeting highly loyal and less price-sensitive SME clients, with a focus on scarcity-driven specialist candidates
Subsubsection Text: Our client focus is centered on SMEs and intermediate-sized enterprises that require high-touch local service and operate in specialty niches that are in high demand. This focus supports our above market growth and margins and provides us resilience as a result of the critical nature of the positions sought by our clients. We believe that SMEs represent a particularly attractive client base as they are generally more loyal customers and are less price sensitive. SMEs tend to be more reliant on each employee and have lower workforce anticipation capabilities than large corporates, so the absence of a single worker can be critical. As a result, when they need to hire someone, they need someone fairly quickly and place a premium on the ability to source job candidates within their time constraints. As SMEs may have more limited or no in-house recruiting capabilities, they are more willing to outsource many of their staffing-related needs to providers like us who can provide a full service offering at all stages of the recruitment lifecycle. SMEs often have limited employer branding and therefore may experience difficulty in reaching the best job candidates without access to the talent pool of a staffing solutions provider. SMEs also often have a faster decision-making process compared to large corporates and lack purchasing departments, so we may face less pricing pressure from such companies. In addition, SMEs, ----- due to the smaller size of their employee pools, are less likely to lay off workers in a downturn and typically maintain a more consistent level of employment than larger companies during a downturn. The stability of employee levels at SMEs was evident during the global financial crisis as, based on information from Accent, employment volumes were resilient at small companies and demonstrated growth from 2008 to 2016. We have a track record of serving the attractive SME segment, with a focus on scarcity-driven specialist candidates. We believe that the ability to find a specific candidate with the right cultural fit is important for SMEs, since they typically have small teams and often seek a particular candidate who is not only qualified for the job, but also matches the client’s corporate culture. Our ability to match such job candidates results from our blend of human and digital touchpoints, with regular interaction with clients and job candidates throughout the recruitment lifecycle (including our international recruiting capabilities). HR staffing solutions also operate in a complex regulatory environment, and we provide our clients with the required specific knowledge by sector, geography and even region. We believe the ability to manage this complexity on a large scale increases the barriers to entry for the sector and diminishes the risk for digital disruption or disintermediation. In addition to our focus on SMEs, we focus on specialist candidates, which provides further resilience to our business as skilled jobs are less cyclical. For example, in France, the unemployment rate for unskilled jobs has had an approximately 8% variation between 2000 and 2020 as compared to a rate of approximately 2% for skilled workers as demonstrated by the chart below. Source: Company information, External consultant analysis, INSEE Note: Based on France. Skilled works are defined as those with two years of post-high school diploma education (baccalaureate) and unskilled workers are defined as those who hold no diploma In particular, we focus on specialty niches that are in high demand and that support higher revenue growth and margins than generalist staffing. We market our services under brands that relate to specific specialized services offered by our Powerhouses or sub business-unit or brands under a Powerhouse, which we call Boutiques. Our multiple brand approach has proven effective in attracting and retaining clients and candidates. For example, our Facebook page of Accent currently has, in most instances, ----- almost twice the number of followers (61.0K) than the Facebook pages of our competitors Randstad Belgium (27.0K), RGF Staffing (Start People) (35.0K) or Adecco Belgium (39.0K) as of November 2022. We also benefit from having diversified our business activities towards more resilient end-markets and job candidate profiles. Our new business structure is reflective of our strategy, which is geared towards moving away from general staffing to a more specialized staffing focus. For the year ended December 31, 2018, our business mix included more of a focus on general staffing, with 15% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA coming from our general staffing segment, 46% from our engineering and consulting segment and 39% from our specialized staffing segment (based on our consolidation perimeter for 2018) whereas for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) was attributable to our engineering and consulting segment and 46.5% was attributable to our specialized talent solution segment (which includes general staffing). We also have actively increased our endmarket mix to focus on public sector, IT and telecommunications, healthcare, food and financial and legal end-markets, which are more resilient throughout the economic cycle. The below chart shows our revenue for the year ended December 2018 by end-market compared to our Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue by end-market for the year ended December 31, 2021. Source: Company information. (1) 2018 revenue figures are presented pro forma for the December 31, 2018 consolidation perimeter (2) 2021 revenue figures are presented pro forma for the December 31, 2021 consolidation perimeter, including impact of TMI and SOLCOM as if they had been part of the December 31, 2021 consolidation perimeter Through our business segments and brands in our core geographies, we provide HR solutions that meet most of the critical job shortages in those markets. Our focus on niche and specialty staffing highlights the added value we can provide to companies looking for specific job candidate profiles which are often difficult to find, and in our experience, clients are willing to attach a premium to such services. Our focus on niche and specialty staffing also enables us to recruit and retain qualified job candidates. Even when we serve large corporate clients, we believe our provision of specialized staffing solutions enables us to maintain pricing power as a result of the quality of and demand for our job candidates. ----- We believe that our geographic footprint, branch density and our ability to recruit internationally are challenging to replicate and are essential to fostering the client relationships and granular geographic reach necessary to reach our targeted SME and specialty-focused clients. We maintain and have access to a large database of job candidates to enable short matching times and have acquired in-depth endmarket experience through selective organic and external growth over many years, which facilitates our ability to source, match and retain job candidates and clients in our key markets.

Subsubsection Title: Outstanding performance throughout the cycle demonstrating highly resilient profile
Subsubsection Text: We have grown our business over recent years both organically and through targeted, strategic and value-accretive acquisitions. From 2008 to 2021, our Like-for-Like Revenue grew at a compound annual growth rate of 7.8%. We believe that our largely consistent positive Like-for-Like Revenue growth in each business segment and for the pro forma perimeter outperforms the market and evidences the success of our differentiated business model. In addition, we achieved Organic Growth of 19.9% in the year ended December 31, 2021, and 17.2% in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Our Likefor-Like Revenue growth across the various stages of the economic cycle from 2008 demonstrates the resilience of our revenues and our ability to recover from economic downturns at a more rapid rate than GDP. We have been able to maintain strong EBITDA margins even through challenging macroeconomic conditions. The chart below portrays our Like-for-Like Revenue growth from 2008 to the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 showing our organic and external growth and our EBITDA margins, including the unaudited business unit accounts of Accent, as well as those of our other business units, on the basis as described in the notes below. Source: Company information, OECD Notes: In preparing the above chart, we have included historical revenue information based on business unit accounts from various periods, past due diligence reports and management analysis. The total amounts include corporate costs. Although we believe the underlying materials used and the basis of preparation to be reasonable, actual results may vary from the indicative information presented above, in particular due to different accounting bases of preparation, and such variations could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on the inclusion of such information. Furthermore, the growth presented in the chart is prepared on a different basis than our Organic Growth presented elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “ Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Statutory and management _account information.”_ (1) Total revenue figures include intercompany eliminations; figures for 2008 to twelve months ended September 30, 2022 are based on the December 31, 2020 perimeter (including Solyne and Greenworking and excluding avanti, Cohedron, Bureau Brug, SOLCOM, TMI, ----- Sira Consulting, Vijverberg, Atrium, BE-Consult, Bis People, LD Personalvermittlung, StaffMe, FID Service Groep, Agium and ABMI and disposal of GRITT Projects). (2) IFRS lease related amounts for 2008 to 2017 are based on the assumption that IFRS lease related amounts equals percentage of IFRS lease related amounts divided by Revenue for 2019. We have been able to navigate through crises by sustaining high levels of organic growth across cycles, including during the global financial crisis in 2008 and the Covid-19 pandemic, demonstrating the resilience of our business model. The below graph illustrates our Like-for-Like Revenue growth across the various economic cycles. Source: Company information. Note: Total revenue figures include intercompany eliminations; figures for 2008 to twelve months ended September 30, 2022 are presented based on December 31, 2020 perimeter (including Solyne and Greenworking and excluding avanti, Cohedron, Bureau Brug, SOLCOM, TMI, Atrium, BE-Consult, Bis People, LD Personalvermittlung, StaffMe, FID Service Groep, Agium and ABMI and disposal of GRITT Projects). We also have a strong track record of external growth through highly accretive acquisitions in a fragmented market. We approach our growth through acquisitions with rigorous discipline. We focus on acquiring successful, profitable companies rather than turn-around acquisitions. Our evaluation of a potential acquisition target includes reviewing the opportunity through the rubric of a number of stringent requirements designed to ensure fit with our overall strategy and culture. The target must fit an identified strategic need to expand our geographic coverage, complement a specific specialty or fill a niche skill gap. We also seek out targets with like-minded management teams with an entrepreneurial spirit and long-term commitment in order to ensure a strong overall cultural fit. We also evaluate the target’s profitability, historic growth and other performance metrics, and assess whether it is a leader in its addressable markets. Once we have identified and then acquired a target, we have a well-defined and proven integration process that involves consolidating the target into our Group reporting system and sharing best practices. Local management teams are given the opportunity to invest at group level or to continue to invest at the local level. We have completed 42 transactions since 2018, comprised of bolton acquisitions with lower multiples that enable growth at the local level, as well as platform acquisitions through which we expand our solutions and enter new specialties or markets. We have an excellent integration track record with our targets’ EBITDA and revenue growing by approximately 8% per annum and 10% on average after we integrated them, as demonstrated by our acquisitions of Abylsen, Covebo, Continu, TIMEPARTNER and Redmore. See “Business—Engineering and _Consulting” and “Business—Specialized Talent Solutions.”_

Subsubsection Title: Reference player in target markets with proven track record of above-market performance delivering higher margins driven by highly incentivized management team
Subsubsection Text: ----- We occupy leading positions across the highly fragmented markets in which we operate. Many of our operating companies are reference players within their respective specialty, benefiting from the virtuous cycle of competitive leadership, with their track record, enabling them to capture a high percentage of their market growth and benefiting from brand loyalty and pricing power as a result. The table below shows our relative market positioning vis-à-vis our peers: Source: External consultant analysis; peer companies’ filings; Company information (1) Based on a numerical mean of revenue growth percentage of each entity. For peers based on last four to five years average, apart from local players (based on 2019 excluding Assystem), and with respect to House of HR, based on over the cycle performance. (2) For each peer, based on a numerical mean of latest publicly available EBITDA margin (post IFRS-16) as a percentage and with respect to House of HR, based on the results of operation for 2021. Based on Net Promoter Scores, we are the most recommended HR solutions provider by customers in the Netherlands and second most recommended HR solutions provider by SME customers in Belgium. In addition, based on Google reviews, we are the most recommended HR solutions provider by job candidate in Belgium and second most recommended HR solutions provider by job candidates in the Netherlands. Our clients make staffing decisions at a local level and our large footprint with high branch density allows us to be physically present in the communities where our clients operate, meaning that clients have a familiarity with our brand at a local level, which provides a key competitive advantage for us. We believe we are unique among our peers and that this is reflected in our performance compared to certain of our competitors. Our Like-for-Like Revenue grew at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 8% from 2008 to 2021 (based on our 2020 consolidation perimeter excluding avanti, Cohedron, SOLCOM and TMI and including Solyne and Greenworking) as compared to the Organic Growth average (weighted by business mix) of our peer benchmark, including Adecco, Randstad and Alten, which grew at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2% during the same period. In addition, we have a track record of significant growth above market, with nominal GDP growing at annual compound growth rate of approximately 1% from 2008 to 2021 (based on the nominal GDP growth for the Eurozone) and the volume of the number of temporary workers (based on a weighted average of publicly available information in Germany, Belgium, France and the Netherlands) having a negative annual compound growth rate during the same period. We also enjoyed best-in-class profitability compared to our specialist and generalist peers. This is demonstrated by the below chart comparing our EBITDA margins on a total basis, for our engineering and consulting segment and for ----- our specialized staffing solutions segment for the year ended December 31, 2021 to the EBITDA margins of some of our specialist and generalist peers for the same period. Source: Peer companies’ filings; Company information. Note: December 31, 2021 figures for House of HR based on December 31, 2020 perimeter. Figures for Amadeus Fire are based on the Personnel Services division excluding the Training division. 1 Average is calculated as the numerical mean of percentage of EBITDA margin. We believe our above-market performance is driven by our strong entrepreneurial culture and local incentivization model. We operate on a strong incentivization model with fast promotion opportunities, including opportunities to open new branches where a manager generates new business. Our variable bonus systems are intended to encourage growth and bonuses as we do not have bonus caps. Variable pay can represent up to 50% of the salary package for our employees, including the management of our business units, branch managers, sales consultants and recruitment consultants. The below chart illustrates the potential pay for one of our account managers on a base salary of €33,000 as compared to an account manager on a base salary of €35,000 at one of our competitors, which demonstrates the additional opportunities provided by us. Source: Company information, External consultant analysis We believe our model encourages winning behaviors from our employees, driven by an owner mindset. We have highly invested top-level and mid-level managers, with 412 managers having reinvested approximately 63% of the net proceeds received from the Acquisition in the new structure, which confirms their belief in House of HR and our business model. Including new joiners, currently approximately 500 members of management are invested in the company. Such investment encourages employees to focus on building relationships, both with clients and candidates, which helps to support our performance. We also typically offer an appealing value proposition to managers of the businesses we acquire by allowing these individuals to retain autonomy over their respective entities’ operations, including brand and identity, while allowing them to benefit from central support on complex regulatory and compliance topics, access to our foreign sourcing network and digital platforms and access to our financing. We also offer such managers an incentive structure tied to, where possible, both their own company’s and our overall results. We believe that this streamlines the integration process and helps to align the management of our acquisition targets with our central management. Together with the support of our new sponsor, Bain Capital, we replaced our long-term incentive plan, which was settled on or about the Acquisition Closing Date, with a new one on the Acquisition Closing Date in order to maintain our culture of incentivization and increase employee commitment and engagement. We also believe ----- that our long-term incentive plan allows for succession planning for key roles by incentivizing key staff to remain with the business and by enabling potential reinvestments in the equity of House of HR going forward.

Subsubsection Title: Ability to pass through wage increases to customers, including through automatic contractual mechanisms, and stable margins
Subsubsection Text: We have the ability to pass through wage increases from inflation to customers in both our engineering and consulting segment and our specialized talent solutions segment, which, coupled with our flexible cost structure, has resulted in resilient gross margins. While our gross margins in both of our segments fluctuate somewhat as a result of seasonality around holiday periods, they have remained largely stable since January 2019 at approximately 22% to 28% (depending on Powerhouses and specialties) for our specialized talent solutions segment and approximately 30% to 37% for our engineering and consulting segment. Our revenues typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due to our ability to pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment and stable margins. In our specialized talent solutions segment, price increases are automatically passed through to our clients. For this segment, our contract model is centered on matching the length of our candidate’s employment contract with us to the length of our placement contract with our client, the ultimate employer, in order to prevent lag time between inflation of gross salary paid to the candidate and the cost we charge to our clients, which results in an automatic pass-through of any salary increases. As contracts expire, we renegotiate them, which has historically resulted in an ability to increase our prices in line with wage inflation. We base our contract pricing on a candidate’s gross salary multiplied by a coefficient factor, with the split typically being transparent to the client. Our coefficient factors tend to remain relatively stable with slight fluctuations as a result of seasonality around holiday periods. For example, Accent’s coefficient factor has remained relatively stable since 2020 at an average of 2.2. The key pricing drivers for the coefficient factor are the scarcity of candidates and the value of any additional services we offer. Key costs for us include salaries and work accident insurance. At the end of the contract period, typically one week or one month in length, if salary increases, then we charge the cost of the higher salary to the client. During the first half of 2022, we achieved average price increases of approximately 5.0% (calculated as the numerical mean of the average price increases across certain Powerhouses, weighted equally). Growth in euro-per-hour billed in our specialized talent solutions segment is driven by increasing cost per hour paid and billed, as well as through increasing bench costs. Our gross margin per hour billed remained highly stable at approximately 23% to 25% (including bench costs) and approximately 29% to 30% (excluding bench costs) for each of the nine months ended September 30, 2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022 as shown in the below chart. Source: Company information, External consultant analysis Note: GM0 = Gross Margin on billed hours only (excl. bench costs); GM = Gross Margin (incl. bench costs / unbilled hours). Difference between GM0 and GM is bench cost. Bench costs include paid sickness and paid holiday. ----- 1 Excluding Atrium and BE-Consult given ongoing integration. In our engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with clients. The contracts are typically time and material contracts with no obligations for any specific result. Most of our candidates in our engineering and consulting segment are permanently hired by us using employment contracts that typically have three- to six-week notice periods. We have placement contracts with our clients that typically last nine to twelve months, which allows us to effectively manage bench time and match our candidates with the upcoming mandates from clients. In most cases, we plan for salary increases in advance and negotiate rate increases with our clients accordingly. Our pricing model in our engineering and consulting segment centers on charging the client an hourly or daily rate. Our billing rate is typically based on an hourly wage and a mark-up where the split is usually not transparent to clients. Since 2021, we have been able to consistently increase our hourly rate in this segment. For example, at Talent&Pro, one of our Redmore Boutiques that focuses on the finance industry staffing, although our hourly rate fluctuated between €46.8 and €48.1 per hour during the course of 2020, by the end of December 2021 we were able to increase it to approximately €49.6, and have continued to increase it during the course of 2022, with an hourly rate of €53.5 as of September 2022. Key drivers of the hourly or daily rates are skills, seniority and scarcity of candidates. Our key costs include salary, potentially including a company car. At the end of a placement contract, renewal either entails replacing the candidate with a new or more junior person at a new price or placing the same candidate, who is now more senior, at a higher price. During the first half of 2022, we achieved average price increases of approximately 6.6% (calculated as the numerical mean of the average price increases across certain Powerhouses, weighted equally). Margin growth in our engineering and consulting segment is driven by increasing the cost per hour paid and billed. Bench-time risk is effectively managed by matching confirmed upcoming client assignments to candidates. Our gross margin per hour billed in this segment also remained stable at approximately 32% to 34% (including bench costs) and approximately 45% to 47% (excluding bench costs) for each of the nine months ended September 30, 2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022. Source: Company information, External consultant analysis Note: GM0 = Gross Margin on billed hours only (excl. bench costs); GM = Gross Margin (incl. bench costs / unbilled hours). Difference between GM0 and GM is bench cost. Bench costs include paid sickness and paid holiday. 1 Excluding Cohedron, Sira Consulting and Vijverberg due to data unavailability.

Subsubsection Title: Robust financial profile supports cash generation with a highly variable cost base and proven ability to deleverage
Subsubsection Text: Our business model has supported strong EBITDA growth and profitability. We demonstrated our financial resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic with strong EBITDA margins of 11%, 10% and 12% for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, and 11% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, respectively. We have limited capital expenditure requirements (primarily related ----- to IT investments and expenditures for the purchase of property, plant and equipment and intangibles, primarily related to our headquarters, furniture and infrastructure for our branch network, accommodation for foreign job candidates, company cars) of approximately 1% of revenue in each of 2019, 2020 and 2021. As our key assets are the talent we provide to meet the temporary staffing needs of our clients, we have limited fixed assets or cash tied up in inventory. Working capital largely consists of receivables (client billings) and payables (job candidate wages, social security, etc.) tied to individual job candidate placements. The receivable for each job candidate placement is typically higher than the payable with the difference roughly representing the bill-pay spread or gross margin embedded in the client service agreement and job candidate agreement. Working capital as a percentage of sales for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, was 4.9% of sales, compared to 2.1% for the year ended December 31, 2021. The working capital dynamics and corresponding downside protection for our cash flows are also evident in our recent performance. As volumes of job candidates reduce, for instance, during period of economic downturns, we benefit from significant working capital inflows, which gives us strong cash resiliency. In 2020, we experienced a positive change in working capital demonstrating the counter-cyclical nature of our working capital profile. As a result, we experience high cash conversion and cash flow growth, which has, in turn, supported our business growth, and has in the past, allowed us to deleverage on a net debt basis following each of our refinancings. The following chart shows our Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow and our Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow as a percentage of EBITDA cash for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021. We also benefit from a flexible cost structure, with approximately 95% of our costs being variable or semi-variable allowing for highly stable gross margins through the cycle. For 2021, approximately 65.1% of our total operating expenses were variable, 31.7% were semi-variable and 3.2% were fixed costs. Our cost of services, which represented 79.1% of our total operational expenses (cost of services and operating expenses together) for the year ended December 31, 2021, is comprised of mostly variable costs related to our people at work (mainly payroll, social security contributions, housing, car fleet and subcontracting costs). Our direct costs linked to our branches are primarily semi-variable and include staff costs, including costs of managers and recruiters, and branch expenses, such as rents, car leases and training, marketing and communication costs. Our overheads related to corporate functions at both an operating company and Group-level, which represented less than 5% of our total operating expenses, consists primarily of fixed costs. Further, due to our back-to-back contract model, we experience limited bench risk in respect of people at work. In many of our jurisdictions, we are able to match the duration of the employment of our job candidates and their placement, allowing us to be flexible in the deployment of our job candidate resources. As costs generally track revenue, costs of service as a percentage of revenue, and as a result, our margins, generally remain stable during downturns, as demonstrated during the Covid-19 pandemic. -----

Subsubsection Title: We are well-protected from disruption by other digital players and have developed an emerging platform for excellent proprietary digital offering
Subsubsection Text: We have an excellent proprietary digital offering and based on interviews with market participants we believe we are well-protected from disruption from typical digital players that focus on a low-skilled, higher volume business. We believe we are differentiated from such market participants because our core offering is focused on specialty staffing and focused on SMEs that require customized services, which are much more difficult to standardize or automate. We believe that we are a thought leader and ahead of our larger peers in many respects as a result of our development of digital initiatives in order to both address new markets with innovative business models and improve our own and existing operations. To complement our physical network of branches and reach new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies that are revenuegenerating. Our NOWJOBS platform, which successfully competes in the low-skill, higher volume segment, is primarily geared to students and other seekers of one-off temporary jobs, and is to date our most successful digital initiative. Originally just available in Belgium where it launched in 2017, we launched NOWJOBS in the Netherlands in 2019, in France in 2021 and in Germany in June 2022, bringing on board big customers such as retail brands H&M and Picnic. For the year ended December 31, 2021, NOWJOBS handled approximately 1.1 billion requests and generated €54.1 million, €1.9 million and €0.2 million in revenues in Belgium, the Netherlands, and France, respectively. Following our acquisition of StaffMe in July 2022, NOWJOBS will operate under the StaffMe brand in France given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country. In addition, we launched our SWOP Recruiter application in May 2021, which is a free digital platform that helps Belgian SMEs with the day-to-day management of their vacancies. The application is linked to our SWOP application, which we launched in 2016 and further upgraded in 2020, and is now one of the largest Belgian apps to help job seekers find a new permanent job. We launched SWOP in the Netherlands in October 2022 and plan to launch SWOP in Germany in the near future. Our Gighouse app is a digital platform that matches freelancers and independent job candidates with available projects at our customers. We aim to leverage our experience as a disruptor in the market to expand successful initiatives to our broader Group. In addition, we have also developed a number of complementary digital offerings that supplement our core services. For example, in June 2019, we launched our MyAccent app, which allows potential job candidates to interact via the Google Home assistant with Accent’s list of open positions. Book’u is our planning tool, allowing customers to plan both their permanent and temporary workforce in one solution, being in touch with this workforce to communicate when they should be available and allowing to spot potential staffing shortages, immediately posting these shortages at their staffing companies of choice. My Talents (Softskillz) testing has been developed together with the University of Ghent, to test ‘who you are’ as a person and to test ‘what type of company do I want to work for.’ These tests will allow for better AI matching of jobs with candidates. Continu-Connect, which launched in 2021 and had 756 registered contacts as of December 31, 2021, shows all available candidates in a region for our customers. Our FYGI app brings together freelance HR recruiters with companies that have a recruitment request. We have also other apps and platforms that assist with the recruitment and other staffing processes, such as Dora, Ariad and CV Creator. All apps are developed taking into account reusability across all House of HR operating companies, benefitting therefore from the economies of scale House of HR has versus local competitors and increasing the barriers to entry for our industry. During 2021, we centralized all our digital assets in House of Invest, creating one platform to meet current needs and invest in new needs as they arise. This enabled us to further invest in our digital roadmap and internationalize our digital initiatives, bringing our digital and IT talents together to work on multiple digital solutions. The main purpose of House of Invest is to roll out the digital initiatives across all House of HR Powerhouses and Boutiques and to capitalize on a centralized knowledge base. House of Invest now owns NOWJOBS, Gighouse, SWOP and SWOP Recruiter, Continu-Connect, CV creator and My Talents (Softskillz), and holds minority ownerships in Dora and Ariad (a traditional digital marketing staffing company) and a majority ownership in Book’u. ----- For the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue from digital solutions amounted to 2.6% of total revenue, compared to 1.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. We have continued investing in IT in 2022 and expect to continue prioritizing the digital venue going forward. We believe our digital offering protects us from disruptions from digital players who focus on low-skilled, high volume business, while our platforms continue to focus on high-skilled job candidates with a focus on SMEs. We are also continuing to innovate our existing processes by identifying areas within our business that could benefit from increased automation and zero-paper processes, including both job candidate- and client-facing and internal processes, such as finance, procurement and marketing and communications. Further, we continue to digitalize our processes and create a centralized repository designed to store, process and secure large amounts of data across our different applications, which will enhance our access to job candidates and improve our matching capabilities. We believe the efficiencies we can realize through this digitalization will produce cost savings while allowing us to meet the everincreasing demands of clients and job candidates.

Subsubsection Title: Entrepreneurial and invested management team with long-term incentive culture backed by a new, highly supportive shareholder with deep industry knowledge
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from a strong and committed management team that is highly motivated to deliver strong performance over the long term. We believe our successful organic and external growth has been due in part to the way in which we have been able to incentivize our managers. For example, our organic “cell division” expansion strategy rewards our local managers with the opportunity to create and run individual branches, fostering loyalty and encouraging the entrepreneurial spirit that has delivered our success to date. For our engineering and consulting branches, our variable pay structure rewards management down to the sales and recruitment consultants with variable pay linked to key performance indicators such as attracting, matching and retaining job candidates and clients. While keeping a highly entrepreneurial culture at the Powerhouse and Boutique levels, all strategic decisions with a significant impact are made at House of HR level, and our local business units share in the centralized corporate support and institutional knowledge. We now also benefit from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of our new shareholder, Bain Capital. Bain Capital has a strong track record of investing in the business services space with over 50 current or past investments. Bain Capital has invested in businesses in the staffing and engineering consulting services, including Quest, a leading global engineering services provider, MSX International, a BPO company focused on technical staffing solutions and managed services, Inetum, an IT services provider in France, and Engineering, an IT systems and services provider in Italy, as well as other investments in the business services space, including Autodistribution and Bravida. Following the Acquisition, our management continues to remain invested in the equity of the Group, having reinvested approximately 63% of the net proceeds received from the Acquisition in the Group, totaling approximately €255.0 million, or between 20% to 25% of ownership of the Group.
We believe we benefit from the following key strengths:

Subsubsection Title: Make use of our agile, decentralized operating model to further focus on organic growth by grasping additional market share while maintaining best-in-class profitability
Subsubsection Text: Over the years, we have been highly successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth under our “cell division” approach in our specialized talents solutions segment as clients are mostly SMEs who require high touch local services. In most of our markets, we expect to continue our strategy of embedding ourselves in local communities through an extensive branch network. While our primary operations are in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France, we have branches spread across countries where we source job candidates. Our international recruiting network is key for our ability to attract and retain job candidates for assignments in sectors where candidates are scarce. Our decentralized structure places our Powerhouses and Boutiques in proximity to our primary stakeholders: ----- our clients, our job candidates and our own employees, which allows us to gain local market knowledge, understand local competition and remain informed of local staffing trends. In order to continue to grow, we intend to expand our branch network where needed and to continue to leverage our success in sourcing and retaining job candidates, focusing on those job profiles which are and will be increasingly scarce in the market. We also believe our extensive branch network approach leads to enhanced entrepreneurship and ownership due to the managerial responsibilities and opportunities allocated or available to branch managers, reinforcing a key part of our values. We also intend to continue to focus on, and leverage our positive track record in, our engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions segments to continue growing profitably. We have gradually shifted our focus toward the engineering and consulting and specialized staffing model and away from general staffing, benefiting from our growing network in the transition to deliver higher margins. The specialized staffing and engineering and consulting segments tend to deliver higher margins than general staffing due to the premium clients place on successful placement of the specific job candidates that they seek. Specialization in turn aims to target those segments and skills that are more difficult to find for our customers, which in the past has provided more stability to our revenue figures and protected our margins, including during economic downturns. We further aim to deliver continued improvement in our adjusted EBITDA margin through efficient cost control over operating expense and strong cash conversion with rigorous management of capital expenditures and working capital. We believe our agile organization and increased specialization will continue to promote flexibility for our Powerhouses and Boutiques to refine recruitment approaches and conduct day-to-day activities that best meet their respective local business needs and enable us to offer clients tailored staffing services. We believe this will continue to translate into higher market penetration and additional market share to propel our organic growth, as well as our ability to effectively staff specialized jobs that drive our bestin-class profitability given the scarcity and complexity of the job profiles we match.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance our reputation as the partner of choice for SMEs and locally managed clients
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue providing critical end-to-end temporary recruiting and outsourcing services that are tailored to the needs of SMEs and other locally-managed clients. We believe that in the future these clients, in both our engineering and consulting segment and specialized talent solutions segment, will continue to require the assistance of providers like us primarily for temporary HR solutions as they grapple with limited resources, lower visibility on staffing needs and greater need for outsourced HR functions, including as a result of the complexity of labor law and associated regulations. As the partner of choice for our SMEs and locally managed clients, we are experienced in accommodating unique and time-sensitive client demands, including matching specialized, “mission-critical” profiles for our clients in the engineering and consulting segment that typically last for months, or deploying a large number of blue-collar workers at short notice for our clients in the specialized talent solutions segment that often last for weeks or sometimes just hours as the situations require. We plan to continue focusing on being the partner of choice for SMEs and locally managed clients by leveraging the large pool of potential job candidates at our disposal and the deep end-market knowledge we have gathered over the years by having boots on the ground in proximity to our clients.

Subsubsection Title: Ensure the smooth and profitable placement of job candidates with a reliable sourcing and reskilling platform
Subsubsection Text: Mastering the “human” aspect of human resources is key to success in our industry, and we intend to continue to be a leader through our focus on being able to source the right job candidate for the right position, including through offering reskilling services. We believe that our network of international sourcing of job candidates is vital to our success, as we are better able to bridge the large gap between the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates, especially as the labor market in our Addressable Market has tightened over the past few years, through having access to a wider pool of quality job candidates than our peers. The location of our agencies (particularly in Poland, Romania, Spain, the Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal) and the support we offer to foreign job candidates ----- (including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance) ensures that we are able to tap into workforces that are skilled but that are eager to seek out opportunities to earn higher wages than those that similar work would provide in their home countries. We intend to continue to develop our network in other countries that meet these criteria. We also plan to continue leveraging our large sourcing network to target the best job candidates and provide them with a wide array of positions and support, including in-house training that equips them with skillsets that match the profiles that our clients look for, administrative support, client knowledge and even transport and housing for foreign job candidates to make their experience as smooth as possible. Finally, we plan to focus on preparing job candidates for what we see as the jobs of tomorrow, such as white-collar positions in big data and information technology, that are being driven by the digitalization of the economy or provide training in order to teach blue-collar job candidates how to use digital tools.

Subsubsection Title: Utilize digital initiatives to reduce cost and drive revenue diversification
Subsubsection Text: Our digital strategy is focused on maximizing the impact of digital cost reduction initiatives, outpacing smaller competitors who have more limited investment capabilities and opening new market segments. In the near-term, we want to leverage digital tools to complement our physical networks to attract job candidates and clients while also spreading awareness of our brands and services. We also intend to continue digitalizing our processes to drive efficiency. For example, SWOP, our free digital sourcing platform that assists SMEs with day-to-day management of their vacancies, strengthens our sourcing capability and supplements the activities of our revenue-generating business units, such as NOWJOBS, which facilitates the actual matching of job candidates with clients. Over the longer term, we intend to pursue a four-pillared digital strategy. First, we aim to reposition the offices we have in urban areas into “JobShops” that are easy to reach, convenient, one-stop shops where job candidates can be tested, get certifications and be matched with potential positions through our digital platforms that require limited involvement of our recruiting consultants. We also are continuing to develop niche, specialized digital platforms that are tailored to meet the specific demands of the various markets we address. Furthermore, we intend to utilize the data that we have generated through our large network to deliver the best possible client and job candidate service through our candidate data platform. For example, we are currently developing Mission Akira, a data-driven tool that helps to train our consultants on the kind of information that they should ask candidates for in order to better prepare them for placement. We are also developing a client version of the ‘Who do I want to work for’ test, which indicates the type of job candidates that fit best with a particular team leader, and the ‘My brains’ test which attempts to indicate the intelligence level of a job candidate within their education level. We also plan to develop more automated processes to free up our recruiting consultants’ time for them to focus on growing ever closer to our client and job candidate base and gather the right information that will lead to faster and better matching. As part of our digital strategy, we are in the process of rolling out our digital platforms internationally to enable us to get more structured and accurate information from job candidates, so we can match them with the right clients in a more effective and flexible manner, which we believe will help introduce brand loyalty and help us with client and job candidates retention. For example, NOWJOBS was first launched in Belgium in 2017, and it was subsequently launched in the Netherlands in 2019, in France in 2021 and most recently in Germany in 2022. We also acquired StaffMe in July 2022, a French digital platform focusing on student employment and which is primarily active in the retail, health event and hospitality sectors, supplementing our NOWJOBS offering. Through this acquisition, we also acquired the other companies of the StaffMe group, including the StaffMe Academy, the first training organization for young entrepreneurs, and the Accelerator, a program of integration through selfemployment for those who are far from employment. NOWJOBS will operate under the StaffMe brand in France given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country. We plan to continue to develop our other digital platforms and roll them out beyond their current markets.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to target accretive acquisition opportunities to achieve European leadership
Subsubsection Text: ----- While our primary focus is to grow our earnings base organically and to improve both profitability and Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow generation through our existing network and customer base, we will continue to consider accretive and strategic platform and bolt-on acquisitions in both new and existing markets to achieve our goal of European leadership. We do not consider acquisition opportunities aimed at turning around a business, but only will consider opportunities that can reinforce our market positions or expand our footprint, either in new geographical regions or niche areas in which we currently are not present and that exhibit the following attributes: stable economies with low unemployment, high salary level, high temporary staff penetration, a stable regulatory environment and supply and demand mismatch for skilled labor. We will continue to focus on acquisitions of highly specialized businesses (such as IT, legal and finance), business focusing on bottleneck jobs and engineering and consulting services. We will also consider opportunities in digital tools that can improve the value chain or allow us to better serve job candidates as well as clients and to develop new and complementary segments that are also marked by labor market scarcity or that can demonstrate the prospect for high growth and superior margins. We will continue to use our M&A assessment criteria, which requires that any opportunity meets our own high quality standards, holds a leading position in its respective specialized end-market, reflects a strong financial profile and represents a good cultural fit with us. While we historically have focused on bolt-on acquisitions that can enhance our network and/or provide us with exposure to complementary sectors of the economy, we also occasionally consider larger acquisitions that are otherwise consistent with our investment criteria. We are also targeting, in particular, certain new end-markets such as healthcare and pharmaceuticals and new geographic markets such as the Nordic countries and other countries, such as Austria and Switzerland.
We and the Sponsor have developed the following strategies:

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte _aansprakelijkheid) organized and existing under the laws of the Netherlands with registration number_ 86433792 and domiciled in Amsterdam, having its registered office in Strawinslylaan 1209, WTC Tower A, 12th floor, 1077 XX Amsterdam, The Netherlands. The Issuer has no material assets or liabilities and has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its formation and the Transactions. The Issuer is indirectly controlled by the Sponsor.

Bain Capital indirectly held approximately 55.0% of the shares in the Issuer as of the Acquisition Closing Date. Bain Capital is a leading global private investment firm that advises and manages capital across several asset classes, including private equity, public equity, fixed income and credit, venture capital and real estate investments across multiple sectors, industries and geographies. Since its inception in 1984, it has made private equity investments in more than 1,300 companies and currently has approximately $160 billion in assets under management. Collectively, more than 10% of Bain’s private equity funds’ commitments come from its professionals. Bain Capital has over 650 investment professionals worldwide spread throughout its global network in Europe, Asia and North America, with a depth of expertise in key vertical industries including healthcare, consumer/retail, financial and business services, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital has investors from across the world that include sovereign wealth funds, public pension funds, foundations, insurance companies, family offices, high net worth individuals and funds of funds. Headquartered in Boston, Bain Capital has over 1,500 team members across 23 offices worldwide, including in Chicago, Dublin, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, Lisbon, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Melbourne, Mumbai, Munich, New York, Palo Alto, San Francisco, Seoul, Shanghai, Singapore, Sydney and Tokyo. Bain Capital has a strong track record of investing in the business services space with over 50 current or past investments. Bain Capital has invested in businesses in the staffing and engineering consulting services, including Quest, a leading global engineering services provider, MSX International, a BPO company focused on technical staffing solutions and managed services, Inetum, an IT services provider in France, and Engineering, an IT systems and services provider in Italy, as well as other investments in the business services space, including Autodistribution and Bravida. -----

On May 28, 2022, the Issuer entered into a share purchase agreement (as amended on November 2, 2022, the “Acquisition Agreement”), by and among, inter alios, the Issuer and the sellers named therein (the “Sellers”) relating to the transfer by the Sellers and the acquisition by the Issuer, directly and/or indirectly, of all of the issued and outstanding share capital of House of HR. The Acquisition was consummated on November 3, 2022 (the “Acquisition Closing Date”). The purchase price for the Acquisition, including the repayment of the Existing Notes and the Existing Facilities, was €2,676.7 million (the “Purchase Price”). In addition, the Acquisition Agreement contains certain agreed earn-outs which may subsequently become payable to the Sellers in the event that certain conditions are met in the future, including an earn-out of up to €110.0 million depending on the level of the Group’s EBITDA for the fiscal years 2022 and 2023. Pursuant to the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, on the Acquisition Closing Date, Naxicap Partners, Ms. Vandendriessche, House of HR’s co-founder, and certain reinvesting managers and other minority shareholders reinvested a certain portion of their Acquisition proceeds (or rolled over all or part of the shares they held, directly or indirectly, in House of HR), through either (i) contributions in cash, (ii) roll-up contributions of part of the receivables they would come to hold against the purchaser (or any of its affiliates) in the context of the Acquisition (in respect of the purchase price due to them) or (iii) contributions in kind of their respective shares in House of HR or the Dutch management vehicle in exchange for ordinary shares and fixed-return preferred shares issued by Villa Dutch Holdco B.V. (“Holdco”), an indirect parent of the Issuer. See “—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure” below. The contributions (in cash or in kind) referred to in this paragraph are collectively referred herein as the “Shareholders’ Reinvestment.” Although the Sellers have given certain customary representations, warranties and indemnities as to, _inter alia, capacity, title and certain business matters in the Acquisition Agreement, the Issuer may not_ be able to enforce claims against the Sellers relating to breaches of these representations, warranties and indemnities. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Transactions—We may not be able to enforce _claims relating to a breach of the representations and warranties that the Sellers have provided to the Issuer under the Acquisition Agreement.”_

Subsubsection Title: Sources and Uses for the Acquisition and other Transactions
Subsubsection Text: The funding sources for the Acquisition, the repayment or refinancing of the Existing Notes, the Existing Facilities and certain other debt, and the payment of related fees and expenses and other costs related to the Transactions consisted of proceeds from the following sources: - equity contributions from Bain Capital and other co-investors in the form of subscription to ordinary shares and fixed-return preferred shares issued by Holdco (the “Pari passu Shares”) equaling approximately €596.8 million and contributed to the Issuer through intermediate holding companies (the “Shareholder Equity Contribution”); and (ii) the Shareholders’ Reinvestment and investment from new managers of approximately €488.2 million, which includes approximately €4.8 million of rollover equity in Topco from strategic minorities; and - drawings under Facility B in an aggregate amount of €1,020.0 million and (ii) drawings under the Second Lien Facility in an aggregate amount of €310.0 million; and - drawings under the Bridge Facility in the aggregate amount of €415.0 million, which will be partially refinanced using the proceeds from the offering of the Notes (see “—The Refinancing” below). ----- In addition, on the Acquisition Closing Date, we drew €114.1 million under the Delayed Draw Term Facility for general corporate purposes, including to finance or refinance amounts used in connection with certain acquisitions completed in 2022 and to finance the acquisition of ABMI which is expected to complete in December 2022, subject to the put option being exercised by the sellers, regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions. See “—Recent Developments—Acquisitions.” The notional sources and uses necessary to (i) consummate the Transactions, including the Acquisition but excluding the Offering, (ii) repay the Existing Notes and the Existing Facilities, (iii) finance or refinance amounts used in connection with certain acquisitions closed in 2022, (iv) finance the acquisition of ABMI which is expected to complete in December 2022, subject to the put option being exercised by the sellers, regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions and (v) pay fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing transactions are shown in the table below. Certain amounts presented have been estimated as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts based on several factors, including actual cash amounts available to the Issuer and/or House of HR, the actual purchase price from the ABMI acquisition (including the actual amount of indebtedness outstanding and actual amount of cash available to ABMI at completion of the ABMI acquisition) and any differences between estimated and actual fees and expenses. Any changes in these amounts may be funded through other cash sources available to the Group. This table should be read in conjunction with “Capitalization” and “Use of Proceeds.”

Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer entered into the Bridge Facility Agreement, which provides for the Bridge Facility in an aggregate principal amount of €415.0 million. The Issuer used the proceeds from the Bridge Facility, the Shareholder Equity Contribution and drawings under the Senior Term Facilities and the Second Lien Facility as described above under “—The Acquisition—Sources _and Uses for the Acquisition and other Transactions.”_ We estimate that the proceeds from the Offering will be €300.0 million. The proceeds from the Offering, together with cash on hand, will be used by the Issuer to partially repay the indebtedness incurred under the Bridge Facility, including accrued and unpaid interest thereon (the “Refinancing”), and to pay fees and expenses in connection with the Offering and the Refinancing. Following the Refinancing, €115.0 million in aggregate principal amount will remain outstanding under the Bridge Facility. The estimated sources and uses necessary to consummate the Refinancing are shown in the table below. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the amount of accrued and unpaid interest under the Bridge Facility on the date of repayment and differences in the actual amount of fees and expenses compared to our estimates. This table should be read in conjunction with “Capitalization” and “Use of Proceeds.”

See “ The Transactions.” (6) Represents (i) amounts used to fund the agreed consideration paid to the Sellers on the Acquisition Closing Date (excluding any future earn-out that may become payable under the Acquisition Agreement, any rolled leases and unfunded liabilities in the amount of €142.4 million, and including €4.8 million rollover equity from minorities) pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, (ii) the prepayment and cancellation, or redemption in full, of net amounts under the Existing Notes and the Existing Facilities, including early redemption premium and other fees, and (iii) the funding, financing, refinancing or refunding of amounts paid in connection with certain recently completed acquisitions of House of HR (see “ —Recent Developments—Acquisitions”). (7) Represents the estimated consideration payable for the acquisition of ABMI (including the repayment of certain existing debt of ABMI outstanding on the date of completion of the ABMI acquisition), as adjusted for our estimates of certain notified cash leakage items and certain other adjustments required under the purchase agreement. Actual consideration paid for the ABMI acquisition may vary due to various factors, including, among others, the date of consummation of the acquisition, the amount of cash available at ABMI, the amount of accrued interest and the amount of any prepayment premium on existing debt of ABMI as of the closing date and any adjustments to the cash consideration paid pursuant to the purchase agreement on the closing date.
