(2) Represents €300.0 million in aggregate principal amount of indebtedness under the Bridge Facility that will be repaid with the proceeds from the Offering, and excludes approximately €3.8 million of estimated accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, an assumed date of repayment. These fees and expenses have been estimated as of the date of this Offering Memorandum and are subject to change. Refinancing costs exclude (i) fees and expenses related to funding the Bridge Facility, (ii) accrued but unpaid interest on the Bridge Facility, (iii) additional expenses in connection with Transactions other than the Offering and the Refinancing that were paid, or will be paid, by the Issuer as described under “ —The Acquisition—Sources and _Uses for the Acquisition” and (iv) other post-closing costs or expenses._

In 2022, in addition to the acquisitions of Sociaal.nl, SOLCOM, TMI, Atrium, BE-Consult, Agathos, Vijverberg, Sira Consulting, Ambulance Zorg+, Bis People, StaffMe, LD Personalvermittlung, and FID Service Groep (which have been included in the September 30, 2022 consolidation perimeter), we completed the acquisition of Agium and Job Raccoon and signed a share purchase agreement to acquire ABMI, each as described in further detail below. The total enterprise value of the 15 closed acquisitions in 2022 is approximately €379 million, and their expected contribution to EBITDA is approximately €50 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, based on our due diligence in respect of these targets. In addition, the total enterprise value of the ABMI acquisition is approximately €60 ----- million and the expected additional EBITDA contribution from this target is approximately €8.2 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, based on our due diligence in respect of these targets. In addition, if certain conditions are met, up to approximately €10.5 million of additional consideration in the form of earn-outs could become payable in connection with the acquisitions of StaffMe, LD Personalvermittlung and Job Raccoon, and up to approximately €10.0 million in connection with the ABMI acquisition. In addition, under ABMI’s Put Option Agreement (as defined below) we may be required to make certain payments up to an amount of approximately €5.8 million if certain events occur, such as if we receive certain credits from the French authorities. We funded the acquisition of Agium and Job Raccoon with cash on balance sheet, and intend to fund the acquisition of ABMI with cash on balance sheet and cash resulting from capital increases. For more information see “Risk Factors—Risks relating to Our Business and Industry—We have _included certain historical financial information on entities that we acquired, which were not prepared by us or reviewed by our auditors and in some instances, which were not audited at all, or which were prepared on a different basis from our current IFRS financial statements, which may not be reflective of our past performance or representative of our future results” and “Risk Factors—Risks relating to Our Business and Industry—We may not realize the expected benefit of our past or future acquisitions or we may face unforeseen costs or liabilities.” Acquisitions Completed after September 30, 2022_ On October 7, 2022, we acquired Agium, a Dutch company specialized in deploying skilled professionals to support companies in their day-to-day finance and control processes and implementation of structure changes. Agium is expected to operate under our Redmore Powerhouse. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Agium generated revenue and EBITDA of €20.3 million and €2.9 million, respectively, and has an enterprise value of €19.5 million, based on our due diligence in respect of the target. On November 14, 2022, we acquired Job Raccoon in an asset deal to supplement our TIMEPARTNER Powerhouse. Job Raccoon is a German recruitment agency using an internet-based recruitment platform specializing in the recruitment of blue-collar workers. At completion, there was an upfront payment for this acquisition in an amount of €0.3 million. In addition, the purchase agreement includes an earn-out in an amount not to exceed €0.5 million in total, which may become payable if certain condition precedents are reached. _Future Acquisitions_ On October 25, 2022, House of HR NV and the shareholders of ABMI signed a put option agreement (the “Put Option Agreement”) to which a fully negotiated memorandum of understanding is attached, to acquire the French company ABMI, a consulting and engineering services group operating mainly in three engineering segments: (i) product design and industrialization, (ii) industrial processes and (iii) industrial facilities (e.g., nuclear and railway infrastructures). The put option may be exercised by the sellers upon completion of the information and consultation of the relevant employee representative bodies to which the offer has been submitted and we are awaiting for written confirmation of approval. The acquisition is expected to be completed in December 2022, subject to the put option being exercised by the sellers, regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions. Following the acquisition of ABMI, we expect to combine ABMI with Abylsen in order to create a new Powerhouse, ABY Engineering. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, ABMI generated revenue and EBITDA of approximately €57.0 million and approximately €8.2 million, respectively, and has an enterprise value of approximately €60.0 million, based on our due diligence in respect of the target. We also have a number of other potential targets in our pipeline for the remainder of 2022 and 2023. -----

Our Like-for-Like Revenue based on the business unit accounts for the month ended October 31, 2022 increased by 13.7% to €255.3 million from €224.5 million for the month ended October 31, 2021. Our Like-for-Like EBITDA for the month ended October 31, 2022 was €30.0 million, representing an increase of 6.4% from €28.2 million for the same period in 2021. Our Like-for-Like Revenue increased by 16.9% to €2,352.0 million for the ten months ended October 31, 2022, and our Like-for-Like EBITDA increased by 11.7% to €275.0 million for the ten months ended October 31, 2022. The increase in our Like-for-Like EBITDA and Like-for-Like Revenue was primarily due to labor scarcity and demand-supply dynamics in the labor market. Our Like-for-Like EBITDA margin decreased to 11.8% in October 2022 from 12.6% in October 2021, primarily due to investments in people and sales and marketing actions to increase inflow. _The preliminary results and estimates presented above have not been audited, are derived from internal management accounts, are the responsibility of management and are subject to our financial closing procedures. These procedures have not yet been completed. While we believe these preliminary results and estimates to be reasonable, our actual results could vary from these estimates and these differences could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information. This information may not be indicative of the remainder of the financial year ended December 31, 2022 or any future period. See “Forward-Looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ -----

_The following summary is qualified in its entirety by, and should be read in conjunction with, the more detailed information appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In this Offering Memorandum, (a) the Issuer means Villa Dutch Bidco B.V., excluding its subsidiaries; (b) House of HR or the Company means House of HR NV, and where the context requires, together with its subsidiaries and (c) “we,” “our,” “us” and “Group” mean, except where the context otherwise requires, (i) when referring to operations, businesses, market shares or historical financial results, House of HR and (ii) following the Acquisition, the Issuer and House of HR, collectively. Capitalized terms used but not defined in this summary are defined elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Investors should consider this Offering Memorandum in its entirety, including the information referred to under “Risk Factors,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the Financial Statements and the notes thereto, prior to making an investment in the Notes._

_The following chart shows a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure as of the Acquisition Closing Date adjusted to give effect to the Offering and other transactions described below. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections entitled “Description of the Notes,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Capitalization.” All entities shown below are 100% owned unless indicated. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors. _ (1) As of the Acquisition Closing Date (excluding the impact of the ABMI acquisition), Bain Capital indirectly held approximately 55.0% of the share capital of the Issuer, Naxicap Partners and Mrs. Vandendriessche indirectly held approximately 21.2% of the share capital of the Issuer and management (and other minority) shareholders indirectly held approximately 23.8% of the share capital of the Issuer (plus MIP Securities). See “ Principal Shareholders” and “ Certain Relationships and Related Party _Transactions—Management Incentive Plan.”_ (2) The Issuer is offering €300.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Notes. The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, and will rank _pari passu in right of payment with the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Facility. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed by the Original Guarantor. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles and, subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis on or prior to March 3, 2023 by the Post-Closing Guarantors. On the Issue Date, subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes and the Note Guarantees thereof will be secured by the Issue Date Collateral on a first-priority basis. On or prior to March 3, 2023, subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Post-Closing Collateral. The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. (3) In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer and Finco, among others, entered into the Bridge Facility Agreement, which provides for the Bridge Facility in an aggregate principal amount of €415.0 million. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Bridge ----- Facility has been drawn in full. Following the Refinancing, €115.0 million in aggregate principal amount will remain outstanding under the Bridge Facility. The Issuer is an original borrower and both the Issuer and Finco are original guarantors under the Bridge Facility. The Guarantors will guarantee the Bridge Facility on a pari passu basis with the Note Guarantees. The Collateral will also secure our obligations under the Bridge Facility on a first-ranking basis. See “ Description of Other Indebtedness—Bridge Facility _Agreement.”_ (4) The Issuer was incorporated as a holding company for the purpose of the Acquisition, has no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those acquired or incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer holds 100% of the share capital of House of HR. (5) The Issuer intends to use the proceeds from the Notes to (i) partially repay amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility, including accrued and unpaid interest thereon and (ii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Offering and the Refinancing, as further described under “ Use of Proceeds.” (6) In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer and Finco, among others, entered into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, which provides for facilities of €1,395.0 million in the form of (a) Facility B in an amount of €1,020.0 million; (ii) the Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of €250.0 million; and (iii) the Delayed Draw Term Facility in an amount of €125.0 million. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Facility B has been drawn in full, €114,084,006.91 of indebtedness has been drawn under the Delayed Draw Term Facility and there are no cash drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, €180.0 million of Facility B was pushed down into French Bidco. The Issuer and Finco are original borrowers under Facility B, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Delayed Draw Term Facility. The Guarantors will guarantee the Senior Secured Credit Facilities on a _pari passu basis with the Note Guarantees. French Bidco also acceded as an additional obligor under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, but will not provide a Note Guarantee or be an obligor under the Bridge Facility Agreement or the Second Lien Facility Agreement. The Collateral will also secure our obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Facility on a first-ranking basis. See “ Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Secured Credit Facilities _Agreement.”_ (7) In connection with the Transactions, the Issuer and Finco, among others, entered into the Second Lien Facility Agreement, which provides for the Second Lien Facility in an amount of €310.0 million. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Second Lien Facility has been drawn in full. The Issuer and Finco are original borrowers under the Second Lien Facility. The Guarantors will guarantee the Second Lien Facility on a junior ranking basis to the Note Guarantees. The Collateral will also secure our obligations under the Second Lien Facility on a second-ranking basis. See “ Description of Other Indebtedness—Second Lien _Facility Agreement.”_ (8) On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Original Guarantor. On or prior to March 3, 2023, subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior secured basis. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to certain limitations. See “ Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note _Guarantees and the Security Interests.” As of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, the expected Post-Closing_ Guarantors represented 63.8% of Like-for-Like Revenues of House of HR, 38.0% of the consolidated assets (excluding intercompany eliminations) of House of HR and 89.1% of Like-for-Like EBITDA of House of HR. We intend to merge The House of Pledge NV, the direct subsidiary of House of HR NV, into House of HR NV in the near future. -----

See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.” Ranking of the Notes ..............................** The Notes will, upon issuance: - be senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth under “Description _of the Notes—Security”;_ - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Facility; ----- - rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be guaranteed by the Guarantors on a senior secured basis, as described below under “—Note Guarantees”; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of the Issuer or of its subsidiaries that are secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such obligation or indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Issuer (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Notes, including French Bidco. Note Guarantees ....................................** The Notes are expected to be guaranteed on a senior basis by (i) on the Issue Date, the Original Guarantor and (ii) on or prior to March 3, 2023, subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles and to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the PostClosing Guarantors. As of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, the expected Post-Closing Guarantors represented 63.8% of Like-for-Like Revenues of House of HR, 38.0% of the consolidated assets (excluding intercompany eliminations) of House of HR and 89.1% of Likefor-Like EBITDA of House of HR. Each Note Guarantee will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and certain contractual and legal limitations. See “Description _of_ _Other_ _Indebtedness— _Intercreditor_ _Agreement”_ _and_ _“Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests.” By virtue_ of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Note Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Note Guarantee. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our_ ----- _Structure—Corporate_ _benefit,_ _financial assistance laws, capital maintenance and other limitations on the Note Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Collateral.” In addition, the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Brief Description of the Notes and the Note Guarantees” and_ “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ Ranking of the Note Guarantees .............** Each Note Guarantee will: - be a senior obligation of the relevant Guarantor, secured as set forth under “Description of the Notes—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of such Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to its Note Guarantee, including such Guarantor’s obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Facility; - rank senior in right of payment to all of such Guarantor’s future debt that is subordinated in right of payment to its Note Guarantee; - rank effectively senior to any existing and future unsecured debt of such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Note Guarantees; - rank effectively senior to any existing and future debt of such Guarantor secured on a second-ranking basis by property or assets that secure the Note Guarantee on a first-ranking basis; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future debt of that Guarantor (including obligations to trade creditors) that is secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations or indebtedness; and ----- - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future debt of such Guarantor’s subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Notes. Collateral ..............................................** Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles and subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on a first-ranking basis: - on the Issue Date, by: (a) a Dutch law governed limited recourse share pledge over the shares in the Issuer owned by Midco; (b) a Dutch law governed limited recourse security interest agreement over structural intercompany receivables owed by the Issuer to Midco; (c) a Dutch law governed share pledge over the shares in the Original Guarantor owned by the Issuer; (d) a Dutch law governed security interest agreement over material, long-term, documented, structural intercompany receivables owed by the Original Guarantor to the Issuer; (e) a Dutch law governed bank account pledge over the Issuer’s material bank accounts in the Netherlands; (f) a French law governed pledge over shares in French Bidco owned by the Issuer; (g) a Belgian law governed share pledge over the shares in House of HR owned by the Issuer; and (h) a Dutch law governed security interest agreement over structural intercompany receivables owed by House of HR to the Original Guarantor ((a) through (h) together, the “Issue Date Collateral”); - on or prior to March 3, 2023, by: (a) share pledges granted by wholly owned Material Subsidiaries incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction over the shares held in each Material Subsidiary ----- incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction; and (b) in respect of a Post-Closing Guarantor (if any) (i) incorporated in England and Wales, floating security over substantially all assets located in its jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to customary “excluded assets,” including real estate, and other customary exclusions, materiality thresholds and exceptions); and (ii) incorporated in the United States, security over substantially all assets located in its jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to customary “excluded asset,” including real estate, and other customary exclusions, materiality thresholds and exceptions), in each case, where to do so would not have a material adverse effect on their ability to conduct their business and operations, as determined by each such Post-Closing Guarantor in its sole and absolute discretion ((a) and (b) together, the “Post-Closing Collateral,” and together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Collateral will also secure the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Bridge Facility on a first-priority basis and the Second Lien Facility on a second-priority basis. The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. In addition, the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. Subject to the provisions of Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description of the Notes—Security” and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see “Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Structure.”_ Use of Proceeds ......................................** The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes will be used to partially repay amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility, including accrued and unpaid interest thereon, and to pay the costs, fees and ----- expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” Additional Amounts ...............................** Any payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes or Note Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes unless required by law. If such withholding or deduction is required by law in any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Withholding _Taxes”), the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as_ applicable, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amounts received by the Holder (as defined in “Description of the Notes— _Certain Definitions”) of the Notes after the_ withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the _Notes—Withholding Taxes.”_ Optional Redemption .............................** The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes on or after         , 2025, at the redemption prices set forth under “Description of the Notes— _Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid_ interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Prior to        , 2025, the Issuer may on any one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes issued under the Indenture (including any additional Notes), using the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to        % of the principal amount of Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the original principal amount of Notes originally issued under the Indenture (excluding any additional Notes) remains outstanding after each such redemption. Prior to       , 2025, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the original principal amount of Notes (including any additional Notes of the same series) in each calendar year, commencing on the Issue Date, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, up to, but excluding, the redemption date. See “Description of the Notes— _Optional Redemption.”_ ----- In addition, prior to       , 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes plus the “makewhole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Optional Redemption for tax reasons ......** In the event of certain changes in law affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, upon giving notice, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for _Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control .................................** Upon the occurrence of certain change of control triggering events, the Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of the purchase. A change of control triggering event, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” Certain Tender Offers............................** In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the applicable series of Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description _of the Notes—Optional _Redemption.”_ Certain Covenants .................................** The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuer and (as applicable) its subsidiaries to: ----- - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase our capital stock; - make certain restricted payments; - make certain investments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of their subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the Issuer; - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain asset sales; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes— _Certain Covenants.” Certain of the covenants_ and events of default will be suspended if and for as long as, and the security interests in respect of the Collateral will be released if, we achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description of the _Notes—Certain_ _Covenants—Suspension_ _of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_ U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations .** For a discussion of certain U.S. federal income tax considerations of an investment in the Notes, see “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain _U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.” You_ should consult your own tax advisor to determine the U.S. federal, state, local and other tax consequences of an investment in the Notes. Original Issue Discount ..........................** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, holders subject to U.S. federal income tax generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis) for U.S. federal income tax purposes in advance of the receipt of cash payments to which such OID is attributable and ----- regardless of the holder’s regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain _U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations— Original Issue Discount.”_ Transfer Restrictions .............................** The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” Holders of the Notes will not have the benefit of any exchange or registration rights. No Prior Market ....................................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is no market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so, and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that an active trading market for the Notes will develop or be maintained. Listing...................................................** Application will be made to list the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such admission to trading in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended. Risk Factors ..........................................** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes. Governing Law ......................................** The Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Indenture will be governed by New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement, the Facilities and the Bridge Facility are governed by English law. Each Transaction Security Document is, or will be, governed by applicable local laws. Trustee..................................................** U.S. Bank Trustees Limited. Security Agent .......................................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Paying Agent .........................................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. ----- Transfer Agent ......................................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Registrar ...............................................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Listing Agent.........................................** Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited. -----

Subsection Title: Summary Consolidated Other Financial and Pro Forma Information
Subsubsection Title: Organic Growth, Like-for-Like and Pro Forma Historical Information of the Company
Subsubsection Text: We present Organic Growth in order to demonstrate our period-on-period revenue growth on an organic basis excluding the impact of acquisitions between one financial period and the comparable prior period by assuming no acquisitions have occurred after the start-date of the prior comparative period as noted in the footnotes below. We present Like-for-Like Revenue and Like-for-Like EBITDA in order to demonstrate our revenue and EBITDA growth over a number of periods by adjusting each period to reflect all of the acquisitions that have occurred as of a particular date as though such acquisitions had occurred on the first date of the earliest comparative period. Like-for-Like Revenue and Like-for-Like EBITDA presented in the below tables are adjusted to reflect our consolidated perimeter including all the acquisitions that had occurred as of September 30, 2022, as if such perimeter had been in place from January 1, 2019. We also present Like-for-Like figures using different acquisition perimeters elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” for further information. _Pro Forma_ Management Adjusted Revenue and _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA are adjusted to reflect the impact of acquisitions that occurred during that period as if they had occurred on the first date of such period as described in footnotes 10 and 12(e) below. As a result, for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Like-for-Like Revenue and Like-for-Like EBITDA based on our consolidated perimeter as of September 30, 2022 are, respectively, the same figures as Pro _Forma Management Adjusted Revenue and Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA. Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: (a) The consolidated income statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 has been restated in our 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements to consider the impact of the disposal of GRITT Projects. See “ Presentation of Financial and Other _Information.”_ (b) Depreciation and amortization is mainly composed of amortization charges on property, plant and equipment and intangible assets (including brand name and customer relationship), as well as impairment on goodwill. (c) Relates to management services provided to GRITT Projects which given its disposal, is now considered a third party. (d) For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, non-recurring items of €12.9 million mainly relate to (i) external advisory fees relating to completed and aborted acquisitions amounting to €5.3 million, (ii) the reversal of an accrual release for accident insurance in TIMEPARTNER amounting to €(8.6) million, (iii) costs related to the partial merger between Zaquensis and TIMEPARTNER amounting to €1.4 million, (iv) costs related to start up initiatives for an amount of €2.6 million, (v) costs related to management reorganization / restructuring costs of €3.0 million, (vi) costs related to the exit of Naxicap as main shareholder and the entry of Bain as new shareholder for an amount of €3.0 million, (vii) advisory fees on IT transformation projects and other external IT advisory fees of €1.2 million, (viii) rebranding costs of certain Powerhouses for an amount of €1.1 million, (ix) legal fees related to disputes mainly with former managers for an amount of €1.0 million, and (x) other costs, adjustments and expenses for one-off events which in the aggregate amounted to €3.0 million. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, non-recurring items of €15.0 million mainly relate to (i) exit process of €3.0 million, (ii) fees relating to acquisitions of €4.5 million, (iii) costs related to management reorganization of €2.4 million, (iv) rebranding costs of certain Powerhouses for an amount of €1.1 million, (v) costs related to the NOWJOBS startups in the Netherlands, France and Germany of €1.2 million, (vi) advisory fees on IT reorganization of €0.9 million, (vii) costs related to the implementation of Covid-19 protection measures for employees amounting to €0.2 million, (viii) costs related to promotional items such as gifts and events for the 20 years existence of Covebo and Profource respectively amounting to €0.5 million, (ix) cost related to capital increase amounting to €0.1 million, (x) costs related to our long-term incentive plan amounting to €0.1 million, (xi) costs related to the startups of Pharmacos R&D, Sixie and Vialegis Netherlands of €0.2 million, and (xii) litigation fees of €0.6 million. For the year ended December 31, 2021, non-recurring items of €15.1 million mainly relate to (i) external advisory fees relating to completed and aborted acquisitions amounting to €11.2 million, (ii) the reversal of an accrual release for accident insurance in TIMEPARTNER in 2021 amounting to €(8.6) million, (iii) costs related to the partial merger between Zaquensis and TIMEPARTNER amounting to €3.1 million, (iv) a reversal of historical withholding tax reduction for an amount of €1.5 million, (v) costs related to start up initiatives of €1.4 million, mainly relating to the expansion of NOWJOBS in the Netherlands and France, (vi) management reorganization / restructuring costs of €1.3 million, (vii) legal fees mainly for disputes with former managers amounting to €1.2 million, (viii) external advisor fees incurred in connection with the conversion to IFRS of Cohedron’s financial statements amounting to €0.7 million, (ix) advisory fees on IT transformation projects amounting to €0.7 million, (x) costs related to the implementation of Covid-19 protection measures for employees amounting to €0.1 million, (xi) costs related to promotional items such as gifts and events for the 20 years and 15 years existence of Covebo and Redmore respectively amounting to €0.5 million, (xii) fees paid to BCG for market analysis done amounting to €0.5 million, (xiii) a VAT fine relating to 2018 and 2019 amounting to €0.3 million, (xiv) costs related to rebranding of Continu and Cohedron amounting to €0.3 million, (xv) advisory fees in light of events such as leaving shareholders amounting to €0.2 million, and (xvi) other costs and expenses for one-off events which in the aggregate amounted to €0.8 million. For the year ended December 31, 2020, non-recurring items of €17.3 million mainly relate to (i) external advisory fees relating to completed and aborted acquisitions as well as the disinvestment of GRITT Projects amounting to €1.0 million, (ii) costs related to promotional items such as gifts and events for the 25 year anniversary of the founding of Accent amounting to €1.0 million, (iii) ----- costs related to start up initiatives of €2.0 million, mainly relating to the expansion of NOWJOBS in the Netherlands and Gighouse, (iv) management reorganization / restructuring costs of €4.7 million, (v) costs related to the implementation of Covid-19 protection measures for employees amounting to €4.6 million, (vi) income related to the earn-out adjustment of a subsidiary from Continu for an amount of €(2.2) million, (vii) costs related to the issuance of our Existing Senior Secured Notes and Existing Senior Subordinated Notes amounting to €0.4 million, (viii) fees to BCG for market analysis done amounting to €0.9 million and (ix) other costs and expenses for one-off events which in the aggregate amounted to €4.9 million. For the year ended December 31, 2019, non-recurring items of €32.9 million mainly relate to (i) external advisor fees relating to completed and aborted acquisitions amounting to €2.5 million, (ii) costs related to start up initiatives of €1.4 million, (iii) management reorganization / restructuring costs of €5.0 million, (iv) external advisor fees incurred in connection with the implementation of IFRS 16 amounting to €0.7 million, (v) costs related to the issuance of our Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and refinancing expenses for €12.7 million, (vi) the removal of the non-cash LTIP expense recorded in the Continu Professionals management accounts for €0.5 million, (vii) social security taxes related to the granting of the stock option plan at Abylsen (AGADP) amounting to €1.5 million, (viii) provisions related to a change in legislation in the Netherlands (mainly transition fees) amounting to €0.9 million, (ix) costs resulting from a fiscal inspection and a social audit amounting to €0.7 million, (x) impairment of GRITT Projects (cash pooling) amounting to €3.7 million and (xi) other costs and expenses for one-off events which in the aggregate amounted to €3.3 million. Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: _The Issuer was formed for the purposes of facilitating the Transactions. The Issuer does not have any business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. We do not present in this Offering Memorandum any financial information or financial statements of the Issuer for the periods presented, other than certain limited financial data presented on an as adjusted basis to reflect the Transactions and the Offering. The historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of House of HR. We have extracted or derived (i) the consolidated historical financial information of House of HR as of and for the financial years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021 from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and (ii) the consolidated historical financial information of House of HR as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and 2022 from the Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements, in each case, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The financial information for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 presented below was derived by adding House of HR’s consolidated financial information for the year ended December 31, 2021 to its consolidated financial information for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and subtracting its consolidated financial information for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. The summary unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 is not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations or our financial condition for any full year period or at any future date. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Financial Information Presented for the Twelve Months ended September 30, 2022.” The information presented below under the caption “Key Performance Indicators” has not been extracted or derived from the Financial Statements, but from our management’s accounts and/or accounting records. We have also presented below unaudited as adjusted data of the Issuer, which gives effect to the Transactions, including the Acquisition, the Offering, the Refinancing, and the drawings under the Facilities and the Bridge Facility, as set forth in “—The Transactions,” as if the Transactions had occurred on (i) October 1, 2021, for the purposes of as adjusted income statement items and (ii) September 30, 2022 for the purposes of as adjusted balance sheet items. See “Capitalization.” The as adjusted financial information of the Issuer as of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not represent what our indebtedness or interest expense would have been had the Transactions occurred on September 30, 2022, or October 1, 2021, respectively, nor does it purport to project our indebtedness or interest expense at any future date or for any future period. The as adjusted financial information of the Issuer as of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS, the requirements of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the adjustments nor the resulting as adjusted financial information as of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, have been audited, verified or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. The summary consolidated financial and other information below includes certain non-IFRS measures that we use to evaluate our economic and financial performance, including Like-for-Like Revenue, Like-for-Like EBITDA, Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. These measures are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered a substitute for, or superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those calculated using financial measures that are prepared in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information— Non-IFRS Financial Measures” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We have included certain historical financial information on entities that we acquired, which were not prepared by us or reviewed by our auditors and in some instances, which were not audited at all, or which were prepared on a different basis from our current IFRS financial statements, which may not be reflective of our past performance or representative of our future results.” You should read the information set forth below in conjunction with the sections “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Our historical results do not necessarily indicate results that may be expected for any future period._ -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations could be materially adversely affected by volatile or uncertain economic conditions.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our staffing services is sensitive to changes in the level of economic activity and economic conditions in the countries, regions and sectors in which we operate. A global economic downturn, such as the one resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic, which impacts a country or region in which we operate may adversely affect our staffing services in that country or region, as fewer clients may seek our job candidates for assignments. In addition, the outbreak of the war in Ukraine in February 2022, global supply chain disruptions and other geopolitical conflicts have caused an immediate impact on global economic conditions, which has led to increased inflationary pressure in 2022, including causing increases in the price for goods and services, which has resulted and may continue to result in shortages in materials and services. Such shortages have resulted and may continue to result in inflationary cost increases for labor, fuel, materials and services, and could continue to cause costs to increase. Although we do not have direct economic activities in Russia and Ukraine and currently the conflict has not had any material impact on our overall sales and EBITDA, it is difficult to predict the scope and extent of any potential impact of the increasing tensions and other geopolitical conflicts could have on our operations, especially given we source candidates from Eastern Europe. Moreover, gas and other raw materials in relation to supply shortages are significantly impacting many industries and sectors, which could result in our clients reconsidering their recruitment efforts of domestic and foreign talents, which may, in turn, impact our results of operations. Furthermore, continuing increases in inflation could impact the overall demand for and costs of our services and the margins we are able to realize on our services, all of which could have an adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows. Inflation may also result in higher interest rates, which in turn would result in higher interests we incur on our borrowings. While the global economy has recovered from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2021, there remains considerable uncertainty over the long-term effects of the above factors and the expansionary monetary and fiscal policies which had been adopted by the central banks and financial authorities of some of the world’s leading economies in the past decade. We cannot predict the long-term effects such factors may have on the global political and economic conditions, including whether they may result in a severe or prolonged global economic recession. Moreover, our revenue and results of operations are dependent on a limited number of countries in Europe and we have material operations in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France. For the year ended December 31, 2021, these countries accounted for 27.8%, 41.9%, 22.2% and 8.1%, respectively, of our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue and as a result, we are particularly exposed to risks arising from economic conditions in these countries. For example, as the United Kingdom (“U.K.”) represents a key export market for several of the countries in which we operate, ----- particularly Belgium and the Netherlands, adverse trade terms between the U.K. and the countries in which we operate following the entry into force of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement on May 1, 2021 could have an adverse effect on the economies of these countries, which could by extension adversely affect demand for our services or our business. Moreover, there is a possibility that other Member States, including the countries where we source our job candidates, could also withdraw from the EU. If this materializes, it could pose further uncertainties on the application of laws and the economies within the EU and the countries involved, including limitation on the free movement of people, which could have a material adverse impact on our business. In addition, a downturn in the endmarkets in which we target clients could have a negative impact on the demand for our services or the prices clients are willing to pay for our services. Moreover, an economic downturn may impact us differently than it has in the past. Among our two business segments, specialized talent solutions has historically been more sensitive to economic fluctuations due to the temporary and flexible staffing element in this segment, which has led to decreases in demand for such services in connection with economic downturns, including that experienced in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic, even if it has historically recovered faster compared to the engineering and consulting segment. Actions that we take to decrease our expenses during an economic downturn may not prevent a loss in operating profit and could have a longer term impact on our operations. When demand drops or remains low, we attempt to reduce the amount of our sales and marketing expenses and job candidates in order to reduce our cost of services and operating expenses but such reductions may not occur as quickly as, or be sufficient to offset the decrease in our revenue. If periods of decline are prolonged and result in a significant decrease in the size of our in-house employees or job candidates, we may not be able to reduce our expenses without negatively impacting the long-term potential of our business units, branches and brands. Furthermore, our decentralized structure can lead to increased costs, which in times of economic downturn could lead to decreased profitability. Any of the foregoing risks, if they were to occur, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The Covid-19 pandemic, including the resulting global economic uncertainty and the related lockdown measures, in particular its effects in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France where we have material operations, or other epidemics or pandemics, have had in the past, and could have in the future, a significant adverse impact on demand for our staffing services, our revenue, operations and workforce.
Subsubsection Text: The Covid-19 pandemic, including the emergence of variants such as Delta and Omicron and related sub-variants, and the rapidly evolving reactions of authorities, including those in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France, to contain the spread and address the impact of Covid-19 have had significant direct and indirect effects on businesses and commerce generally, including disruptions to supply chain, workforce, transactional activity, facility operation and production. While restrictions on the conduct of business in many jurisdictions, including the closure of workplaces determined to be non-essential, have eased or been lifted, there remain certain restrictions on the international, national and local movement of people and goods, which continue to disrupt many of our clients’ business operations and their recruitment needs. The extent and scope of such restrictions continue to be highly uncertain and subject to change, and stricter measures could potentially be put in place in the future. A prolonged continuance of this public health crisis could therefore have a material adverse effect, including materially increased volatility in financial markets and significant worsening of the global, European, Belgian, Dutch, German and French macroeconomic outlooks. The spread of Covid-19 has led us to modify certain of our operational practices, and we may take further actions required by authorities or that we determine are in the best interests of our in-house employees, job candidates and other stakeholders. We implemented a work-from-home policy that has been used by most of our in-house employees. For the Group’s in-house employees who cannot work remotely, we have implemented additional protective procedures, including equipping employees with ----- sanitizing equipment (such as disinfectants and hand sanitizers), implementing social distancing, staggering employees working hours as required to comply with governmental restrictions, and increasing the frequency of cleaning in the Group’s facilities, but these measures may not prevent the exposure of our in-house employees to Covid-19. For job candidates on assignment with a client, many of the markets in which we operate still place certain responsibilities on us for overseeing certain health and safety obligations for our job candidates. See “Regulation.” As a result, for certain job candidates who have been placed in client workplaces where exposure to Covid-19 is possible, we may be subject to risk of liability should such employees allege their workplaces failed to adequately mitigate the risk of exposure to Covid-19. Since we also place job candidates and certain employees with our clients, it is also possible that one of our job candidates or employees with Covid-19 could then infect other employees at the clients’ premises, which could lead to sickness, shutdowns or late deliveries at a client’s business. Clients may hold us liable should we not have taken the required precautionary measures with such job candidates or employees and it could also cause reputational harm to us should any such events occur. In addition, in order to facilitate remote working arrangements, some of our job candidates are accessing client workspaces from their personal devices through cloud-based systems, which could increase cybersecurity risks to our clients for which they may hold us liable. The intersection of public health, workplace safety, employer liability and privacy laws is complex, and we cannot predict how regulatory or liability regimes may evolve in the future as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. Although we have seen a full recovery of our financial performance in 2021 and the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we cannot predict the impact that any future developments relating to the Covid19 pandemic may have on the demand for our staffing services and on our business, results of operations and financial position. These developments may include, but are not limited to, the duration and spread of Covid-19, its severity, emergence of new variants and further actions taken to contain the virus or treat its impact, including the rate of deployment of vaccines. A number of measures taken by governments in the early stage of the Covid-19 pandemic intended to mitigate the spread of Covid-19 caused dramatic disruptions to our clients businesses and impacted the demands for our staffing services in 2020, in particular in the non-food retail, hotel, restaurant and cafe, aerospace, travel and tourism and automobile industries. Future waves of Covid-19 may result in national or local governments reviving such severe countermeasures. For example, in the spring of 2020 different degrees of lockdowns were introduced in each of our primary geographic markets which had an immediate impact on demand for our staffing services. Softer lockdowns were introduced again in the autumn of 2020 which also led to a decrease in job candidates at work after we had experienced a gradual increase in the number of job candidates at work following the initial lockdown in the spring of 2020. Governmental countermeasures eased again in early 2021, which led to the gradual normalization of economic activities in our primary geographic markets, recovering to pre-Covid-19 levels. This trend was carried into 2022 despite the outbreak of the new strain of Covid-19, Omicron, in the last weeks of 2021 and at the beginning of 2022. Governments could, however, impose similar or more stringent restrictions again in the future as they deem necessary, and this could lead to economic distress and reduced demand for our staffing services, which could affect our results of operations. Potential future lockdown measures, such as shutting down production facilities and offices or restricting free movement of transportation and distribution, closing of restaurant and bar facilities, closing or reducing hospitality at events, amongst others, could disrupt our client’s businesses or ours more significantly in the future than what has been experienced to date, leading them to curtail their reliance on us. Throughout the Covid-19 pandemic, there were a number of government measures introduced, including in our primary markets of Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France, which positively contributed to the Group’s ability to manage cash flows during the period and manage the costs associated with our in-house employees and job candidates. For example, we utilized temporary unemployment measures introduced that have allowed us to retain certain in-house employees and job candidates without bearing the full expense of their wages and salaries and have utilized certain postponement of VAT or other tax and benefit payments. A number of these measures, however, ended during the course of 2021, and the remaining measures expired as of July 2022. While this has, to date, only resulted in a minor impact on our costs, we could experience additional costs and liabilities and ----- may also find it more difficult to retain in-house employees and job candidates if demand for our staffing services reduces or is variable due to a resurgence of Covid-19 in the markets in which we operate, without the introduction of additional government measures (or which there is no guarantee any will be introduced). If any of the foregoing were to occur, there could be a material adverse effect on the Group’s business, results of operations, financial condition or prospects and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Inflation, changes in regulation and other macroeconomic factors may lead to increase in our operating costs that we may not always be able to pass on to our customers, which could adversely affect our profitability.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of our contracts with clients may provide for fixed pricing rates for the services to be provided, a cap on pricing or other terms which we negotiate based on our assumptions regarding our clients’ required scope of services, costs that will be incurred to fulfill the scope and operational efficiencies we expect to achieve and other estimates. As a result, while we seek to pass on our costs to our clients, this may not be feasible in all situations. These assumptions and estimates may prove to be inaccurate, particularly if operating costs continue to rise in the current inflationary environment, as well as due to other increases in our costs driven by changes in regulation, increased competition in the labor market, changes to economic conditions, other costs beyond our control or other developments, and as a result, our margins under these contracts may be materially adversely affected. In particular, we may be unable to pass on increases in costs due to a change in regulation governing minimum wage requirements, payments required to be made under social security and other benefits which could affect our profitability. For the year ended December 31, 2021, personnel expenses and wage taxes, in aggregate, constituted 85.1% of our cost of services. Although we seek to structure our arrangements with third parties on a back-to-back basis with the related customer arrangements, for example, by entering into agreements with job candidates with durations and termination rights that are coterminous with the duration of our contracts with the relevant clients, there may be instances where we are not able to offset or transfer such costs to our clients. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The employment services sector is highly competitive and we may be unable to compete successfully in our markets.
Subsubsection Text: Our industry is highly competitive. This is driven by a variety of factors, including low barriers to entry especially in localized markets, the availability of qualified job candidates, the quality and speed of customer service, and brand loyalty. We compete in a number of our markets with large, consolidated international staffing services providers and smaller, more localized companies. Many of our competitors are global full-service and specialized employment services providers with substantial marketing and financial resources, and may be better positioned in certain markets. For example, our Accent Powerhouse which operates in the specialized talent solutions segment in Belgium, faces competition from global service providers, each of which compete mainly on volume-driven clients. We expect that we will continue to experience pressure on price from competitors and clients. We may also face increased competition from smaller, more localized staffing solutions providers. Such firms would most likely cater to a smaller set of clients and as a result, may be able to provide more time and attention to their clients. In particular, SME and ISEs may prefer to work with more localized firms. Moreover, there is a risk that we may be unable to compete effectively on price with such firms as their cost base may be lower, including regarding technological capabilities. In addition, new and existing competitors may be aided by technology that enables them to compete with our staffing services. The widespread adoption of sophisticated, automated job description and candidate screening tools could make many traditional functions of staffing companies obsolete. Specifically, the increased use of the internet may continue to attract technology-oriented companies to ----- the staffing industry. Free social networking sites such as LinkedIn and Facebook and online job boards such as Google for Jobs are also becoming a common way for recruiters and employees to connect without the assistance of a staffing company. We believe that our future success will depend largely upon our ability to anticipate and keep pace with these and other technological and digital developments and advances. Current or future competitors could develop alternative capabilities and technologies that are more effective, efficient, easier to use or more economical than our services. In addition, with continuing development and increased availability of information technology, the end-markets in which we compete may attract new competitors. If our capabilities and technologies do not keep up with advances, become obsolete or uncompetitive, this may lead to increased costs or not being able to find and match the right job candidates for clients, which may lead to loss of revenues and market share. We may face competition from our clients themselves as they insource or make alternative arrangements for some of the services we provide. SMEs and ISEs have historically accounted for a substantial portion of our sales. As such clients grow, they may increasingly take advantage of low-cost alternatives, including developing and using their own in-house resources rather than engaging a third party to support them in their staffing needs. Moreover, our clients, particularly our large corporate clients, may increasingly look for off-shore or near-shore labor markets as alternative sources for staffing as opposed to our staffing services, and such trend could accelerate as a result of the increase in remote working as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. As a result, there is a risk that we may not be able to maintain our existing client engagements and if we are not able to maintain or replace such clients, this could negatively impact our business. Due to competition, we may experience reduced margins on our services, loss of market share, and loss of clients. Our inability to compete effectively with current or future competitors as a result of any of the foregoing and other factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our continued success depends upon our ability to attract and retain qualified job candidates and in-house employees.
Subsubsection Text: Our business depends on our ability to attract and retain qualified job candidates who possess the skills and experience necessary to meet the requirements of our clients, particularly for the specialized positions that we place under both our engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions segments. Given the current global labor shortage in our primary markets, we may experience an increasingly tight labor market with low levels of unemployment, and there is a risk that we may be unable to meet our clients’ requirements in identifying an adequate number of job candidates. We must continually evaluate and upgrade our base of available qualified job candidates to keep pace with changing client needs and emerging technologies. Competition for individuals with proven specialty skills is often intense, and we expect demand for such individuals could make it difficult to retain such job candidates. Qualified job candidates may not be available to us in sufficient numbers or on terms of employment acceptable to us. In addition, we may lose existing job candidates to clients, if such clients decide to permanently retain our job candidates sent on temporary assignment, including as a result of legislative or regulatory reform. Additionally, our clients may look to us for assistance in identifying and integrating into their organizations job candidates from diverse backgrounds, and who may represent different generations, geographical regions and skill sets. These needs may change due to business requirements, or in response to geopolitical and societal trends. There is a risk that we may not be able to identify job candidates with the required attributes, including as a result of expanding restrictions on immigration or that our training programs may not succeed in developing effective or adequate skills to meet the demand where needed. We may also face difficulties in recruiting job candidates through our international recruitment network if such job candidates are not incentivized to relocate and seek assignments with clients in the markets in which we operate as a result of increasing wages in their home countries. In addition, the Covid-19 pandemic has led many job candidates to reevaluate their careers, work conditions and long-term professional goals, resulting in an increased rate of employees switching jobs and transitioning between different job modes. While this has led employers to focus more intensely than ever on employee retention and job mobility, which has created substantial opportunities for us to offer our services, there is no guarantee that we will be able to ----- capitalize on this trend. Employers and employees have also grown to be versatile during the Covid-19 pandemic and companies could seek to leverage flexible working arrangements to utilize their current employees to fill their staffing needs instead of seeking our services. Further, we are also dependent on our in-house employees to establish and maintain client relationships, to recruit job candidates, to run our day-to-day operations and to identify internal growth and external acquisition opportunities. A number of our Powerhouses rely on in-house employees who are specialists in the end-markets of the clients we serve with a deep understanding of the job requirements of our clients. Such qualified in-house employees may not continue to be available to us in sufficient numbers or on terms or in geographic locations which are economically and strategically advantageous to us. Moreover, we may be unable to continue to find, develop or retain suitable in-house employees who meet our performance standards. If we fail to recruit, train or retain qualified job candidates who meet the needs of our clients or in-house employees who meet our performance standards, our reputation, business and financial results could be materially adversely affected. Similarly, increases in compensation or in benefits resulting from competition for such qualified job candidates or in-house employees may have a material adverse effect on our current business, future prospects, financial condition and results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations or ability to grow could be materially negatively affected if we cannot successfully keep pace with technological changes in the development and implementation of our services and solutions, including that of our digital platform.
Subsubsection Text: We believe our success depends on our ability to keep pace with technological changes in the development and implementation of our services and solutions. For example, rapid changes in the use of artificial intelligence and robotics are having a significant impact on some of the industries we serve, and could have significant and unforeseen consequences for the staffing industry and for our business. There is a risk that these, or other developments, could result in significant disruption to our business model, and that we will be unprepared to compete effectively. Additionally, our business is reliant on a variety of technologies, including those which support applicant on-boarding and tracking systems, order management, billing, payroll and client data analytics. There is a risk we will not sufficiently invest in technology or industry developments, or evolve our business with the right strategic investments, or at sufficient speed and scale, to adapt to changes in our marketplace. Similarly, from time to time we make strategic commitments to invest in or develop particular technologies to recruit, manage or analyze our workforce or support our business. In particular, we have developed several digital staffing solutions in recent years, and we intend to continue to invest in our digital initiatives. There is a risk that our digital initiatives will be unsuccessful as we may be unable to cater these digital solutions to the needs of employers or candidates, develop the technical aspects of these digital solutions quickly enough to keep pace with market trends or implement them effectively. Furthermore, we operate on a best practices basis, meaning that we implement digital initiatives more broadly among our Group once they have been tested by a Powerhouse, which may lead to delayed implementation of, and as a result, delayed benefit from, such initiatives. These and similar risks could have a negative effect on the appeal of our services and solutions, or our ability to develop and maintain a competitive advantage in the marketplace and, as a result, on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on certain key personnel, the loss of whom could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We depend on our senior management at the Group level, as well as key personnel at each operating company, for the implementation of our business strategy and day-to-day operations. Our senior management’s and key personnel’s knowledge of the market, our business, our clients and our Group ----- represents a key strength of our business model, and we believe that our experience and human capital serve as barriers to entry to potential competitors. Accordingly, we face risks relating to our ability to continue to attract, retain and incentivize senior management and other key personnel in our company. If any senior management or key personnel leave, it could take time to find appropriately qualified individuals to replace them especially considering the specialized nature of our business and the current tight labor market. If we are unable to retain key members of our senior management team in particular and cannot hire new qualified personnel in a timely manner, this could negatively impact the management of our Powerhouses and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Maintaining and protecting our reputation and the image of our brands is important to our ability to attract and retain clients and job candidates and any harm to our reputation and brands could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on our reputation, as well as positive recognition of the brands used by our Powerhouses, among other factors, to attract and retain clients. We believe that maintaining, protecting and enhancing our brand will depend largely on our ability to continue to provide high-quality, useful and innovative services to our clients and our ability to successfully match job candidates with our clients’ needs. If clients or job candidates do not perceive our staffing services to be of high quality, our reputation could be harmed and the value of our brands could diminish, thereby decreasing the attractiveness of our staffing services to existing and prospective clients as well as job candidates. We also believe that our reputation and brands may be harmed if we fail to maintain a consistently high level of customer service. Our reputation and brand could also be negatively affected by the actions of clients or job candidates that are inappropriate or illegal, regardless of whether such actions relate to services we provide to such clients or arise while a job candidate is on assignment with a client if we are publicly associated with such actions. In addition, clients or job candidates may become dissatisfied with our billing policies, our handling of personal data or other aspects of our staffing services. If we fail to adequately address these or other complaints, negative publicity about us or our services could diminish confidence in and the use of our staffing services. Our image or reputation can be severely damaged even by isolated incidents, particularly if an incident receives considerable negative publicity or results in litigation, and such litigation may also directly affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Some of these incidents may include: - problematic in-house employee or job candidate behavior, such as social discrimination, violent behavior and sexual harassment, or disagreements or disputes with clients, job candidates or in-house employees; - placing job candidates who do not, or are alleged to not, have the requisite background or experience; - accidents that take place both within our own premises or at client sites; or - breaches or allegations of breaches of legal and regulatory obligations. Other incidents that may generate negative publicity or harm our reputation or brands may arise from events that are or may be beyond our control, such as data security breaches or fraudulent activities associated with our records, work accidents relating to job candidates placed with our clients, litigation and legal claims or third-party misappropriation, dilution or infringement of our intellectual property.
