For example, adverse publicity relating to workplace accidents, including serious injuries or fatal accidents, could have a negative impact on our business, including loss of existing job candidates or inhouse employees, loss of clients or regulatory action. Furthermore, negative publicity relating to the temporary staffing industry, the use of foreign workers, the housing of foreign workers or immigration/worker mobility more generally or the staffing industry more generally, whether or not directly or indirectly related to any specific events arising from our own operations, could harm our reputation through association, particularly if such negative publicity references us as an operator in ----- such industry or makes any of our clients or job candidates reluctant to use our services as a result. For example, in the past, we received negative publicity and were subject to litigation related to the failure of a third party to provide adequate housing arrangements for job candidates who were recruited through our international recruitment network. In addition, our German subsidiary SOLCOM has faced negative publicity in the past in connection with a dissatisfied former shareholder. Failure to address, or appearing to fail to address, these and other issues could erode client confidence in our reputation or the brands of our Powerhouses. Restoring our reputation may be costly and difficult to achieve. Negative publicity or negative public opinion may adversely affect our ability to retain and attract clients or job candidates, or increase the costs of attracting and maintaining our client and job candidate base, the loss of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We could incur liabilities or our reputation could be damaged from improper disclosure or loss of sensitive or confidential company, employee, associate, job candidate or client data, including personal data, or from other difficulties faced in the operation of technical infrastructure.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the operation of our business, we store, process and transmit certain personal data, including personnel and payment information, about our in-house employees, clients, associates and job candidates, a portion of which is confidential and/or personally identifiable and sensitive. In engaging in these data-related activities, we rely on our own technology and systems and those of thirdparty vendors we use for a variety of processes, including cloud-based technology and systems, mobile technologies and social media. Unauthorized disclosure, modification or loss of confidential, personally identifiable or sensitive data or other operational failures may occur through a variety of methods. These include, but are not limited to, systems failures, in-house employee negligence, fraud or misappropriation, or unauthorized access to or through our information systems, whether by our inhouse employees, vendors or third parties, or a cyber-attack by hackers, members of organized crime and/or state-sponsored organizations. Computer malware, viruses, social engineering (predominantly spear phishing attacks), and general hacking have become more prevalent, have occurred on our systems in the past, and could occur on our systems in the future. We also regularly encounter attempts by third parties to fraudulently induce our in-house employees or job candidates to disclose information in order to gain access to our data or systems. An incident involving disclosure, data modification, loss or security breach or a significant technical failure could subject us to significant monetary damages or losses, litigation, negative publicity, regulatory enforcement actions, and liability under our contracts, resulting in increased costs or loss of revenue. In the past, we have experienced data security breaches resulting from unauthorized access to our systems, which to date have not had a material impact on our operations or financial results; however, there is no assurance that such impacts will not be material in the future. Furthermore, we are subject to specific regulations regarding the use of personal data. Those regulations generally impose certain requirements on the Group in respect of the collection, retention, use and processing of such personal information. Specifically in the EU, the General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) came into force and has applied directly to the legislation of all EU Member States since May 25, 2018, replacing historical EU data privacy laws, and implements more stringent operational requirements for processors and controllers of personal data. Moreover, there are a large amount of socalled opening clauses, which could lead to differences between implementations of the GDPR in European Union Member States. The implementation of these requirements of the GDPR is a burden on the Group’s legal and compliance functions, in particular for international data transfers as they occur in our business. The task to meet all the GDPR requirements is relatively complex. Therefore, it is possible that we may be found to fail to meet certain requirements of the GDPR and its implementations by the Member States. In case we are found to infringe provisions set out in the GDPR, sanctions may be imposed. Our failure to implement the GDPR (including the implementing rules of the EU Member States) could affect our reputation and relationships with our clients, or result in ----- regulatory action against us for the infringement of data protection rules, any of the foregoing could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial position or results of operations. The GDPR imposes administrative fines for data protection compliance violations of up to a maximum of €20 million or 4% of the company’s global annual turnover. If the third parties we work with violate applicable laws or contractual obligations, or suffer a security breach, such violations may also put us in breach of our obligations under privacy laws and regulations and this could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business. Although we seek to ensure that procedures are in place to ensure compliance with the relevant data protection regulations by our inhouse employees and job candidates and any third-party service providers, and also implement security measures to help prevent cyber theft, we nonetheless are exposed to the risk that this data could be wrongfully appropriated, lost, disclosed, stolen or processed in breach of data protection legislation. Managing these risks have become more difficult in connection with working-from-home policies that we adopted in connection with the Covid-19 pandemic and exposes us to additional risk for which additional work, licenses and expertise is needed to detect and prevent the occurrences from happening. Ransomware and cyber risks have increased in general during the Covid-19 pandemic and have also required us to invest in even more strict back-up procedures, leading to higher operating costs for all of its information technologies. In addition, concerns regarding our practices with regard to the collection, use, disclosure or security of personal information or other privacy-related matters could result in negative publicity and have a material adverse effect on our reputation and business and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any significant disruption in or cyber-attacks on our information technology systems, computer systems or software or in the systems operated by third parties that we utilize for such services could damage our reputation and result in a loss of clients or job candidates.
Subsubsection Text: Our brand, reputation and ability to support our in-house employees, attract and retain clients and job candidates depends upon the reliable performance of our or our third-party suppliers’ servers, network, cloud infrastructure, physical infrastructure, network infrastructure and content delivery processes (“IT systems”). Like many businesses, we and our third-party suppliers have experienced in the past, and may experience in the future, system disruptions that impact our IT systems. Any disruptions, outages or delays in our IT systems, including as a result of fire, flood, power loss, telecommunications failure, physical or electronic break-ins, earthquakes, pandemics, acts of war or terrorism or other events or disruptions, could affect the availability of our services and prevent or inhibit the ability of our in-house employees, clients or job candidates to access and utilize our systems or services. Moreover, we and our third-party suppliers may not be able to anticipate evolving techniques used to effect security breaches (which change frequently and may not be known to us until launched), or prevent attacks by hackers, including phishing, ransomware attacks or other cyber-attacks, or prevent breaches due to employee error or malfeasance, in a timely manner, or at all. Cyber-attacks have become far more prevalent in recent years, potentially leading to unauthorized access to, misuse or disclosure of, unavailability of, or the theft or manipulation of confidential and proprietary information, including information regarding our clients and job candidates, as well as loss of access to, or destruction of, data on our or third-party systems. The occurrence of any of the foregoing events could result in damage to our IT systems or could cause them to fail completely, and our insurance may not cover such events or may be insufficient to compensate for losses that may occur. An IT system failure at one site could result in reduced functionality and productivity for our in-house employees, clients or job candidates, and a total failure of our IT systems could cause our IT systems to be inaccessible by some or all of our in-house employees, clients or job candidates. Any errors, defects, disruptions or other performance problems with our IT systems could harm our reputation and may have a material adverse effect on its business, results of operations and financial condition and thus our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to effectively implement our business strategy, and there can be no assurance that we will achieve our objectives.
Subsubsection Text: An important element of our strategies is our effort to diversify our revenues beyond our core staffing and employment services through the utilization of digital initiatives and the introduction of new endmarkets through acquisitions. The development of such solutions is often unique and presents costs, risks and complexity that may be difficult to calculate. These solutions may be unprofitable if we are not able to accurately anticipate these costs and risks in implementing these solutions. For example, we may fail to structure and utilize our solutions in a manner that properly compensates us for the IT development costs associated with such innovations. With respect to acquisitions, we regularly review and pursue opportunities for strategic growth through acquisitions, including as a way to expand to new geographical areas and new market sectors. We may face difficulties in identifying suitable target businesses or consummating a transaction on terms that are favorable to us. In addition, we may be unable to realize expected strategic benefits, growth, diversification of our end-markets or other financial benefits from such acquisitions in the timeframe we anticipate or at all. Moreover, we may be unable to identify, negotiate or finance acquisitions or other strategic initiatives, successfully or at favorable terms in the future. Any future joint ventures or acquisitions of businesses, technologies, services or products might require us to obtain additional equity or debt financing, which may not be available on favorable terms, or at all. The parties to the agreements will not consummate the transactions until the conditions are fulfilled, which could take several months and, in exceptional circumstances, significantly longer. Accordingly, the parties may not be able to complete the transactions in a timely fashion or at all. Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot guarantee the successful implementation of our business strategies. Additionally, our strategies may put operational strain on our business and consume management time and focus to the detriment of our existing business operations. If we do not meet our strategic objectives or achieve the results initially expected, we may be unable to recover our investment or this may otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have included certain historical financial information on entities that we acquired, which were not prepared by us or reviewed by our auditors and in some instances, which were not audited at all, or which were prepared on a different basis from our current IFRS financial statements, which may not be reflective of our past performance or representative of our future results.
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we have presented certain historical financial metrics of our business unit accounts’ revenues and EBITDA, including figures on a pro forma basis from 2008 to the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 in part to demonstrate the impact of the 2009 financial crisis on our historical results of operations and to adjust for the impact of acquisitions we have done in the past as well as certain non-recurring and extraordinary items. The pro forma historical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum have been computed by adding the revenues of all of our acquired entities to our historical statutory accounts for the applicable periods to present our total revenues, as if they had been operating as a consolidated group at the relevant date. The historical financial metrics for the acquired entities have been obtained from their individual accounts and are therefore not comparable to our historical financial information. Some of these accounts may not have been prepared in accordance with statutory requirements or the accounting policies used by these acquired entities may differ in substantial respects from the manner in which we have prepared our accounts. For example, ABMI’s statutory accounts are prepared on a French GAAP basis. This financial information may not reflect what our results of operations or financial condition would have been had the Group operated as a consolidated group or reporting segment during the periods presented. A number of estimates, judgments and assumptions were made for the purpose of allocating those items that were not directly attributable and/or separately identifiable. Furthermore, our historical financial information does not necessarily indicate what our results of operations, had they existed with our current consolidation ----- perimeter, would have been had we been a consolidated entity in the past, how our financial condition will be in the future or how our operations might respond in the future to events similar to those experienced by us in the past. We have also included certain financial figures of certain of our competitors in this Offering Memorandum. The historical financial information of our historical statutory accounts, our business units’ accounts and the financial reporting of certain of our competitors, have been presented for illustrative purposes and those of our competitors are not necessarily comparable and are not prepared on the same basis.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not realize the expected benefit of our past or future acquisitions or we may face unforeseen costs or liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: In the past, we have grown through a combination of organic development and significant platform acquisitions, and we intend to continue this combination in the future. Recent acquisitions during the periods presented in the Financial Statements include several bolt-on and asset acquisitions in 2020, 2021 and 2022, and the acquisitions of new Powerhouses at the Group, including Cohedron in 2021 and TMI and SOLCOM in 2022. Growth through acquisitions entails certain risks, including the risk of a failure to realize the expected benefits of the acquisitions and incurrence of unexpected risks and obligations. These risks include, but are not limited to: - diversion of management’s time and attention from daily operations to the integration of newly acquired operations; - the possibility of not being able to retain key staff members and clients from the companies we acquire; - difficulties in conforming the acquired company’s accounting, books and records, internal controls, and procedures and policies to ours; - retaining the loyalty and business of the clients of acquired businesses; - challenges arising from a lack of familiarity with new markets with differing commercial and social norms and customs which may adversely impact our strategic goals or require us to adapt our business model for and other regulatory frameworks; - compliance with foreign legal and regulatory systems; - difficulties integrating technologies and maintaining uniform standards; - unforeseen legal, regulatory, anti-trust, pension liabilities, other contractual matters or other issues; - difficulties in maintaining timeliness and quality of service; and - unanticipated costs and expenses associated with any undisclosed or potential liabilities. There can be no guarantee that we will be able to discover or fully assess any or all potential costs or liabilities associated with any future acquisition. Furthermore, we have in the past and expect in the future to operate and acquire businesses in countries or markets where we are not currently present, with different regulatory systems and different operating cultures, which may exacerbate the risks identified above. In addition, acquisitions are also subject to the risk of overvaluation of the target and thus to the payment of consideration greater than the targets’ actual value to our business. We may also be unable to evaluate the scale of a potential acquisition, which may result in being unable to allocate proper resources to execute the acquisition, while our acquisition model expects we may acquire new business units which will have a great deal of autonomy. ----- Even if we are able to successfully integrate the operations of acquired businesses, we may not be able to realize the potential cost savings, synergies and revenue enhancements that were anticipated from the acquisition, either in the amount or within the timeframe that we expect. Additionally, the costs of achieving these benefits may be higher than, and the timing may differ from, what we expect. Our failure to realize the expected benefits or synergies of past or future acquisitions could result in the lack of implementation and achievement of our growth strategy may prevent us from obtaining the advantages that the acquisitions were intended to create, or could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on search engine optimization, undertake digital advertising campaigns and utilize social media and other online platforms to acquire new job candidates and clients, which may not be successful or cost-effective.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on Internet search engines, such as Google, to direct traffic to our Powerhouses’ websites, including our Powerhouses’ mobile websites. Search engines frequently update and change the logic that determines the placement and display of results of a user’s search, such that the purchased or algorithmic placement of links to our websites may be negatively affected. Moreover, a search or metasearch engine could, for competitive or other purposes, alter its search algorithms or results causing a website to place lower in search query results. If a major search engine changes its algorithms or results in a manner that negatively affects the search engine ranking, paid or unpaid, of our websites, or if competitive dynamics impact the costs or effectiveness of search engine optimization, search engine marketing or other traffic-generating arrangements in a negative manner, it may lead to the loss of existing job candidates or clients or hamper our ability to attract new job candidates or clients. In addition, certain meta-search companies have added or intend to add various forms of functionality to their sites. To the extent such functionality is promoted at the expense of traditional paid listings, this may reduce the amount of traffic to our websites. We also attract job candidates as well as new clients through paid marketing channels. In order to maintain our current revenues and grow our business, we need to continually optimize advertising campaigns, and paid search engine optimization aimed at acquiring new job candidates and clients. Social media and online job boards have been an effective way for us to reach passive job seeker candidates and our success in these efforts depends, in part, upon our continued ability to promote our staffing services on third-party websites, such as Facebook, Google for Jobs and Indeed.com to whom we pay fees to advertise. If one of the advertisers or social media platforms to which we direct online advertising expenditures, use to promote our services or locate potential clients, were to increase their fees, change their interface or experience disruptions in service, we may be required to incur additional advertising expenses to acquire job candidates and clients. Furthermore, if any significant third-party websites or platforms on which we advertise, promote our services or locate potential clients were to lose their market position or otherwise fall out of favor with consumers or other factors cause their user bases to stop growing or shrink, we may need to identify alternative channels for advertising and promoting our staffing services, which could consume substantial resources and may not be effective, or available at all. Any of the foregoing may have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition or result of operations and thus our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Given that many of our job candidates are employees on indefinite term contracts, an underutilization of such job candidates or any significant increase in staff costs or other direct costs may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: Our Powerhouses regularly place medium to highly skilled job candidates who are engineers, technicians or other white-collar consultants with clients on a medium-term to long-term basis, and the job candidates in most of our engineering and consulting segment Powerhouses are employees with ----- indefinite term contracts on our payroll whether or not they are on assignment with a client. In addition, due to regulatory requirements, our job candidates in Germany are also our employees with indefinite term contracts and on our payroll whether or not they are on assignment with a client. In light of the above, the utilization of such job candidates (i.e., the time that can be billed to a client assignment) has a significant impact on the generation of our revenue. If such job candidates are underutilized, we will not be generating revenue, but we will continue to incur costs for these job candidates. Accordingly, the time for which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed to a client assignment, or “bench time,” has an impact on our profitability. The degree to which we are able to utilize and manage our job candidates is affected by a number of factors, including: - our ability to forecast demand for our services and to recruit, maintain and deploy job candidates in alignment with demand, including job candidates with the right mix of skills and experience to support client demand; - our ability to transition job candidates from completed client engagements to new assignments and to hire, assimilate and deploy new job candidates; - our ability to manage retention; - our ability to engage and motivate our job candidates and their level of productivity; and - performance, including through seeking out new clients engagements or extending existing clients engagements. A number of these factors have been more difficult to manage as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. Although our business activities have been restored to or surpassed pre-Covid-19 levels, a number of our clients may still be uncertain of their staffing needs or hesitant to renew assignments for job candidates as the Covid-19 pandemic has changed the way how job candidates approach working. The war in Ukraine and the potential economic impact, as well as the global inflation and supply chain shortage have also caused uncertainties on how companies fill their staffing requirements. Furthermore, while temporary unemployment government measures implemented during the Covid-19 pandemic allowed us to manage certain of our costs that come from underutilized job candidates, a number of these measures, however, ended during the course of 2021, and the remaining measures expired as of July 2022. Moreover, the significant economic volatility in today’s market, despite the recovery in GDP growth for our geographical market following the Covid-19 pandemic, may lead to a reduction in the funding and/or willingness of customers to engage us for our services, which could in turn lead to an increase in underutilized job candidates. Increased direct costs (resulting from salary inflation for existing or new job candidates or an increase in headcount for our job candidates as part of our growth strategy or otherwise) without a corresponding increase in revenue could have a material adverse effect on our gross profit. While it is important for us to manage our additional client assignments or higher priced job candidate costs to maintain our gross margin, a failure to increase pay in line with our competitors could restrict our ability to attract new job candidates and retain existing job candidates, which could impact the quality of the services we provide to clients and our ability to win new or to maintain existing client relationships. If our costs increase at a higher rate than our revenue, whether due to factors that lead to less revenue (including as a result of our job candidates being underutilized) or factors that lead to increased costs, we may not be as competitive and profitability will be impacted. As a result, a material underutilization of our job candidates or an increase in costs could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our interim results fluctuate as a result of seasonality in our business.
Subsubsection Text: ----- Our revenue is subject to seasonal fluctuations in many of the end-markets in which we operate. We have in the past experienced, and expect in the future to experience fluctuations in our results of operations due to seasonal demand in our current end-markets. Seasonality varies depending on a number of different factors and can impact our Powerhouses and our two business segments differently. The underlying end-markets we serve are subject to various drivers that impact overall industry demand and therefore demand from our clients for staffing. For example, the construction industry may experience inclement weather or other causes on a worksite, which can impact demand for job candidates. As a result of the mix of services we provide, seasonal work can also cause a peak in demand during a specific period, such as the weeks leading up to Christmas and Easter, around harvest time in the food production sector or around holiday periods such as the Christmas holidays and summer holidays. Historically, as a general matter, our revenue fluctuates, with higher levels of revenue typically being received in the second half of the year just after the summer holidays, which is then sustained for a period before decreasing again in December due to Christmas holidays. We also present certain unaudited monthly revenue and _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA financial information in this Offering Memorandum for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 derived from management accounts, which typically display more seasonality and may be subject to adjustment at quarter-end, and therefore investors should exercise caution when placing reliance thereon. Moreover, we also experience seasonality with regard to our working capital requirements. We generally experience larger working capital requirements in the first half of the year due to increased holiday pay, bonus pay and tax payments. While our working capital requirements are generally lower in the second half of the year, our working capital requirements also experience an increase at the end of the year for end-of year bonuses and holiday pay, particularly as certain of our businesses institute mandatory holiday at the end of the year. Furthermore, our results during 2020 were also impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, which affected the traditional seasonality patterns experienced by the Group with respect to revenue and with respect to working capital (with a number of governments granting postponements to certain tax or other expenses and providing grants for certain unemployment support that temporarily decreased the Group’s working capital needs) compared to previous years.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Weaknesses and deficiencies in our controls generally or over financial reporting may prevent us from managing our growth effectively, reporting our financial results accurately or result in a material misstatement of such results.
Subsubsection Text: The accuracy of our financial reporting is dependent on the effectiveness of our controls. Controls over financial reporting have inherent limitations, including human error or inaccuracies in recording information or transferring information into systems, the possibility that controls could be circumvented or become inadequate because of changed conditions, a lack of requisite personnel, lack of segregated duties or controls, fraud or because of our decentralized structure across smaller business units. Because of these inherent limitations, controls over financial reporting may not prevent or detect all misstatements or fraud. In addition, our organizational structure may make it difficult to implement changes across business units in a consistent manner, including those required for internal control, other controls and compliance. We could also face difficulties in bringing the controls, accounting procedures and policies of the companies that we acquire up to the standard of our controls and procedures in time for the reporting cycle following an acquisition, which could lead to inaccuracies or misstatements in our financial reporting. If we cannot maintain or execute adequate controls over financial reporting or implement required new or improved controls that provide reasonable assurance of the reliability of the financial reporting and preparation of our financial statements for external use, we could suffer harm to our reputation, fail to meet our reporting requirements on a timely basis, be unable to properly report on our business or our results of operations, or be required to restate our financial statements. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face risks associated with the collection of trade receivables and certain counterparty risk.
Subsubsection Text: ----- Trade receivables constitute a significant portion of our assets and are therefore a major business investment. As of December 31, 2021 and as of September 30, 2022, trade receivables constituted 11.6% and 13.8%, respectively, of our total assets. Successful control of the trade receivables process demands the development of appropriate credit, collection, and financing policies. In addition, we are exposed to credit risk, meaning the risk that our clients and other counter-parties may be unable to fulfill their payment obligations. Macroeconomic conditions have a significant influence on credit risk, as in an economic downturn more clients tend to fall into default, which could be magnified for us as a result of our exposure to SME and ISE clients, which may have less ability to raise capital from other sources during a downturn. Since the outbreak of Covid-19 in the markets in which we operate, a number of businesses, particularly small businesses, have been supported by government measures. It cannot be excluded that as the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic continues or once these government measures expire, such businesses, including our clients supported by such measures, may face cash flow shortages or bankruptcy, which could impact our ability to collect trade receivables in a timely manner or at all, particularly for those receivables which would not be covered by the Group’s credit insurance, which has a maximum liability amount of up to €250.0 million and is held by all of our Powerhouses, except for Cohedron and TMI. If our clients become unable to pay amounts owed to us, or pay us more slowly, then our cash flow and profitability may suffer. We are also exposed to counterparty risk with respect to certain credit insurance maintained by certain of our business units, swap agreements we have entered into in respect of interest payments as well as factoring agreements (for which our Group retains a credit risk and late payments risk). Financial services institutions and other counterparties are inter-related because of trading, funding, clearing or other relationships. As a result, defaults by, or even rumors or questions about the financial stability of one or more financial services institutions, or the financial services industry generally, could lead to market-wide liquidity disruptions, losses and defaults. Many of these transactions expose us to credit risk in the event of a default by one or more of our counterparties. If we fail to maintain a solid collections policy or to manage our credit risk or if there were such an economic downturn in the markets in which we operated or an impact on the financial services markets including our counterparties, such a failure or event could have a negative effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance policies may not be adequate to cover all the risks we face and, if we are no longer covered by our existing insurance, it may be difficult to obtain replacement insurance on acceptable terms or at all.
Subsubsection Text: Our policy is to maintain directors’ and officers’ liability, occupational accident, credit, general professional liability, workers’ compensation (for Belgian entities only), motor third party liability, travel, property damage and cyber insurance and additional insurance covering our main insurable risks to the extent such insurance coverage is available for reasonable premiums. We may, however, become subject to liability against which we have not been insured, cannot insure or are insufficiently insured, such as employment practices liability, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition or results of operations. For example, to the extent any claims arise during a job candidate’s assignment with a client which we expected the clients’ insurance to cover and it does not, we may face uninsured losses in connection with any such events. In addition, we may not be able to enter into new insurance agreements on commercially acceptable terms and conditions in the future. For example, our business units in Belgium are required to insure occupational accidents through specifically licensed private insurance companies, as a consequence of the Law of April 10, 1971 and subsequent Royal Decrees. Furthermore, following the outbreak of Covid-19 in the markets in which we operate, a number of insurance companies have increased or may attempt to raise insurance prices, which we may not be able to fully recover by passing along these increased expenses in our negotiations of client contracts and fees for our job candidates’ services. Given the nature of our operations, which typically results in us placing our job candidates on our payroll while they are on assignment, we are required to insure a significant number of persons. Since 2021, a variable premium rate has been applied to our work accident insurance, with a base premium rate of 2.918%, a mid-case rate of 3.064% and ----- worst-case rate of 3.097%, depending on the number of work accidents we have. This premium is calculated based on the gross salary mass of our temporary workers. For 2021, we estimate that the mid-case rate will apply, although the base premium rate could potentially still apply depending on the recovery process of the individuals involved in work accidents, which would have a significant impact on the calculation of the final compensation to be paid out and therefore impact the premium rate that will be applied to us. We also estimate that the mid-case rate will apply for 2022, and at the moment we are on course for the base premium rate; however, this expectation could change drastically depending on any further occurrences of work accident in the remainder of 2022. The materialization of any of these risks may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in sentiment toward the staffing industry could affect demand for our services.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, the staffing industry has come under criticism from unions, works councils, regulatory agencies, governments and other constituents that maintain that labor and employment protections, such as wage and benefits regulations, are subverted by staffing services, particularly temporary staffing services. Our business is dependent on the continued acceptance of staffing arrangements as a source of flexible labor for our clients. If attitudes or business practices in some locations change due to pressure from organized labor, political groups, or regulatory agencies, or alternatively due to increased use of and preference for online job platforms and other digital intermediaries which results in decreased demand for our services from clients, we could experience a decline in revenue. For example, temporary staffing is generally impermissible in Germany without a valid permit from the relevant authorities, and there can be no guarantee that regulations in our other primary markets will not change in the future to prohibit the same. Also, new legislation has come into effect in the Netherlands requiring employment housing to remain available for four weeks following the end of employment of foreign workers, which has also led to an increased focus on separation between employment providers and housing providers. While this separation is not currently legally required, we expect it will be enforced in the future. Notwithstanding the above, there is currently no clear indication as to the extent of what the required separation will be, and we cannot be certain at this time whether a complete separation, or a full ban on the provision of housing to temporary workers by employment agencies, will be legally required in the future and how that would impact the demand for our services. In addition, the use of foreign workers by the staffing industry is also criticized and may receive significant political, media or other attention from time to time. To the extent that this decreases demand for our staffing requires, this could also result in a decline in revenue for the Group. In particular, demand for our services from government and public sector clients related to the Covid19 pandemic may decrease over time. On July 20, 2021, we acquired Cohedron, which primarily advises public authorities and municipalities and is currently a Powerhouse in our engineering and consulting segment. We have increased business from services rendered to the government and public sector clients during the Covid-19 pandemic due to, among other developments, work related to government support measures, such as the TOZO scheme, as well as concerns related to the widespread personal debt issue of the citizens in the Netherlands. The Covid-19 pandemic-related services and other work for government and public sector clients has contributed to our revenue over the past year. It is unknown to what extent business with such clients may decrease as the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic lessen or change over time. Demand for our services from government and public sector clients may also fall as clients adapt to the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic and their needs evolve. We will continue to monitor the situation, but the future impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and its effects on the needs of our clients are impossible to fully predict, and there can be no assurance that our increased business in the government and public sector will be sustained. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may have to incur significant charges for impairment of goodwill or other material intangible or tangible non-current and current assets.
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2022, goodwill represented €1.2 billion or 49.5% of our total assets, and our noncurrent assets amounted to €1.9 billion and our current assets amounted to €603.1 million. As required by IFRS, we test material assets annually for impairment. We have not experienced any material impairments of goodwill during the three years ended December 31, 2021. We performed an impairment test during the second quarter of 2022 given the rising interest rate in the current market, which we consider to be an impairment indicator. Goodwill impairment in relation to the GRITT Powerhouse was identified, as the recoverable amount was €40.9 million compared to the carrying value of €54.2 million. We performed another impairment test during the third quarter of 2022 due to further increases in interest rates, and identified no additional impairments. We therefore recorded a goodwill impairment of €13.3 million for the nine months ending September 30, 2022, as we consider this change to have a long-term impact. If we have any indication that the value of any of our material assets could decline, including indicators such as an economic downturn, the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and its consequential economic impact or certain business decisions, this results in an impairment test that could result in impairments of goodwill or of other current or non-current assets, and if any such impairments were substantial, this would negatively impact our operating profit. Any significant charge for impairment in the future could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or result of operations and thus our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. In addition, following the Transactions, we will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations). The application of purchase accounting may result in significantly different carrying values for goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment. Due to these and other potential adjustments, future financial statements for the Group could be materially different and may not be comparable to our Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including but not limited to, risk of impairment of goodwill and intangible and tangible assets, increased depreciation and amortization expenses over the remaining lives of the acquired assets and recognition of temporary differences at the acquisition date. None of the financial information in this Offering Memorandum have been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes to the financial statements that might occur as a result of purchase accounting adjustments to be applied as a result of the Transactions. See “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Comparability of the Financial Statements.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Risks relating to template contracts and forms may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain contractual relationships with a large number of clients across the jurisdictions in which our business units operate. In order to efficiently manage these contractual relationships at each of our business units, we employ general terms and conditions and standard templates in our contracts and forms. Furthermore, certain of our business units work with a number of large corporate clients and are sometimes required to adhere to their standard terms and conditions. As a result of the foregoing, we are exposed to legal risks whenever such contracts contain drafting errors, execution errors (including unsigned agreements), lack sufficient detail on the nature of our liability to the client, require customized terms and conditions, or require additional analysis as to legal sufficiency. Such general terms and conditions, standard contracts and forms used and signed by us may not comply with all the applicable legal requirements at all times. Moreover, as our in-house employees receive incentivelinked pay, they could agree to non-standard terms in a bid to sign on new clients which may expose us to additional liabilities. In addition, certain agreements with our clients contain indemnifications and hold harmless obligations in favor of our clients. We are not always able to contractually exclude or limit such potential claims and certain of our contracts therefore bear the risk of uncapped liability, including certain agreements with our large corporate clients. There can be no assurance that we will not experience these problems in the future, that the insurance will cover all claims that may be asserted ----- against us or that we may not incur fines or other losses if any such problems should arise. Any of the foregoing may result in claims for compensation, unexpected liabilities for the Group or other legal consequences that may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A significant portion of our revenue is derived from SME and ISE clients and we could be negatively impacted by the costs associated by providing such service or adverse market conditions or other factors that affect our SME and ISE clients.
Subsubsection Text: Our client portfolio is mainly composed of SMEs and ISEs, which have historically accounted for a substantial portion of our sales. Key challenges we face in providing services to the SME and ISE market include: - serving as the expert in staffing needs to organizations that often lack internal HR resources and ensuring our services meet their needs in terms of support, flexible decision making and excellence in customer service; - devoting resources to advise our SME and ISE clients on compliance with applicable labor regulations, including health and safety requirements; - investing in client relationships takes time and staffing assignments with SMEs and ISEs may require more of such investment since typical average staffing needs may be for only one to two job candidates at a time; and - devoting significant resources to developing services tailored to their needs, standards and specific requirements. Furthermore, an economic downturn in the end-markets in which our SME and ISE clients operate could have a negative impact on the demand for our services or the prices such clients are willing to pay for our services. The Covid-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on the results of operations and financial viability of SMEs and ISEs as many have had their trading interrupted due to lockdowns and typically businesses of such size have difficulty accessing debt and equity financing. Although certain government programs have been established to assist SMEs and ISEs, we can provide no assurance that these schemes will be sufficient and a number of them have been, or may be in the future discontinued, and as a result many SMEs and ISEs may be in danger of closing. Therefore, while lockdown measures have lifted or eased, many of our SME and ISE clients may still be facing significant difficulties in recovering from the economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The current inflationary environment may also pose further financial pressure on our SME and ISE clients as they may be less likely to be able to pass-through higher operational costs to their customers, which may impact their demand for our services or the prices they are willing to pay us. As a result, our focus on SMEs and ISEs could result in additional costs to the Group as compared to our peers that are less focused on the SME and ISE market. Conditions or developments that affect SMEs and ISEs in particular, which may be related to macroeconomic factors, including inflation, regulatory developments, consumer trends or other factors leading to a material decline in SMEs’ and ISEs’ demand for staffing services could have a material adverse effect on the Group’s business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to extensive laws and regulations which may adversely affect our ability to conduct our business and may reduce our future earnings.
Subsubsection Text: In many jurisdictions in which we operate, such as Belgium and Germany, the employment services industry is heavily regulated. These laws and regulations sometimes limit the size and growth of ----- employment services industries in these countries. Some of the laws and regulations impact directly our profitability; for example, the 2008 EU Directive of Temporary Agency Work seeks to guarantee those working through staffing solutions providers equal pay and conditions with employees in the same business who perform the same job duties, which led to an increase in our cost of services. Some other laws and regulations restrict our sector expansion; for example, the use of staffing services by staffing solutions providers in the local construction end-market is prohibited in Germany. Furthermore, in April 2017, Germany enacted legislation introducing equal pay for temporary workers as well as restricting the length of temporary employment to 18 months, which led to a downturn in our business and an adverse impact to our operating results due to the overtaking of temporary workers by clients, and which legislation has continued to have an impact in subsequent periods. While we have systems and processes in place to monitor our compliance with such laws, it is possible such systems could fail which could have a negative impact on our financial results or reputation. In addition, substantial changes to Dutch law governing temporary staffing came into effect from January 1, 2020. These changes to regulation had some impact on our business, as they resulted in the costs for temporary work increasing. For example, there are increased social security charges for temporary staffing agencies in their capacity as employer, and we expect a formal separation between employment providers and housing providers will be legally required in the future. Furthermore, payroll employees will be entitled to all terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions, and a temporary employment clause and the additional flexibility to enter into fixed term employment agreements that are traditionally allowed are no longer applicable to payroll employees. As a result of these regulations coming into effect in 2020, our cost of services has increased, but we also simultaneously increased our sales prices for our job candidates’ services. While to date we have been able to pass on the majority of these increases in costs to our clients through higher fees charged for our services, this nevertheless leads to an increased cost for our services at clients, which may lead to clients questioning the relatively higher cost of temporary/flexible staffing versus hiring permanent employees, thus reducing their demand for our services. The impact of these changes cannot yet be fully ascertained as it is still evolving following the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, and while companies have demonstrated increased demand for hiring flexibility in the current market, many of them have also become more focused on cost savings, leading to less use of temporary work. In some countries, special taxes, fees or costs are imposed in connection with the use of our job candidates. For example, as a consequence of certain legal restrictions, certain deductions are not allowed if the net salary paid to job candidates falls below minimum wage as a result. For these nondeductible costs, we send invoices to the workers. If workers do not pay their invoices and return to their country of origin, we are left with the costs. Furthermore, changes in zoning regulations or their interpretation could result in increased costs in order to house our job candidates. Covid-19 related government measures relating to quarantine regulations and separate housing requirements for job candidates at certain of our Powerhouses have also resulted in increased housing costs for job candidates. Additionally, trade unions may use the political process to target our industry in an effort to increase the regulatory burden and expenses associated with offering or utilizing temporary staffing workforce solutions. How employment-related laws are interpreted and applied to our practices may result in increased operating costs and less flexibility in our business. Furthermore, many countries are also expanding restrictions on immigration and have introduced substantial penalties that may be imposed on staffing solutions providers and their client for employing foreign workers without necessary work and residence permits. As a result, there is a risk that we may incur greater expense in connection with restrictions imposed on recruiting foreign workers. In addition, the countries and territories in which we operate may, among other things: - create additional regulations that prohibit or restrict the types of employment services that we currently provide; - require that new or additional benefits be paid to our job candidates; ----- - increase payroll related costs such as general and medical insurance, workers’ compensation; - require us to comply with additional social laws, including in relation to collective bargaining procedures; - require us to obtain additional licensing to provide employment services; - limit the circumstances under which temporary staff may be employed; - reclassify the status or categorization of our job candidates under applicable social laws which would require us to comply with additional requirements, including payment of additional welfare benefits; or - increase taxes such as sales or value-added taxes. In some countries, we are able to utilize laws, regulations or governmental measures that incentivize work and employment through governmental support programs, subsidies or other specific measures which help generate demand for our staffing services and provide opportunities for us to place job candidates or to be reimbursed for certain of their wages or salary costs by placing them in work. These governmental programs include those supporting shift work, night work, students and training, amongst others. If these programs are discontinued, there may be less demand for our staffing services. In addition, should we or the administrator responsible for such programs determine as a result of reviews, control procedures or otherwise that any of our job candidates or the work opportunity do not meet the eligibility criteria for such programs after we have placed them, we may not be eligible for any subsidies for such job candidates’ wages or salaries or we could be required to reimburse the government for any subsidies that were already received, which could have a negative impact on our profits. Furthermore, we also benefitted from temporary government measures introduced as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, which have since expired and such expiration resulted in limited increased costs to the Group. Any future regulations or interpretations from administrations thereof may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations because they may make it more difficult or expensive for us to continue to provide employment services (such as by increasing employment taxes), particularly if we cannot pass on increases in costs to our clients. For example, on December 17, 2020, the Dutch government approved a new law that aims to curb nitrogen emission, which has had an impact on the Dutch agricultural sector given the country’s large amount of livestock, and, in turn, caused the demand of our job candidates in this sector to fluctuate. Belgium has also passed similar nitrogen emission-related legislation, which could have an adverse impact on our business there as well. In addition, on April 21, 2021, the European Commission presented a proposal for a Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (“CSRD”), which would amend the existing reporting requirements of the Non-Financial Reporting Directive and encourage corporate spending towards sustainable activities across the EU. The European Council approved the CSRD on November 28, 2022 and the application of the regulation is expected to take place in four stages, the first of which will require companies that already fall under the CSRD to complete their first CSRD reporting on the financial year 2024, with expected reporting deadlines in 2025. We expect that we will be required to comply with the CSRD. We cannot guarantee how the new Dutch nitrogen regulation, the CSRD or any other existing or potential environmental regulations will impact our governance structure and our day-today business activities. Future changes to regulations may have more stringent requirements that could increase our cost of operations or impact the demand of our services, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and in turn impact our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Potential vaccine mandates adopted in our primary markets could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The Covid-19 pandemic has sparked debates around how to increase vaccine uptake around the globe, and while at the moment none of the governments in our primary markets has imposed vaccine ----- mandates, the European Commission has been encouraging its member states to step up in their vaccination campaigns and address vaccine hesitancy. It is unclear at the moment whether there will be any vaccine mandates imposed in our primary markets, and it is extremely difficult to predict the impact that a vaccine mandate will have on us or on our job candidates should any such mandate be imposed. Any vaccine requirement or vaccine mandate, if implemented, may result in employee attrition; likewise, any failure to implement a vaccine requirement or mandate may also result in employee attrition or resistance to returning to onsite work, either of which could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Our staffing business is required to maintain and comply with a number of permits, licenses or certifications, and our failure to maintain or comply with such authorizations may result in the loss of our licenses, our existing clients or may hamper our ability to attract new clients.
Subsubsection Text: In some of the jurisdictions in which we operate, including Belgium and Germany, our temporary staffing business requires a variety of permits and licenses. Our business may be adversely affected if we are unable to comply with existing regulations or requirements or if changes in applicable regulations or requirements occur. In the event of non-compliance, our existing permits and licenses may be revoked or we may be subject to a fine, and re-application for such permits and licenses may be prohibited or may require us to incur significant cost and expense. For example, we are currently being investigated by Belgian authorities for allegedly providing residential housing units that do not meet the required quality of living standards. On October 31, 2022, the court of first instance ruled in our favor, but the prosecutor has appealed and we expect the court of appeal to hear the case in 2023. Although we believe any potential financial fines resulting from such investigations would not be material to our overall business, such investigation could lead to a potential review and change of status of our temporary worker agency license. Should the status of our license change, some of our clients might prefer not to work with us until our license is restored to its previous status. Certain of our licenses are also subject to periodic renewal. If the regulatory approvals required for such transfers are not obtained, are delayed or are economically prevented, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. We also maintain various client quality certifications which authorize certain of our Powerhouses, such as, among others, Abylsen, GRITT and Redmore, to supply services to our clients. A failure to renew these quality certifications in future audits may cause us to lose existing clients and threaten our ability to attract new clients, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Breaches of the health and safety laws may adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our clients operate in a variety of end-markets in which our clients and our business units are often subject to a number of increasingly stringent health and safety laws and regulations. As a result, our job candidates working in these end-markets, including, in particular the construction, infrastructure and defense sectors, may be subject to accidents at work, some of which have in the past and could in the future, result in injuries, including severe ones causing disability or even death. In certain of the jurisdictions in which we operate, we may be liable to our job candidates for damages or subject to regulatory action as a result of unsafe working conditions at the client’s premises. We could also be liable toward our job candidates or subject to regulatory action or loss of our license to the extent we do not meet legal requirements with respect to such placement, for example submitting job candidates to a medical examination for applicable placements in advance of the job candidate beginning work. Furthermore, any failures of such standards by our clients or ourselves that generate adverse publicity could have a negative impact on our reputation and our ability to attract future business, result in the loss of existing job candidates affected by any such behavior or otherwise harm our business or operations. In circumstances where a liability arises as a result of the actions of a client, we may be ----- unable to recuperate or bring a claim in respect of any sums that we have paid in connection with the relevant claim. Any failure to comply with the existing, or any future, standards applicable to our clients may result in civil claims, criminal liability, regulatory action and penalties against us or our directors or managers. For example, the labor inspectorate in Belgium is currently conducting an investigation into one of our Powerhouses in Belgium for alleged criminal negligence in respect of health and safety legislation relating to a fatal accident of a temporary worker on customer premises. Should we be found liable, we could face fines, temporary or permanent restrictions on engaging in certain activities, and temporary or permanent closures of one or more sites. Any such action could also lead to liability for our directors or managers, which could, in turn, damage our reputation and impact our ability to participate in public tenders for this Powerhouse. Any failure to prevent a health or safety risk from occurring and causing damage or loss may materially adversely affect our reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Legal, regulatory or other adversarial action, including employment-related claims, could have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: At any given time, we may be a party to litigation or be subject to non-litigated claims arising in the ordinary course of business. These may include possible claims by clients or regulatory bodies against us relating to: - classification of temporary workers; - employment of undocumented workers; - failing to verify job candidates’ backgrounds and qualifications; - job candidates’ misconduct or negligence; or - fraudulent or criminal job candidate activities or misuse of client proprietary information. We may also be subject to claims by job candidates or regulatory bodies (including in relation to actions of our clients or any third parties that we hire). Some of these may include claims relating to: - violations of labor laws such as minimum wage requirements: - discrimination and harassment; - wrongful termination or denial of employment; - violations of employment rights related to employment screening or privacy issues; - violation of social laws, such as provision of adequate housing for foreign workers; or - payment of workers’ compensation claims or other health and safety related claims. In addition, in the ordinary course of business, we bring claims or may be pursuing other legal or regulatory remedies. We are involved in contractual relationships with our clients and other third parties that may cause us from time to time, by court order or by unilateral action, to enforce our contractual rights against these parties. These claims may seek, among other things, compensation for alleged losses, civil penalties or injunctive or declaratory relief. If any such claim is ultimately resolved unfavorably, and we are required to bear all or a portion of the costs arising from such proceedings, we may not receive compensation we were expecting, be required to incur additional expenses may be less effective at enforcing our agreements in the future. For example, the founder and former Chief Executive Officer of one of our Powerhouses in France, who we dismissed for cause, brought two claims against us alleging that he is entitled for additional ----- monetary payment for certain shares that he owned in the French Powerhouse of which he was CEO and for certain shares he owned in House of HR. Although we believe that he is not entitled to such additional payment as a result of him having been dismissed for cause, should he prevail in his claim, our maximum potential exposure is €15.0 million. A decision is expected during the course of the first quarter of 2023. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.” In addition, SOLCOM has been a subject in investigations by customs authorities in relation to suspected de-facto employment of freelancers. The investigations were closed in 2021, and while it was concluded that no criminal offenses were committed and none of the freelancers were deemed employees, we paid a total of €4.0 million to the German pension insurance and the public prosecutor’s office in 2021 to minimize procedural costs. Accent was also challenged in 2017 by the Belgian tax authorities for an alleged tax fraud relating to a Luxembourgish construction in for activities prior to 2014, which Accent ultimately settled with the Belgian tax authorities. Furthermore, there is currently a pending case before the European Court of Justice regarding certain German staffing legislations, which stems from a law suit against TIMEPARTNER concerning a labor law violation, which TIMEPARTNER previously won in two instances. All parties involved in this case have provided statements, and we believe that the court may take six to 14 months to issue a decision. We may be subject to other litigation and disputes, claims and complaints, including adversarial actions, by clients, in-house employees, suppliers, insurers and others in the ordinary course of business, which may have a material impact on our results of operations, liquidity, capital resources or financial position. Significant claims or a substantial number of small claims may be expensive to defend, may divert the time and focus of management away from our operations and may result in our having to pay monetary damages, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. In addition, adverse legal publicity or substantial litigation against us could negatively impact our reputation, even if we are not found liable, which could also have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Our business may suffer if we cannot continue to license or enforce the intellectual property rights on which our business depends or if we are subject to claims of intellectual property infringement.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, upon our ability to protect our proprietary methodologies and other intellectual property, including the value of our brands. We rely upon a combination of trade secrets, confidentiality, license and other contractual agreements and patent, copyright, and trademark laws to protect our intellectual property rights. We also rely on certain license agreements from third parties to utilize software or other intellectual property used within our businesses. For example, certain of our business units rely on proprietary software that we have developed internally or acquired, such as NOWJOBS, SWOP, Book’u, CV Creator, MyTests, Dora, MyTools and Gighouse, as part of our digital initiatives strategy. Our intellectual property rights may not prevent competitors from independently developing services and solutions similar to ours or from using similar software to ours. In certain jurisdictions, such as Belgium, we also rely on a favorable tax regime on copyright incomes to attract creative software developers. In Belgium, an ongoing reform will make the favorable tax regime subject to stricter conditions. This may affect our ability to attract or keep software developers. Furthermore, the steps we take may not be adequate to prevent or deter infringement or other misappropriation of our intellectual property by competitors, former in-house employees or other third parties, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. We can also not be sure that our services and solutions do not infringe on the intellectual property rights of third parties. Third parties, including competitors, may assert intellectual property infringement, misappropriation or invalidity claims against us that could be upheld. ----- Intellectual property litigation, which could result in substantial cost to and diversion of effort by us, may be necessary to protect our intellectual property rights, including trade secrets or proprietary technology or for us to defend against claimed infringement or misappropriation of the rights of others and to determine the scope and validity of our or others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights. We may not prevail in any such litigation, and if we are unsuccessful, we may be subject to monetary liability and injunctive or equitable relief, which may prevent our use of others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights if we are not able to obtain the necessary licenses on reasonable terms or at all. Any failure by us to protect our trademarks and other intellectual property rights may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to anti-corruption, anti-bribery, anti-money laundering, financial and other relevant laws and regulations, and our compliance systems may not be sufficient to adequately prevent or detect legal, financial and operational risks.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to various laws and regulations relating to, among other things, prevention of bribery and corruption, money laundering and illegal employment, as well as compliance requirement in relation to data protection and minimum wage regulations, as well as trade and economic sanctions on certain countries, persons, groups and/or entities, projects and/or activities. We are reliant on the compliance of our in-house employees, job candidates and clients with applicable laws and compliance policies implemented by us. There can be no assurance, however, that our in-house employees, job candidates and clients will not commit criminal, unlawful or unethical acts, or that our compliance and risk management will be sufficient to prevent or detect any breaches of relevant laws and regulations. Any such acts or breaches of law could result in whistle-blower complaints, adverse media coverage, civil and criminal investigations or other penalties and damages, which could cause considerable damage to our reputation, thereby negatively affecting our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to detect and prevent fraud or other misconduct committed by our employees, representatives, agents, customers or other third parties.
Subsubsection Text: We may be exposed to fraud or other misconduct committed by our employees, representatives, agents, customers or other third parties that could affect our reputation and subject us to litigation, financial losses and sanctions imposed by governmental authorities. Such misconduct could include hiding unauthorized or unlawful activities, resulting in unknown and unmanaged risks of losses, improperly using or disclosing confidential information, misappropriating funds, engaging in misrepresentation or fraudulent, deceptive or otherwise improper activities or otherwise failing to comply with applicable laws or our internal policies and procedures. Our internal control procedures are designed to monitor our operations and ensure overall compliance. Such internal control procedures, however, may be unable to identify all instances of noncompliance or suspicious transactions in a timely manner, if at all. Furthermore, it is not always possible to detect and prevent fraud and other misconduct and the precautions we take to prevent and detect such activities may not be effective. There is no assurance that fraud or other misconduct will not occur in the future. If such fraud or other misconduct does occur, it may result in negative publicity for us.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Title: Changes in the interpretation of tax laws, changes to tax rates, the introduction of new tax legislation or challenges to our tax position may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations and thus on our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to income and other taxes in various jurisdictions.
