Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading provider of HR solutions in key European staffing markets, offering end-to-end temporary recruiting and outsourcing services. We supply specialized and niche staffing to primarily small and medium-sized enterprise (“SME”) clients in a diversified range of end-markets. We offer and tailor our services to the staffing needs of our clients through our engineering and consulting segment and specialized talent solutions segment, which are comprised of a well-developed portfolio of ten specialized business units, which we call Powerhouses, across various countries. We also offer digital recruiting through our dedicated platforms, using our digital tools, including, NOWJOBS, SWOP and Gighouse app, targeting low-skilled, high-volume markets with significant roll-out potential. Since our founding, we have expanded from a presence in only Belgium to more than 10 countries in Europe. Corresponding to our geographic expansion, we have also become more diversified in the endmarkets we serve, primarily through our acquisitions in recent years, which provide us with staffing capabilities in additional areas such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, life sciences, government and public administration and technology. As of September 30, 2022, we had 72,296 job candidates at work and approximately 40,858 productive people at work (meaning the number of our job candidates adjusted to reflect a 38 hour per week workweek) and 4,734 in-house full-time equivalent employees. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we had 31,456 unique clients, our Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue was €2,770.0 million and our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA was €330.5 million. Our engineering and consulting segment represents 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. This segment supplies staffing of highly-skilled professionals, such as engineering consultants and financial and insurance specialists, to fill specialized roles in a variety of end-markets, such as financial, industrial, logistics, infrastructure, public administration and construction, and, more recently, fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors such as energy, telecommunications, pharmaceuticals and technology. This segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals, Redmore, GRITT, Cohedron and SOLCOM Powerhouses and has the broadest geographic footprint, with its primary operations in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. The engineering and consulting segment assists clients in the search and selection of the right candidate, including for interim management and secondments, and such temporary client assignments generally last for months. The below chart illustrates in blue the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for our engineering and consulting segment. ----- Our specialized talent solutions segment represents 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. This segment supplies specialized staffing of high-demand mid-skilled workers for specialized positions, such as clerical positions, carpenters, nurses and machine engineers, as well as blue-collar workers to companies in certain sectors, including construction, retail, finance, food, healthcare and construction. This segment is comprised of our Accent, Covebo, TIMEPARTNER and TMI Powerhouses, with their primary operations in Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany, as well as branches in countries that form part of their international recruiting networks, which currently operate principally for this segment though we are planning to expand them for our engineering and consulting segment. These international branches provide us with the capability to source foreign candidates to bridge the large gap between the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates, especially as the labor market in our Addressable Markets has tightened over the past few years. The Specialized Talent Solution segment generally delivers job candidates through temporary agencies to clients in a fast and flexible way when they are shorthanded, with duration of job placements typically lasting for weeks, but they could also last hours or months depending on the needs of our clients. The below chart illustrates in pink the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for our Specialized Talent Solution segment. We serve as an intermediary between job candidates and their ultimate employer by matching up candidates that are looking to find a job, gain experience or find variety or flexibility with our clients that are looking for specialist skills, flexible employee arrangements, time and cost efficiencies or to cover peaks or sourcing for particular projects. We source and screen candidates, provide candidate matching services and present candidates to the client. We also assist with the hiring of the candidates by customers, client and candidate retention, provide timesheet, invoicing and payroll services, and regularly follow up with clients. We aim to help our clients at all stages of the recruiting process to relieve their management from the burden of having to seek appropriate job candidates for available positions. To ensure that we are able to tap into skilled workforces, we offer career coaching to job candidates in order to help them find career paths that align with their professional goals, and we provide in-house training to equip them to match the job profiles in which they are interested or that are scarce in the market to increase job candidates’ employability. We also offer support to foreign job candidates, including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance. We enter into employment contracts with the candidates and pay their salaries. We enter into placement contracts with our clients and bill our clients for our services. Our bill-pay spread is a key driver of our profitability and supports our industry-leading gross margins. We maximize bill-pay spread as a result of candidate scarcity, our niche focus, our SME and local customer focus, our premium service offering, our excellence in marketing candidates to jobs and non-solicitation or minimum fee/period protection for candidates in respect of clients. We have strong pricing power driven by contractual dynamics that ensure pass-through of salary increases. Our specialized talent solutions segment benefits from contractual dynamics which allow for an automatic pass-through to clients of price increases, and our business model also allows for limited bench risk because staffing contracts are back-to-back. In our ----- engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with our clients, and we effectively manage to keep our bench time low by matching confirmed upcoming client assignments to candidates. The business model of these two segments has enabled us to establish a track record of margin stability even during challenging economic conditions such as the Covid-19 pandemic and in the inflationary environment in 2022. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we generated 27.6%, 39.8%, 26.0% and 5.5% of our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France,_ respectively. We have branches in the countries where we source job candidates, including Poland, Romania, Spain, Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal. As of September 30, 2022, we had a network of 742 branches and 18 recruitment offices. To complement our physical network of branches and reach new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies, including our SWOP application, our SWOP Recruiter application and our NOWJOBS platform. We have increased our focus on developing digital support growth initiatives for our primary operations to enable us to reach additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner. We support businesses by providing flexible staffing solutions that are used throughout all stages of the economic cycle, resulting in our resilience during economic downturns. While the economy is strong, the job market tightens meaning that our clients need help sourcing candidates. As markets soften, companies typically shift to a more temporary workforce and need staffing solutions and flexibility. When markets reach the bottom of the cycle, temporary staffing suffers but then is characterized by a quick recovery as temporary employment tends to recover faster than permanent employment. For example, during the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, our business recovered from the early losses in approximately three to six weeks. We also have a highly variable cost base and the ability to pass on wage inflation, which supports the stability of our gross margins. For example, our Like-for-Like Revenue growth (based on the December 31, 2021 perimeter) for 2019, 2020 and 2021 fluctuated significantly due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and were 2%, (9)% and 19%, respectively, but we were able to maintain a gross margin of approximately 28% throughout this period. Flexible staffing solutions proved instrumental in the global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, resulting in a full recovery of our sales during the year ended December 31, 2021. During the Covid-19 pandemic, the retail, food retail and hospitality sectors were severely impacted across all our key markets due to lockdowns and other restrictive measures, which led to a significant reduction in our staffing activities in these sectors. Certain sectors, such as logistics and education, however, proved to be less sensitive to the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic, and clients in these sectors continued to seek our services, particularly for high-skilled, specialized roles. In addition, demand for staffing services from municipalities and government agencies during the Covid-19 pandemic increased due to, among other developments, work related to the administration of government support measures, which we were able to capitalize on given our specialization in this end-market provided by the Cohedron Powerhouse in our engineering and consulting segment. We were founded in 1995 by Philip Cracco and Conny Vandendriessche along with a financial sponsor as a Belgium-based recruiting firm. Originally called Accent, we changed our name to House of HR in 2012. Over the course of 2012 to 2014, Naxicap, a French private equity firm, acquired a majority stake in our business, and we have expanded significantly to become a leading provider of specialized HR solutions in multiple European markets. On November 3, 2022, Bain Capital acquired a majority stake in the Group, with Naxicap, Conny Vandendriessche and management maintaining stakes. See “The _Transactions.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions, Disposals and the Comparability of our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: During the periods under review, our growth and expansion has accelerated through platform acquisitions, such as those of Cohedron B.V. (“Cohedron”) in 2021 and TMI and SOLCOM in the first quarter of 2022, which became new Powerhouses of our Group, as well as bolt-on acquisitions, which ----- we refer to as Boutiques, that strengthen or complement the position of our Powerhouses and contribute to our international recruiting network. Our M&A capital expenditure were €39.4 million, €16.6 million and €190.8 million for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, and was €303.5 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Below is a timetable of the acquisition activity undertaken by our Group which has impacted our consolidation perimeter since January 1, 2019 and through September 30, 2022: - On April 2, 2019, we acquired a majority stake in the Pharmacos Group (“Pharmacos”), a French project sourcing and staffing company in the pharmaceutical and bio-engineering industry. Pharmacos operates as part of our Abylsen Powerhouse. - On April 3, 2019, we acquired Mykelson Holding SAS (“Mykelson”), a French engineering company providing support and management consulting services in four areas: strategy, digital transformation, project management and agile transformation. Mykelson operates as part of our Abylsen Powerhouse. - On October 21, 2019, we acquired Eurojob International Holding B.V (“Eurojob”), a Dutch company specialized in staffing for food retail, logistics and production. Eurojob operates as part of our Covebo Powerhouse. - On October 24, 2019, we acquired Etudes de Travaux d’Armor (“ETA”), a French consulting and project management company specialized in high-end engineering and serving mainly telecommunications and utility companies. - On January 23, 2020, we acquired TechMatch B.V (“TechMatch”), a Dutch engineering staffing specialist focused on mechanical, process and electrical engineering. TechMatch operates as part of our Continu Professionals Powerhouse. - On May 19, 2020, we acquired a majority stake in Book’u (in which we previously had a minority stake), a Belgian company that offers online human resources planning and administration tools. This investment enabled us to further expand our portfolio of digital solutions. - On January 15, 2021, we acquired Solyne, a Dutch staffing specialist that predominantly focused on placing white-collar technical professionals for its clients via secondment, freelance arrangement, subcontracting and other temporary staffing services. Solyne operates as part of our Continu Professionals Powerhouse. - On January 26, 2021, we acquired 60% of the shares in Greenworking, a French consultancy firm that primarily provides consulting services to French blue-chip companies in the field of teleworking, work-life balance, leadership, digital change and social responsibility. Greenworking operates as part of our Abylsen Powerhouse. In June 2022, Abylsen acquired 35.1% additional shares in Greenworking for a consideration of €9.8 million and we currently hold 95.1% of the shares in Greenworking, with Greenworking’s management retaining a minority stake. - On June 15, 2021, we acquired a majority stake in avanti GmbH (“avanti”), a German company specializing in a wide array of healthcare staffing solutions all over Germany. avanti operates as a Boutique of our TIMEPARTNER Powerhouse. - On July 20, 2021, we acquired Cohedron, a Dutch group consisting of several specialties and operating under various brand names, including Wyzer, Future Communication, Human Capital Group, Argonaut, Zorg-Lokaal, Plangroep and Plangroep Financial Services. Cohedron primarily advises public authorities and municipalities and supports them through offering services that include the outsourcing of finance functions (such as debt counselling, budget ----- management and administration), the secondment of highly skilled professionals and providing customized staffing solution consultancy services. Cohedron is currently a Powerhouse in our engineering and consulting segment. - On August 3, 2021, we acquired Vanberkel Professionals B.V. (“Vanberkel Professionals”), a Dutch company offering specialist financial services, such as audit, controlling, consulting and financial accounting, with a focus in the central government, local authorities, housing cooperatives, care and education sectors. Vanberkel Professionals operates as part of our Cohedron Powerhouse. - On September 14, 2021, we acquired Prio Bewindvoering in an asset deal, a Dutch company offering assistance in budgeting issues through guardianship. The assets of Prio Bewindvoering have been integrated into our Cohedron Powerhouse. - On November 12, 2021, we acquired Bureau Brug, a Dutch company that offers HR management solutions, including recruiting, selecting and training highly skilled temporary professionals, in various domains in the public sector. Bureau Brug operates as part of our Cohedron Powerhouse. - On November 16, 2021, we acquired Multi Engineering in an asset deal, a Dutch company active in secondment and project-based deployment of experts in the construction and infrastructure business. The assets of Multi Engineering have been integrated into our Continu Professionals Powerhouse. - On January 1, 2022 we acquired Sociaal.nl in an asset deal, a Dutch company active in executing, supporting and assisting in debt counselling and administration projects. The assets of Sociaal.nl have been integrated into our Cohedron Powerhouse. - On January 28, 2022, we acquired SOLCOM, a German leading IT service provider that specializes in recruiting high-skilled professionals in the IT and engineering sectors. SOLCOM is currently a Powerhouse in our engineering and consulting segment. - On February 24, 2022, we acquired Atrium, a training center that provides training to increase safety at work. Atrium operates as part of our Accent Powerhouse. - On March 3, 2022, we acquired TMI, one of the largest HR service providers for the healthcare sector in the Netherlands. TMI specializes in the recruitment of staff for hospitals, public care institutions, nursing homes and other healthcare facilities domestically and internationally. TMI also recruits for temporary staff and other flexible job arrangements. The candidates that TMI works with include doctors, nurses, psychologists and pharmacists. TMI is currently a Powerhouse in our specialized talent solutions segment. - On April 8, 2022, we acquired BE-Consult, a Belgian provider of environmental consulting and training services to the construction, chemical, logistics and asbestos sectors. BE-Consult operates as part of our Accent Powerhouse. - On April 25, 2022, we acquired Agathos in an asset deal, a Dutch company active in traineeships and high potential programs for municipalities and other governments in the Netherlands. The assets of Agathos have been integrated into our Cohedron Powerhouse. - On June 1, 2022, we acquired Vijverberg, a Dutch legal staffing company that provides legal advisory services to clients in the public sector and related areas in the Netherlands. Vijverberg will be added to the Cohedron Powerhouse. - On June 3, 2022, we acquired Sira Consulting, a Dutch consultancy firm specialized in providing consulting services to authorities in the Netherlands on governmental policy, such as ----- calculating the cost of promulgating new legislation. Sira Consulting will be added to the Cohedron Powerhouse. - On July 4, 2022, we acquired Ambulance Zorg+ in an asset deal to supplement the TMI Powerhouse. Ambulance Zorg+ is a Dutch provider of ambulance care personnel. - On July 5, 2022, we acquired Bis People, a Dutch company specialized in flexible employment, secondment of skilled workers, mediation for self-employed workers and recruitment of personnel for building construction and infrastructure operations. Bis People will be added to the Covebo Powerhouse. - On July 28, 2022, we acquired StaffMe, a French digital platform focusing on student employment and which is primarily active in the retail, health, event and hospitality sectors, supplementing our digital NOWJOBS offering. Through this acquisition, we also acquired the other companies of the StaffMe group, including the StaffMe Academy, the first training organization for young entrepreneurs, and the Accelerator, a program of integration through self-employment for those who are far from employment. - On July 28, 2022, we completed the acquisition of LD Personalvermittlung, a German staffing agency with a focus on the placements of physicians to clinics or hospitals to ensure care coverage and absorb peak workloads at these institutions. It currently has a strong geographic focus on the southern German market. LD Personalvermittlung will further reinforce our presence in the healthcare industry and is complementary to avanti, which focuses on the placement of nurses, by operating under a new Powerhouse under our specialized talent solutions segment, House of Care Talents Germany. - On August 25, 2022, we completed the acquisition of FID Service Groep, a Dutch company active in staffing employees in green waste management and providing relevant training to employees, such as the operation of cranes and other machines. FID Service Groep will be added to the Covebo Powerhouse. Below is a timetable of the acquisition activity not included in our consolidation perimeter through September 30, 2022 and undertaken by our Group after September 30, 2022 until the date of this Offering Memorandum: - On October 7, 2022, we acquired Agium, a Dutch company specialized in deploying skilled professionals to support companies in their day-to-day finance and control processes and implementation of structure changes. Agium is expected to operate under our Redmore Powerhouse. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Agium generated revenue and EBITDA of €20.3 million and €2.9 million, respectively, and has an enterprise value of €19.5 million, based on our due diligence in respect of the target. - On October 25, 2022, we signed the Put Option Agreement to acquire the French company ABMI, a consulting and engineering services group operating mainly in three engineering segments: (i) product design and industrialization, (ii) industrial processes and (iii) industrial facilities (e.g., nuclear and railway infrastructures). The put option may be exercised by the sellers upon completion of the information and consultation of the relevant employee representative bodies to which the offer has been submitted and we are awaiting for written confirmation of approval. The acquisition is expected to be completed in December 2022, subject to the put option being exercised by the sellers, regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions. Following the acquisition of ABMI, we expect to combine ABMI with Abylsen in order to create a new Powerhouse, ABY Engineering. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, ABMI generated revenue and EBITDA of approximately €57.0 million and approximately €8.2 million, respectively, and has an enterprise value of approximately €60.0 million, based on our due diligence in respect of the target. ----- - On November 14, 2022, we acquired Job Raccoon in an asset deal to supplement our TIMEPARTNER Powerhouse. Job Raccoon is a German recruitment agency using an internetbased recruitment platform specializing in the recruitment of blue-collar workers. At completion, there was an upfront payment for this acquisition in an amount of €0.3 million. In addition, the purchase agreement includes an earn-out in an amount not to exceed €0.5 million in total, which may become payable if certain condition precedents are reached. Additionally, in the period under review the Group completed one material disposal: - On June 23, 2020, we entered into a share and receivable transfer agreement to sell GRITT Projects as its business model was not aligned with the Group’s overall strategy and was not delivering the expected performance. The Group, via its subsidiaries GRITT NV and LogiTechnic NV held 100% of the shares in GRITT Projects NV. The sale of GRITT Projects NV entailed (i) a capital increase done by GRITT NV and Logi-Technic NV of €3.2 million; (ii) the sale of the shares held by GRITT NV and Logi-Technic NV, against EUR 1 closing price; and (iii) the price supplement of €0.4 million. As a result, a total loss of €19.6 million was recorded in the year ended December 31, 2020. See note 3.1 to each of our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for further information. We also have a number of other potential targets in our pipeline for 2022: we have submitted one nonbinding offer, we are currently reviewing the investment memorandum for one target and we have made non-committal contact for several other targets. We have also lost out on nine potential acquisition opportunities in 2022. These offers are in line with our strategy to further invest in niche staffing, focus on digital and expand also in the engineering and consulting segment. The offers are in line with past acquisitions in terms of size and profitability. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Acquisitions.” Our acquisitions have resulted in increased revenue and increased geographical coverage, as well as improved diversification of our services and the number of clients and end-markets that we serve. On account of the number of acquisitions that we have undertaken and intend to continue to undertake, our results of operations from period to period may not be comparable. Acquisitions, which include the acquisition of majority stakes in equity investments or joint ventures that were previously not accounted for as part of our consolidation perimeter, affect our results of operations on inclusion in our consolidation perimeter. For example, during the year ended December 31, 2019, we accounted for Book’u as an associate; however, on May 19, 2020, we acquired a majority stake in Book’u, and as a result, a full consolidation has been recorded for Book’u in the year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, as acquired businesses are consolidated from the date of their acquisition, the full impact of an acquisition is only reflected in our consolidated income statement and statement of cash flows in the subsequent financial year. Our cost of services, selling expenses and other general and administrative expenses have typically increased in proportion to the size of the acquisitions we have undertaken. Certain acquisitions, however, have created opportunities for margin improvements, particularly where such acquisitions have shifted the services mix we offer from more general to more specialized, or where such acquisitions have been in our engineering and consulting services segment, since more specialized job candidates are typically in greater demand and can thus result in our Group having greater pricing power when placing job candidates. Because of the number of acquisitions we have undertaken and the nature of the businesses we acquire, we carry a significant amount of goodwill on our balance sheet. As of September 30, 2022, goodwill represented €1.2 billion or 49.5% of our total assets. Our goodwill is reduced by any accumulated impairment losses. Goodwill is not amortized but it is tested for impairment annually, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate that it might be impaired. If an impairment charge were made, we may record significant charges in our income statement under IFRS. For ----- example, we performed an impairment test during the second quarter of 2022 given the rising interest rate in the current market, which we consider to be an impairment indicator. Goodwill impairment in relation to the GRITT Powerhouse was identified, as the recoverable amount was €40.9 million compared to the carrying value of €54.2 million. We performed another impairment test during the third quarter of 2022 due to further increases in interest rates, and identified no additional impairments. We therefore recorded a goodwill impairment of €13.3 million for the nine months ending September 30, 2022, as we consider this change to have a long-term impact. Our margin based on current goodwill impairment tests appears to be sufficient to avoid any material impairment risk in the near future. We have historically financed acquisitions through a combination of borrowings, equity and excess cash generated within the Group. We structure our acquisitions to include, from time to time, contingent and deferred considerations that are included in the cost of the business combination at the fair value on the date of the acquisitions. Apart from a number of earn-outs for which the remaining price to be paid by us to sellers is currently estimated to be approximately €19.9 million if conditions precedent are reached, we do not have any material financial or legal claims under the stock purchase agreements for the acquisitions during the period under review. If the ABMI acquisition closes, an additional estimated earn-out of €10.0 million may become payable if certain conditions precedents are reached. In addition, under ABMI’s Put Option Agreement, we may be required to make certain payments up to an amount of approximately €5.8 million if certain events occur, such as if we receive certain credits from the French authorities. We expect to continue to pursue smaller, margin-accretive, complementary bolt-on acquisitions, which will become our Boutiques following the acquisitions, mainly in our existing markets, and we also occasionally consider larger acquisitions that are otherwise consistent with our investment criteria. We will continue to focus on acquisitions of highly specialized businesses (such as IT, legal and finance), business focusing on bottleneck jobs and engineering and consulting services, as well as new geographic. We are also targeting, in particular, certain new end-markets such as healthcare and pharmaceuticals and new geographic markets such as the Nordic countries and other countries, such as Austria and Switzerland. For further discussion regarding our acquisitions strategy, please refer to “Business—Our Strategies—Continue to target accretive acquisition opportunities to achieve _European leadership.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: Changes in Segment Reporting Beginning in 2021
Subsubsection Text: We had historically structured our business across three segments: engineering and consulting, specialized staffing and general staffing. In the first quarter of 2021, we integrated our legacy specialized staffing and general staffing segments into the current specialized talent solutions segment, and we have been presenting our results in two segments since then to reflect the integration. This change in segment reporting better reflects our strategy towards becoming further specialized in the human resources solutions market, as well as allows us to more clearly present our portfolio of services to our client base. Our financial information disclosed in this Offering Memorandum is presented under this new dual segment structure for the periods under review. Our financial information for the specialized talent solutions segment as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 represent the sum of the results of the legacy specialized staffing and general staffing segments. As a result, such information may not be directly comparable with the information included in our 2020 Financial Statements. See note 6 to our 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: Our Interim Results Fluctuate as a result of Seasonality in our Business
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue is subject to seasonal fluctuations in many of the end-markets in which we operate. We have in the past experienced, and expect in the future to experience, fluctuations in our results of operations due to seasonal demand in our current end-markets. Seasonality means that our results vary ----- from quarter to quarter, and therefore the results of one quarter may not be indicative of results for the full year. Seasonality varies depending on a number of different factors and can impact our two staffing segments differently. The underlying end-markets we serve are subject to various drivers that impact overall end-market demand and therefore demand from our clients for staffing. For example, the construction end-market may experience inclement weather on a worksite, which can decrease demand for our job candidates. As a result of the mix of services we provide, seasonal work can also cause peaks in demand during a specific period, such as around harvest time in the food production sector or around holiday periods, such as the Christmas holidays, Easter and summer holidays, especially for the businesses that are active in the event, hospitality and food sectors. Historically as a general matter, our revenue fluctuates, with higher levels of revenue typically generated in the second quarter of the year, then decreases during the summer holidays and increases again in the second half of the year beginning just after the summer holidays, which then lasts for a sustained period before decreasing again in December due to Christmas holidays. Due to this seasonality effect, we do not expect our Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements to be reflective of the results we anticipate for the full year to which they apply. The 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements were additionally impacted by Covid-19, which impacted the traditional seasonality patterns experienced by the Group with respect to revenue and working capital (with a number of governments granting postponements to certain tax or other expenses and providing grants for certain unemployment support that temporarily decreased the Group’s working capital needs) compared to previous years, though the working capital dynamics of our business are such we are largely able to match payables with receivables for job candidates at work at SMEs, which provides us with some counter cyclicality. Moreover, we also experience seasonality with regard to our working capital requirements. We generally experience larger working capital requirements in the first half of the year due to increased holiday pay, bonus pay and tax payments. While our working capital requirements are generally lower in the second half of the year, our working capital requirements also experience an increase at the end of the year for end-of year bonuses and holiday pay, particularly as certain of our businesses institute mandatory holidays at the end of the year. For additional information see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our _interim results fluctuate as a result of seasonality in our business.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Concomitant with its global and market-wide impact, Covid-19 and its subsequent new variants negatively affected our business, results of operations and financial condition, particularly in 2020. Our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020, decreased by 8.2% as compared to that for the year ended December 31, 2019. See “Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations— Impact of Covid_19 and our Response” for further details on this impact. As a result, the comparability of our financial statements as of and for the year ended December 30, 2020 when compared to future periods may be more limited.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The Acquisition was completed on November 3, 2022. See “Summary—The Transactions.” Consequently, our consolidated financial information following the Transactions will not be fully comparable with our historical consolidated financial information due to, among other things, (i) the application of purchase accounting from the date of acquisition in connection with the Acquisition, (ii) changes to depreciation and amortization expenses, among other things, that may result from the purchase accounting of the Acquisition, (iii) additional interest expense associated with the financing of the Transactions (after taking into account the refinancing of certain of our existing debt), (iv) the acquisition by French Bidco of 70.8% of the share capital of Nowjobs France II SAS from a subsidiary of House of HR and 100% of the share capital of ABY Engineering SAS, and the acquisition by ABY Engineering SAS of 99.97% of the share capital of NewCo Abylsen SAS from a subsidiary of House of HR and (v) changes to the level of consolidation of our results in the future. See “Presentation of ----- _Financial and Other Information—Historical Financial Information—Comparability of the Financial Statements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Economic and trading conditions in the countries in which we operate, or which we plan to enter, have impacted our business in the past and will likely impact our business going forward in various ways. While our business has historically generally been able to mitigate the fluctuations of the business cycle due to a flexible cost structure, economic downturns can lead to a decrease in demand for our services. Similarly, growth in national and international economies (i.e., GDP growth), particularly in the sectors in which we specialize, can lead to increased demand for our services. Among our two business segments, specialized talent solutions has historically, due to the temporary and flexible staffing element in this segment, been more sensitive to economic fluctuations, which has led to decreases in demand for such services in connection with economic downturns, but has often exhibited an early resurgence after a recession as companies often reach for this resource as they invest in the growth of their operations. Conversely, our engineering and consulting segment has historically been more “defensive,” and as a result may show the effects of economic fluctuations less intensely and may take longer after any economic downturn to recover. We have observed this same pattern in both 2020 and 2021, as the temporary and flexible staffing activities of the specialized talent segment had by the end of 2020 returned to levels comparable to, and in 2021 surpassed, those seen in 2019, as measured by weekly productive job candidates, outpacing the activity level of that for the engineering and consulting segment during the same period. For most of our Boutiques, “productive job candidates” are defined as job candidates working at the customer premises, expressed in full-time equivalents for the time they are on client assignments. The Covid-19 pandemic impacted the demand for our staffing services in 2020, and any resurgence of Covid-19 or emergence of new variants or other pandemics could lead to potential future impact. At the same time, there were a number of government initiatives introduced during the Covid-19 pandemic that positively contributed to the Group’s ability to manage cash flows. A number of these measures, however, ended in the course of 2021 or will end in the near future. Historically, following periods of crisis the Group has demonstrated an ability to rebound, in part based on its decentralized structure, allowing for flexible decision-making based on local needs and legislation, including revisions to incentive-based structures to adapt to the changing environment. Management believes that the Group’s strong geographical, segment and sector diversification has allowed it to smooth the impact and recovery across the business as demonstrated by the positive EBITDA it recorded every month throughout the Covid-19 crisis. Economic activities in our primary geographic markets normalized and recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels in 2021 and this trend was carried into 2022. Despite the outbreak of the new strain of Covid-19 virus Omicron in the last weeks of 2021 and at the beginning of 2022, we are recording a higher number of productive job candidates at work each of the weeks in 2022 to date as compared to 2019, 2020 and 2021. The outbreak of the war in Ukraine in February 2022 has caused an immediate impact on global economic conditions, and the uncertain resolution of this conflict could result in protracted and severe damage to the global economy. Although we do not have direct economic activities in Russia and Ukraine, it is difficult to predict the scope and extent of any potential impacts the war could have on our operations, especially given we source candidates from Eastern Europe. The war has also caused supply shortage of, and therefore increased prices of, gas, energy and other raw materials, further disrupted the global supply chain, which had already been impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, and added to inflation, all of which are significantly impacting many companies, industries and sectors directly and indirectly, resulting in us incurring increased operating costs and our clients reconsidering ----- their recruitment efforts of domestic and foreign talents, which may, in turn, impact our results of operations. Some customers, mainly those in Germany, have ended their requests for flexible staffing solutions due to the shortage of goods or the challenges of exporting goods to Ukraine and Russia. At the same time, the labor cost inflation as a result of the overall inflation is expected to lead to higher costs of labor in relation to both our in-house employees and our people at work, which in turn will lead to an increase in the Group’s operating costs, especially in Belgium where labor cost inflation is linked to consumer price index increases. Such impact is not as significant to our specialized talent solutions segment, as the cost of people at work within this segment can be passed through almost immediately to the majority of our clients; however, this does not always apply to our engineering and consulting segment as the contracts we enter into with our clients in this segment do not typically include automatic wage pass-through provisions. Notwithstanding the above, we are generally able to pass through the increased costs due to labor shortage and inflation to our clients. In addition to these general trends, our results of operations have been impacted and we expect will continue to be impacted by certain other key macroeconomic conditions, such as the changing demographic mix as the number of people retiring outpaces the number of people entering the labor force, unemployment rates and staffing penetration, in the geographic markets in which we operate. Low unemployment rates often indicate a shortage of available workers in an economy, which can increase the demand for our job candidates, whom we often recruit from other countries and increasingly through our digital initiatives in an effort to establish a steady inflow. Furthermore, increases in staffing penetration can indicate a greater prevalence or acceptance of temporary staffing in an economy, which increases the market for our services. We generally operate in geographic markets that are characterized by high average salaries, low unemployment and which are well developed and mature in the temporary staffing and consulting fields. As a result of these trends, the demand for our services has increased significantly over the last decade. For further information relating to the outlook for the staffing solutions industry in our main geographical markets, see “Industry and Market Data.” Macroeconomic trends within each of our primary markets also contribute to the performance of our operations in each of these countries: _Belgium_ Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in Belgium was 2.1%, (5.7)% and 6.2% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Belgium has also continued to experience a tightening in the labor market as the population ages and there are fewer local workers to take the place of retirees. Furthermore, Belgium has also been experiencing high employment rates due to employment outgrowing the active population. Unemployment in Belgium has gone from 7.5% in 2007 to 6.4% in 2021, according to data from the World Bank. Staffing penetration has also increased in response to this tightening of the labor market and decrease in unemployment. In the near term, while growth saturation of employment will likely slow our growth in Belgium in the private sector, the opening of certain public sector opportunities may offset this slowdown to a certain degree. Management believes that the impact of potential client default is limited. As an illustration, the historical rate of insolvencies (as a percentage of company stock) in Belgium from 2007 to 2016, based on third party market data, has ranged between 0.5% to a maximum of 2.2% for small and medium sized firms and below 0.5% for larger firms with over 250 employees, including during the financial crisis of 2008-2009. Accordingly, bad debt provisions as a percentage of sales in Accent have ranged steadily between 0% to 0.3% of sales, on an LTM basis, from 2017 through September 30, 2022. _The Netherlands_ Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth was 2.0%, (3.8)% and 5.0% in 2019, 2020 and 2021 respectively, in the Netherlands. As is the case elsewhere, GDP growth in the ----- Netherlands affects us primarily through its effect on the end-markets in which our clients operate. Our engineering and consulting and specialized staffing segments in the Netherlands are affected by growth in the construction and engineering markets, which in turn are driven by overall domestic economic growth. Long-term demographic and economic trends are also driving a demand for construction workers. After a downturn from 2009 until 2012, the Dutch construction end-market has been growing significantly due in part to general economic resurgence, low interest rates, as well an increase in environmentally-focused project or larger infrastructure projects. These trends contribute to demand for job candidates with specialties and skills that operate in the construction end-market. The Netherlands also has a number of jobs that are driven by regulatory developments in addition to GDP fluctuations. For example, demand for job candidates in the financial services sector is impacted by the growth in financial regulation. This impacts demand for our services, due to the fact that, within our engineering and consulting segment, our Powerhouse Redmore provides job candidates with technical, specialized skills to the financial sector. This also happens in the public and government sector, an end-market that our Powerhouse Cohedron addresses. The Netherlands, similarly to Belgium, has historically had low unemployment rates which impacts our business positively. Between 2007 and 2014, the unemployment rate in the Netherlands rose from 4.2% to 7.4%, but then decreased to 4.0% in 2021 (according to data from the World Bank). This low unemployment rate has led to fewer local individuals going into the strenuous working conditions of the logistics workforce, which has supported demand for our job candidates, including our foreign job candidates, who have experience in this sector and can meet demand for such jobs. _Germany_ Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in Germany was 1.1%, (4.6)% and 2.9% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. In Germany, our general staffing activity is GDPsensitive and exposes us more directly to fluctuations in GDP and economic change. As GDP slows, market value grows at a slower pace and the number of hours worked by an individual decreases. Lowskilled, mainly blue-collar workers are, however, in structural shortage in Germany, which provides opportunities for our services. Unemployment in Germany between 2007 and 2021 fell from 8.7% to 3.5% (according to data from the World Bank). Companies are, therefore, expected to continue to address staff shortages through temporary staffing. Moreover, we believe that generally lower-skilled workers do not travel as much, which can lead to significantly localized shortages in demand. Some companies, including ours, overcome this barrier through sourcing in Eastern Europe where lower skilled workers are willing to travel. Decreasing unemployment and shortages of low-skilled blue-collar workers has driven an increased reliance on temp workers leading to an increase in demand for our services. Finally, the staffing industry specifically was impacted by certain German regulatory reforms, including the Act on Staffing (Arbeitnehmerüberlassungsgesetz) (“AÜG”), which has been substantially amended over the years, most recently in 2017. The focus of the 2017 amendment was to strengthen permanent employment; as a result, a maximum period for temporary staffing has been introduced and formal requirements have been tightened up as has the equal pay principle. Providing staffing services in the construction industry in Germany is also generally prohibited by law, although it is possible for a staffing solutions provider who is active in the construction industry to obtain a specific permit. Additionally, beginning in 2021 the German government has generally forbidden staffing companies to work in the meat industry as a result of the sanitary crisis in 2020. See “—Changes in regulation— _Temporary Employment Regulations.” France_ Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in France was 1.8%, (7.9)% and 7.0% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. In France, we only provide engineering consulting ----- under our engineering and consulting segment, which has historically been insulated to a significant degree from GDP fluctuations. The unemployment rate in France has increased from 7.7% to 8.1% between 2007 and 2021 (according to data from the World Bank), which is higher than the other countries in which we work. As we operate in a specialized sector in France, the structurally high unemployment in France, however, has not impacted demand for our services in a material manner, nor do we expect it to do so in the future. _Brexit_ On January 1, 2021, the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement entered into force provisionally and entered into force on May 1, 2021. Despite the implementation of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, there remains significant uncertainty as to how the agreement will affect relations between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Significant political and economic uncertainty remains about whether the terms of the relationship will differ materially in practice from the terms before withdrawal. Lack of clarity about future laws and regulations in the United Kingdom as the United Kingdom determines which European Union laws to replace or replicate could depress economic activity and restrict our access to capital. The economic outlook could be further adversely affected by: (i) the risk arising from changes in laws and regulations in the U.K.; (ii) the risk that movements in the pound sterling exchange rates related to Brexit could damage competitiveness or profitability; (iii) the risk that goods moving between the U.K. and any member of the EU will be subject to duties and tariffs; and (iv) the risk that goods moving between the U.K. and any member of the EU will be subject to additional inspections and documentation checks, leading to possible delays at ports of entry and departure. As the U.K. represents a key export market for several of the countries in which we operate, particularly Belgium and the Netherlands, adverse trade terms between the U.K. and the countries in which we operate could have an adverse effect on the economies of these countries, which could by extension adversely affect our business. Furthermore, Brexit has limited the ability of individuals from various foreign countries to work in the U.K., which increased the supply of job candidates in several of the countries in which we operate, but we believe that this trend has not significantly impacted our Gross Margin. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our results of operations could be _materially adversely affected by volatile or uncertain economic conditions.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: While the markets in which we operate tend to be fairly stable from a legal and regulatory perspective, from time to time there are changes that may impact the performance of our business. Our industry is extensively regulated by regulatory authorities in each of the countries in which we operate and at an EU level. These regulations impact how we structure our employment agreements with job candidates and our service agreements with clients. See “Regulation.” During the period under review, certain changes in the regulatory frameworks, particularly the new legislations on payroll that took effect in the Netherlands from January 1, 2020 which, among other things, mandated that payroll employees are entitled to all terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions, impacted our results of operations. _Temporary Employment Regulation_ Regulations around temporary employment can impact the clients and opportunities that are available to us. For example, as from the 2017 to 2018 period, the Belgian region of Flanders and the Belgian federal government authorized temporary employment in the public sector for periods of up to twelve months, which has provided additional opportunities to place temporary employees within these sectors. While this practice is still not permitted in the Belgian region of Wallonia, if in the future and to the ----- extent that this region adopts a similar policy, it could further increase our ability to provide our services in that region. Moreover, regulations can affect the duration of our services. In Germany, since the last reform of the AÜG in April 2017, the assignment period of temporary workers was limited to 18 months (with exceptions) after which the employee either needs to be let go from the company where they were working or accepted on to the general payroll of that company. As a result, as our job candidates approach the end of their assignment period they will either need to be replaced, which can be difficult during times of scarcity of qualified job candidates, or are taken over by the client resulting in lower volumes for us. Furthermore, wages and benefits of temporary workers are aligned to those of the employees of the company after nine months of uninterrupted assignment (through the “EqualPay” mechanism), but must be paid by the staffing solutions provider, which increases the administrative burden on us. In addition, beginning in 2021 the German government has generally forbidden staffing companies to work in the meat industry as a result of the sanitary crisis in 2020. In the Netherlands, there have been low-wage benefits regulations (“LIV”) which create subsidies for the employment of low-wage workers since January 2017. This law is aimed at incentivizing employers to hire employees who have a vulnerable position in the labor market. A review of these incentives, however, resulted in cuts to the maximum compensation to the normal LIV in 2020, which resulted in lower subsidies obtained in 2020 as compared to prior years, especially in Covebo, despite comparable turnover. In November 2022, this law was further revised and it was decided that, only for 2022, the LIV benefit for 2022 will be increased retroactively, while the LIV benefit for 2023 will be remain at the normal level and the LIV benefit for 2024 will be reduced. If the planned pension reform goes ahead in 2025, the LIV will end in 2024. Moreover, under the Wet Aanpak Schijnconstructies (“WAS”) regulation, cost related to workers, can be withheld from workers’ wages only if the wage remains above net minimum wage (since January 2016). However, deductions are still allowed below minimum wage for pension and healthcare insurance. All other deductions are not allowed if the net salary then becomes below minimum wage. For these non-deducted costs, we send invoices to the workers. If workers do not pay their invoices and return to their country of origin, we are left with the costs. This regulation has no impact for the clients. Significant Dutch law changes came into effect with respect to temporary agency work and payrolling, among others. From January 1, 2020, the Balanced Labor Market Act (Wet Arbeidsmarkt in balans) (“WAB”) came into effect. For example, there will be increased social security charges for temporary staffing agencies in their capacity as employer. Furthermore, payroll employees will be entitled to all terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions. These regulations came into effect in 2020 and our cost of services has increased, but simultaneously also our sales prices increased. We currently see that we have been able to pass on the majority of these increases in costs to our clients through higher fees charged for our services. Furthermore, new legislation has come into effect requiring employment housing to remain available for four weeks following the end of employment of foreign workers. Currently, the majority of foreign workers leave employment housing immediately following the end of their employment, or during the weekend thereafter. Foreign workers that do remain in employment housing are required to pay weekly rent, and we send them weekly invoices. There is increasing attention in the Netherlands on separation between employment providers and housing providers. While this separation is not currently legally required, our Covebo Powerhouse has already implemented relevant measures to address it. We expect a contractual separation will be enforced in the future; however, there is currently no clear indication as to the extent of what the required separation will be, and we cannot be certain at this time whether a complete separation, or a full ban on the provision of housing to temporary workers by employment agencies, will be legally required in the future. For a further discussion of the regulatory framework in which we conduct our business in our principal geographic end-markets, see “Regulation.” ----- _Tax Regulation_ Changes in tax law can impact our current and future tax liabilities, and can also lead to reversals of certain deferred tax income balances. For example, the Belgian Corporate Income Tax regime has been modified by the Belgian Government by means of the Corporate Income Tax Reform Act of December 25, 2017 (Official Gazette of December 29, 2017). As a result of the reform, we remeasured our deferred income tax balances. Deferred income tax expected to be reversed in the year to December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2020 has been measured using the effective rate that will apply in Belgium for the period (29.58%). Deferred income tax expected to be reversed beyond December 31, 2021 has been measured with an effective rate of 25%. Further, the Dutch corporate income tax rates and brackets have been modified. As of January 1, 2022, the Netherlands levies Dutch corporate income tax at a rate of 15% with respect to taxable profits up to €395,000 and 25.8% with respect to taxable profits in excess of that amount. _Financial regulation_ While regulations on banking, insurance and the financial industry as a whole only have an indirect material effect on our business, recent regulatory developments in the financial industry between 2016 and 2019, including the updates to the financial supervision amendment Act, the Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products regulation, the Capital Markets Union, the International Financial Reporting Standards, final documents on the Reform of Basel III (“Basel IV”), Customer DD/Know your Customer regulations, the Uniform Calculation Method-Uniform pension calculation, and the new EU Directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision (“IORP II”), have created a heightened need for specialized employees, which can create additional demand for our job candidates who focus on compliance and legal matters in the financial industry. _ESG Regulation_ On April 21, 2021, the European Commission adopted a proposal for the CSRD, which would amend the existing reporting requirements of the Non-Financial Reporting Directive and encourage corporate spending towards sustainable activities across the EU. The European Council approved the CSRD on November 28, 2022 and the application of the regulation is expected to take place in four stages, the first of which will require companies that already fall under the CSRD to complete their first CSRD reporting on the financial year 2024, with expected reporting deadlines in 2025. We expect that we will be required to comply with the CSRD. We cannot guarantee how the CSRD will impact our governance structure and our day-to-day business activities. We have a formalized ESG charter to guide us on achieving our targeted ESG KPIs and complying with relevant ESG regulations. See “Business— _Environmental, Social and Governance” for information on our ESG initiatives._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Organic Growth_ In addition to the sales growth created through the acquisitions discussed above (see “—Factors _Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Acquisitions, Disposals and the Comparability of our Financial Statements”), our sales are impacted by the Organic Growth of our_ business. We measure Organic Growth by analyzing revenue growth between one financial period and the comparable prior period, excluding the impact of acquisitions on revenue as follows: - in respect of revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 (compared against the nine months ended September 30, 2021), we have excluded the impact of acquisitions on revenue by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2021; ----- - in respect of revenue for 2021 (compared against 2020), we have excluded the impact of acquisitions on revenue by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2020; and - in respect of revenue for 2020 (compared against 2019), we have excluded the impact of acquisitions on revenue by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2019 or that divestments have taken place as of January 1, 2019. The key drivers of the Organic Growth of our business are: - increasing our geographic footprint by opening new branches with our “cell division” approach; - continuing our growth in stronghold sectors and niches; - winning new contracts with clients; - expanding our work with existing clients; - sourcing additional job candidates that can fill scarce assignments held by our clients; - increasing candidate sourcing through international recruitment; - digitalization; - expanding into new business lines; and - pricing growth. We seek to minimize the financial risk of new offices by focusing on securing new sales in a geographic region before committing to additional costs of a new office there. Historically, we have successfully hired additional sales employees onto our payroll to win new contracts with clients; our Powerhouse Continu Professionals has notably employed this approach successfully. Furthermore, our business integration in Germany and the expansion of our business through the opening of new branches of our existing Powerhouses in 2022 have accelerated our Organic Growth. When doing bolt-on acquisitions in new but matching sectors, we have successfully expanded these services to existing branches, as proven by Continu Professionals with the acquisition of mténv. Moreover, our Organic Growth is impacted by our ability to improve the utilization of job candidates and reduce our bench time, see “—Gross Margin—Bench time/Utilization,” increasing our sales in time and material contracts over any given period. Our ability to expand our business geographically by opening offices in new locations also functions as an incentive to reward employees who have demonstrated strong results and initiative and would be well-suited to lead new offices. We typically open new offices when we receive a significant number of requests from existing clients or prospective clients to provide services in new locations or when we see increasing demand for our services coming from a specific region. Expansion through opening new offices has positively impacted and is expected to continue to impact our operating profits. _Staffing volume_ The key drivers of staffing volume in any given market are the macro-economic and sector specific growth, and the labor tightness, see “—General economic conditions” discussed above and the regulatory environment, see “—Changes in regulation” above.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: ----- The substantial majority of our service agreements are structured to give us the ability to pass-through wage increases from inflation to customers in both of our segments. See “Business—Our Strengths— _Ability to pass through wage increases to customers, including through automatic contractual mechanisms, and stable margins.”_ In the specialized talent solutions segment, which accounted for 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, price increases are automatically passed through to our clients. For this segment, our contract model is centered on matching the length of our candidate’s employment contract with us to the length of our placement contract with our client, the ultimate employer, in order to limit bench time risk and prevent lag time between inflation of gross salary paid to the candidate and the cost we charge to our clients, which results in an automatic pass-through of any salary increases. Under these types of contracts, the utilization risk of the job candidates in between contracts is reduced. In Germany, temporary workers are, however, required to be on the temporary employment company’s payroll, which creates bench time risk for us with regard to our temporary job candidates in our specialized talent solutions segment. In many cases, bench time is limited, as temporary workers’ contracts can usually be terminated in, on average, two weeks’ notice given during the time of the job candidate’s last assignment, unless we decide to retain them. At the end of our contracts, we renegotiate them, which has historically resulted in an ability to increase our prices in line with wage inflation. Our revenues typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due to our stables margins and ability to pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment. We base our contract pricing on a candidate’s gross salary multiplied by a coefficient factor, with the split typically being transparent to the client. The key pricing drivers for the coefficient factor are the scarcity of candidates and the value of any additional services we offer. Key costs for us include salaries and work accident insurance. At the end of the contract period, typically one week or one month in length, if the salary increases, then we charge the cost of the higher salary to the client. In the specialized talent solutions segment, regulations in Belgium and the Netherlands require that job candidates through our services are paid the same as local or company-sourced workers, while this applies in Germany only after a job candidate has worked for the employer for a certain period of time. The following chart illustrates our revenue per billed hour for the specialized talent solutions segment. Source: Company information, external consultant analysis. Price analysis excludes TMI. In our engineering and consulting segment, which accounted for 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with clients. The contracts are typically time and material contracts, which means we are compensated for the time that our job candidates spend with a client on assignment, and have no obligations for any specific result. Most of our candidates in our engineering and consulting segment are permanently hired by us on employment contracts that typically have three- to six-week notice periods and we have placement contracts with our clients that typically last nine to twelve months, which allows us to effectively manage bench time and match our candidates with the upcoming mandates from clients. In most cases, we plan for salary increases in advance and negotiate rate increases with our clients accordingly. Our pricing model in our engineering and consulting segment centers on charging the client an hourly or ----- daily rate. Our billing rate is typically based on an hourly wage and a mark-up where the split is usually not transparent to clients. Key drivers of the hourly or daily rates are skills, seniority and scarcity of candidates. Our key costs include salary, potentially including a company car. At the end of a placement contract, renewal either entails replacing the candidate with a new or more junior person at a new price or by placing the same candidate, at a more senior level with a higher salary. Margin growth in our engineering and consulting segment is driven by increasing the cost per hour paid and billed. The hourly and daily pricing model for engineering and consulting positions generally produces higher Gross Margins than factor pricing based on the job candidates’ gross salaries. In our engineering and consulting segment, there is a higher risk of bench time than in our specialized talent solutions segment, as a result of our job candidates being on our payroll but not being used on a paid job assignment. As their employer, we are still responsible for their costs even if they are not generating money for our operations. To mitigate the bench time risk, we carefully monitor our job candidates that are our employees with indefinite term contracts and seek to minimize their bench time by lining up assignments to transition to once a current one is complete, or by terminating employment agreements as appropriate should transition to another assignment be not feasible or desirable. The following chart illustrates our revenue per billed hour for the engineering and consulting segment. Source: Company information, external consultant analysis. Price analysis excludes Cohedron. We also perform a limited amount of work under search and selection contracts in both of our business segments through our Accent (through the Ctrl-F brand), Redmore (through the Ctrl-F brand), TIMEPARTNER, Continu Professionals, Covebo, GRITT and TMI Powerhouses. This can be done either by the Powerhouses themselves or through one of their Boutiques. Unlike for other types of contracts, the full amount of the commissions typically remains with us as it is not subject to cost of services or other deductions. In such arrangements, we do not benefit from a share of the on-going revenue during the duration of the employment as we do in other contracts. We also perform certain amount of work placing freelancers. In the case of freelancers, rather than receiving a salary from us, the freelancers submit invoices to us for the services they have provided to the relevant client. Freelancers produce smaller Gross Margins for us as they are generally more experienced and are therefore more expensive to hire, but this is partially compensated by the fact that freelancers present no bench risk for us.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are impacted by the levels of competition that we experience in each of the markets in which we operate and in any new markets that we may enter. We compete with other firms offering HR solutions to both clients and job candidates to varying degrees in each of the geographical markets and staffing segments in which we operate. Competition for both of these groups is based on a variety of factors, and such competition has intensified following the Covid-19 pandemic due to the general labor shortage. Competitive factors in obtaining and retaining clients can include the ability to find job candidates with the appropriate skills and/or experience, brand awareness, quality, speed of client service, proximity to the client and particularly in relation to temporary staffing services, and price. Competitive factors in obtaining and retaining job candidates can include wages, quality of engagement, number of hours of work available, responsiveness to work schedules, job content and type of project, personal validation of the job candidates and brand image. ----- On large contracts, which are more common in temporary staffing services under our specialized talent solutions segment, there is often pressure on pricing due to the increased competitiveness in the industry. There is often less pricing pressure in our engineering and consulting segment, due to the scarcity of candidates to fill certain roles. As a result, this segment and the higher margins associated with these fields are becoming increasingly attractive to firms in the industry. In certain of our key geographic markets, such as the Netherlands, the specialized HR solutions market is relatively mature with comparatively established pricing. Across all four of our key geographic markets the industry is fragmented. In individual markets and specialist sectors, we compete with smaller, more localized or more specialized firms. As a result of the trend towards consolidation in the specialized HR solutions industry, we also compete with larger full-service and specialized competitors in the international, national, regional and local markets. In addition, some current and prospective clients, particularly among larger corporates, may elect not to fill their staffing requirements from outside sources, and may instead hire independent contractors directly on a temporary basis or provide similar services internally. Many clients use more than one staffing services provider, and the majority of client relationships are non-exclusive. Websites, search engines and online job boards, such as Google for Jobs, monsterboard.nl and Indeed are improving their matching capabilities, potentially affecting part of our business. Pricing, promotional and marketing actions of our competitors may also impact our business, such that our price levels could be impacted or that we need to invest more in marketing and advertising to obtain the right candidates. For a further discussion of our competitors in each of our divisions, see “Industry and Market Data.”

Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations have been affected in the periods under review, and are expected to continue to be affected, by various key factors relating to our business and industry, which we describe below.
