(118.2) 6.8% (116.4) 7.3% (112.9) 5.5% (81.8) 5.6% (126.1) 6.2% _Cost of Services_ Cost of services comprises costs directly attributable to revenue, which mainly relate to costs associated with our job candidates, such as their wages and salaries, social security charges, training costs, other benefits (including housing expenses, car leases, mobility costs, vouchers for meals and other incentives, such as reimbursements to job candidates for utilizing environmentally friendly transportation solutions as well as other benefits for job candidates), and costs associated with freelancers. A small portion of these costs relates to material costs for projects performed in GRITT Projects, which was divested in 2020. Our job candidates’ wages and salaries, social security and other benefits amounted to our largest cost of services during the period under review. The principal factor that affects these costs is the number of job candidates that we employ. As a result, these costs increase ----- as we add additional job candidates either through growing our business organically or through acquisitions. Our overall number of job candidates, however, may not be representative of our expected cost of services since these costs will be impacted by the level of compensation each job candidate receives, which is in turn linked to inflation, specializations, qualifications and positions filled by each job candidate. During the period of Covid-19, which had a particularly severe impact on the global economy in 2020, attracting foreign nationals entailed additional costs, given restrictions on crossing borders and additional quarantine measures and isolation requirements which led to increased numbers of days of unproductivity, with the result of increased housing expenses, hygienic and sanitary costs and provision of groceries for candidates arriving from abroad. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our cost of services decreased by 7.8%, from €1,288.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,188.2 million. This was in parallel with an 8.2% decrease in revenue during the same period, from €1,738.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,596.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This illustrates the largely variable nature of our cost base, as Accent, Continu Professionals and Covebo mainly employ workers whose contracts can be terminated immediately, or who can be put on the bench without cost, as well as freelancers. For workers with less flexible conditions, typically because they are on our payroll with an indefinite term contract, such as the specialists employed by GRITT, Abylsen and TIMEPARTNER (including AERO and IBB) under permanent contracts and whose costs of services are therefore semi-variable, we were able to rely on economic unemployment measures to decrease the related costs. In some cases, even when companies could terminate contracts immediately, they chose not to do so and instead opted to rely on certain government economic unemployment initiatives so they could scale up quickly when the Covid-19 restrictive measures eased. These companies also employ freelancers, for whom costs are fully variable. Such additional costs reduced in 2021 as lockdown measures eased, which consequentially also led to a higher level of staffing activities compared to 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our cost of services increased by 26.6%, from €1,188.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €1,504.3 million. This was in parallel with a 28.4% increase in revenue during the same period, from €1,596.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €2,050.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Given the nature of our operations, which typically results in us placing our job candidates on our payroll while they are on assignment, we are required to insure a significant number of persons against work accidents, which impacts our cost of services. Since 2021, a variable premium rate has been applied to our work accident insurance, with a base premium rate of 2.918%, a mid-case rate of 3.064% and worst-case rate of 3.097%, depending on the number of work accidents we have. This premium is calculated based on the gross salary mass of our temporary workers. Such cost will be partly offset by customer compensations and efforts to lower accident occurrence and further offset by other cost reductions, following efficiencies realized in other departmental costs within Accent. Ransomware and other cyber risks have increased in general during Covid-19 and also require us to invest in a higher standard of back-up procedures as work from home and remote working practices predominate, especially in relation to compliance with data protection laws, avoidance of misappropriation and cyber theft, leading to higher operating costs for our information technologies, as additional work, licenses and expertise is needed to detect and prevent adverse occurrences. This also increased our cost of services since 2020. _Gross Margin_ Our Gross Margin represents our gross profit (our revenue less our cost of services) divided by our revenue. Our Gross Margin was 25.9%, 25.6% and 26.6% for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, and 26.0% and 26.3% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. There are two primary drivers of our Gross Margin: the bill-pay spread and the bench time/utilization of our job candidates (particularly our job candidates in our engineering and consulting segment): ----- - _Bill-pay spread: We will typically enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate (often for the duration of an assignment or longer in the case of certain business units) and we will enter into a placement contract or project contract with the client. We then bill the client for the services performed by the job candidate who are on time and material contracts and pay the salary of the job candidate. The percentage difference between what we bill our clients and what we pay as salary to the job candidates is referred to as the “bill-pay spread” and it is the key driver of our profitability. - _Bench time/Utilization: Job candidates in most of our engineering and consulting business units as well as our job candidates in Germany are our permanent employees on our payroll whether or not they are on assignment with a client. As a result, our engineering and consulting segment in particular carefully monitors the end date of all job candidates’ assignments and aims to line up the next assignment before their current ones come to an end. This monitoring seeks to minimize “bench time,” which is the time for which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed to a client assignment. Our bench time for 2021 was approximately 0.3%. By minimizing a job candidate’s bench time, we aim to ensure the job candidate is being utilized on a project that requires his or her skill set, so there is a match between what we bill the client for the job candidate’s services and what we pay the job candidate. New assignments also ensure future career development of the job candidate. Furthermore, the impact of utilization upon our Gross Margin will also depend on the mix of job candidates whose utilization is impacted, with the more specialized job candidates typically performing work under contracts with higher bill-pay spreads as a result of their scarcity and specialization. As most of our contracts are on a time and materials basis, increased utilization rates will typically improve our Gross Margin. The Covid-19 pandemic has presented an additional impact on our Gross Margin as a result of various local government measures providing partial compensation for temporary unemployment, such as furlough schemes. In certain cases, for example in France, we retained job candidates on our payroll but the government measures did not provide full compensation for such candidates; therefore, the company responsible for the candidate still had to pay a portion of the compensation. In addition, in certain cases we also retained job candidates on our payroll in order to accommodate our customers more quickly when the isolation measures were over, without having to wait for additional hires. For some companies that typically have higher bench time, we saw a reduction in their bench time as a result of placing job candidates on government economic unemployment initiatives. Due to the difference in Gross Margin between our various segments, our segment mix, and within each segment, our industry, sector or candidate mix can affect our overall Gross Margin. For example, in Accent, the construction end-market generates a higher Gross Margin than the hospitality end-market, and student candidates generate a lower Gross Margin compared to the experienced candidates. Below is the revenue split between our two business segments for the years ending December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impact of Covid-19 and our Response
Subsubsection Text: Concomitant with its global and market-wide impact, the Covid-19 pandemic negatively affected our business, results of operations and financial condition in 2020. Our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020, decreased by 8.2%, from €1,738.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,596.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily as a result of Covid-19. In response to this unprecedented situation, we modified certain of our operational practices and changed how we communicate both internally and with customers; we implemented additional protective procedures; and we accessed temporary government measures that were advantageous to us. ----- In respect of sales in our markets, our response included keeping branches open to the extent possible, such that the large majority of our branch network continues to exist post-lockdowns, as management sought to preserve stability in terms of access to customers. Temporary Unemployment measures were utilized in order to retain experienced and trained staff members, while we undertook various initiatives and loyalty programs for staff of platforms and operating companies, including motivational training. We also awarded special bonuses in respect of extraordinary efforts with new customers, and for boosting sales in the initial months after the first lock-down. In particular, in Accent, special regional growth bonuses, which were structured to allow for increased collaboration on a region-wide basis, and speed bonuses, for those offices that were the first to return to financial performance in line with 2019 figures, were awarded. During the Covid-19 pandemic, we managed our costs of services, where possible, by placing consultants or temporary workers on temporary unemployment or similar schemes (depending on available government assistance in each of our markets) in order to keep our workforce intact to the extent possible, so as to be able to place these candidates back on customer assignment once customers resumed hiring. In Continu Professionals, consultants were also kept on the payroll, and were kept on the bench so as to allow them to return to work after the virus’s first wave. This approach paid off during the summer, when the large majority of people on the bench were back at work with a customer. We also reduced expenses by placing internal staff on temporary unemployment where we deemed appropriate, such as in branches that were inactive because the sector had closed (such as the retail nonfood and hotel, retail and café (“horeca”) segments). In Accent, we placed internal staff on temporary unemployment on March 18, 2020, the first day this was allowed by the authorities. In Abylsen, internal staff were not put on temporary unemployment, thereby permitting them to remain close to those consultants that were still at the customer, allowing us to continue to detect further opportunities with those customers that were still active during the first lock-down. We reduced marketing expenses and other expenses to the minimum required in 2020, while retooling in an effort to draw interest, such as webinars we organized for customers to explain the impact of government measures. Management also reduced capital expenditures compared to recent prior years in order to protect cash levels during the Covid-19 pandemic and as a precautionary measure also drew on its Existing Revolving Credit Facility in March 2020, which was subsequently repaid in June 2020. Our sales fully recovered during 2021, achieving above pre-Covid-19 pandemic levels, mostly due to the economic recovery and the overall digitalization trends that are expected to continue going forward. With global economy having been revived in 2021, there is a talent crunch as companies are looking to fill positions that were cut in 2020 due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Moreover, the Covid19 pandemic has led to many job candidates re-evaluating their careers, work conditions and long-term professional goals, resulting in an increased rate of employees switching jobs and transitioning between different job modes. This has led employers to focus more intensely than ever on employee retention and job mobility, which has created substantial opportunities for us to offer our services. In response to the evolving market trends, we are increasingly more focused on the bottleneck professions and specialized jobs, and our M&A strategy is strengthening our capability to capitalize on such trends. For example, our acquisitions of TMI and Cohedron helped us to expand and compete in the healthcare and public sectors. Also, Accent partnered with a regional public employment service, the VDAB (the Flemish Institution for Employment Mediation and Training), to participate in CareerFlow, a government-initiated project in Belgium that facilitates job mobility between employers and provides alternatives to employees. Through this project, employees can temporarily or permanently work for different employers, which allows them to develop skill sets that would best match their professional goals. This creates a benefit for both employers and job candidates, as employers have a larger and more diverse talent pool to tap into for their various staffing needs, while job candidates have a better chance to stay employed and more flexibility in shaping their careers. ----- Although the spread of the new strain of Covid-19, Omicron, in the last weeks of 2021 and at the beginning of 2022 did not visibly impact our recovery in terms of sales, increased sickness and isolation measures did put pressure on our Gross Margin. Furthermore, we are navigating a new market landscape as the expectations and preferences of employers and job candidates have changed drastically during the Covid-19 pandemic. There is no clear indication whether there will be an ongoing resurgence in the spread of Covid-19 in our primary markets in the future, and together with the war in Ukraine, we are experiencing increased costs of labor, services and raw materials as a result of inflation and are facing the prospect of another recession. We generally have the ability to, however, pass through wage increases from inflation to customers in both our engineering and consulting segment and our specialized talent solutions segment, which, coupled with our flexible cost structure, has resulted in resilient Gross Margins. Our revenues typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due to our stable margins and ability to pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: .......................................................................... (1) Excludes the corporate segment and intragroup eliminations, which amounted to less than 1%. ----- Additionally, the difference in Gross Margin between various types of contracts can also affect our overall Gross Margin. For example, our search and selection services are based on commissions earned for job candidates sourced for clients. We receive less revenue from such services because we only locate the candidate and then receive a search and selection commission, rather than a contract with the client that also includes such job candidate’s wages or salary, social security and other benefits to be paid out and administered by us. Such contracts tend to provide a higher Gross Margin of approximately 100% since there are no subsequent costs to deduct from the commissions received. _Selling Expenses_ Selling expenses comprise the wages and salaries (including variable pay), social security charges and other benefits (such as accommodation expenses) for in-house employees responsible for operational activities at our branches, as well as advertising and marketing (including internal marketing), amortization of customer relationships and brand names that were originally valued in the context of various business combinations and other selling expenses. Selling expenses are primarily impacted by the number of in-house employees we employ. As a result, selling expenses will increase when we grow our operations and the number of in-house employees that we have who manage the recruiting lifecycle and oversee the sourcing, selection and placement of our job candidates on assignment. In 2020, the Covid-19 pandemic also resulted in an increase in such selling expenses. In particular, in Accent we paid a one-time additional bonus to members of our commercial team during the second and third quarters of 2020, in recognition of extraordinary continuing contributions during the Covid-19 period. As the impact of Covid-19 lessened in 2021, selling expenses increased primarily in correspondence with revenue. _Other general and administrative expenses_ Other general and administrative expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses of head offices, IT expenses, depreciation expenses largely relating to charges on capitalized buildings, cars and software, and other general and administrative expenses at the headquarters level, as well as share-based payments. During the period under review, our share-based payments consisted of several ratchet schemes offered to key management at different acquired Powerhouses (Abylsen, Covebo, Continu Professional, TIMEPARTNER and GRITT) (“ratchet schemes”) and our former long-term incentive plan at the level of shareholders of House of HR (“long-term incentive plan”), which we settled in connection with the Acquisition. In 2019, 2020 and 2021, we recognized €4.6 million, €3.9 million and €1.5 million, respectively, in share-based payments connected to option grants made under our longterm incentive plan launched in 2018. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we recognized €3.7 million in share-based payments connected to option grants made under the same long-term incentive plan. See note 19 to each of our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and note 21 to our Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information. On the Acquisition Closing Date, we established the structure for a management equity participation program pursuant to which certain managers of the Group are able to acquire, subscribe for or otherwise receive MIP Securities. See “Certain Relationships and _Related Party Transactions—Management Incentive Plan.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As the population of our target markets ages and workers exit the labor pool, there has been an increase in competition among employers to fill the gaps left behind. This has left an opening for staffing intermediaries, especially those like us that have a proven track record of identifying and matching the right candidates to the right jobs, to fill these vacant positions with qualified talent. Additionally, a scarcity of talent for certain roles is driving wages up, which in turn can increase the pricing power of staffing firms for the solutions and staffing we provide.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In recent years, candidates are increasingly turning to online job boards when seeking out a position, particularly through traffic generated by mobile devices. At the same time, clients expect more efficient services at a lower cost that can only be delivered through the use of digital tools. We have also seen an increase in the number of passive job seekers who apply through targeted advertisements on social media when they were not actively searching for a position at the time. The market has also experienced the development of new platforms, such as Uber Works in the United States, which however announced in May 2020 the closure of their operations in light of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to their official press release. Such platforms may be considered competitors, since they sometimes are able to attract people directly to be employed for them via freelance or independent status. Nevertheless, such platforms lack a human touch in the services they provide, and authorities in different countries monitor fair treatment of workers by these platforms and are looking to ensure that there is no unfair competition with other forms of labor. Such monitoring is especially common in the EU, where regulation and labor unions are stronger than in other countries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Career mobility and the need to re-skill
Subsubsection Text: Millennial workers, especially highly skilled ones, are increasingly mobile and seeking a varied career path, driving the need for re-skilling. This re-skilling can be provided through both formal and on-thejob training that is typically provided as part of temporary work agreements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility
Subsubsection Text: ----- As the diversity trend becomes mainstream across clients, service providers have an opportunity to provide increasing value to their clients by tapping into broad, international pools of candidates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Increased premium on quality of life
Subsubsection Text: It is increasingly difficult to find qualified candidates to fill some roles that offer long hours and difficult conditions, as younger generations of workers are placing a fairly large premium on happiness in their personal and professional lives. This has contributed to a supply-and-demand gap in certain end-markets and as a result, staffing solutions providers with the ability to source and place candidates successfully, are in greater demand.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial pressures on companies, especially the SMEs, have incentivized them to outsource many of their non-core functions. Further, due to accelerated business rhythms, companies are increasingly looking to obtain immediately available resources. This has led to an increased need for temporary staffing and outsourced support that can be provided rapidly on short notice.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower job security has been a driver of demand in the recent years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the key factors above, there are also certain trends that could play a significant role in our results of operations in the future as these trends become more prevalent or as our operations in such areas develop and grow. See also “Industry—Staffing Solutions Secular Industry Drivers.” These include: aging population; technological changes; career mobility and the need to reskill; diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility; increased premium on quality of life; and outsourcing and offshoring.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue consists of the fair value of the consideration received or receivable for the services rendered during the year to third parties. We mainly derive revenue from the transfer of services over time and at a point in time in our engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions segments. We mainly generate revenue from offering HR staffing solutions to our clients. The duration of these HR staffing solutions may vary between a couple of hours up to a period of two years (without minimum volumes attached to these contracts). In a small number of cases, we also provide solutions to customers active in larger project-oriented businesses (such as the telecommunications or the construction end-markets) where apart from staffing, specific deliverables also have to be provided. Such engagements may take one week up to two to three months. We do not have a single major customer from which we generate revenue. The size of this business is also reduced following the divestment of GRITT Projects.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of services comprises expenses directly attributable to revenue. These costs mainly include expenses related to job candidates, such as wages, salaries, and social charges but also include costs associated with freelancers and subcontractors, referred to as “insourced costs.” Cost of services also includes the housing expenses for foreign and other job candidates referred to as “services costs.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Selling expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses in relation to operational activities at the branches, advertising and marketing, and other selling expenses, as well as the amortization and impairment of acquisition-related intangible assets and goodwill. Trademarks, licenses and customer relationship contracts acquired in a business combination have a finite useful life. They are recognized at fair value at the acquisition date and are subsequently carried at cost less accumulated amortization ----- and impairment losses. The amortization of customer relationships is based on the projected useful life of the client (between seven and 15 years).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: General and administrative expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses of head offices, IT expenses, and other general and administrative expenses. The depreciation expenses component under this line item largely relates to charges on capitalized buildings, cars and software, among others.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income includes interest income on short-term bank deposits, interest income on loans to related parties, gains on derecognition of non-convertible bonds, cross-charges to related parties and swaps.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance expenses include the interest on borrowings from related parties, banks, bonds, as well as the refinancing costs and bank fees related to costs associated with the refinancing of bank loans and other recurring bank fees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Share in profit/(loss) of equity accounted investments
Subsubsection Text: Share in profit/(loss) of equity accounted investments is comprised of gains and losses from equity accounted investments, such as joint ventures. As of September 30, 2022, Accent held a 50% stake in Sixie BV and House of HR held a minority stake in Ariad and a minority stake in Happy Recruiter. We do not consider these joint ventures and associates to be individually material to us. During 2021, we had a loss from an equity accounted investment in Happy Recruiter, as both the shares in and the loans towards Happy Recruiter were impaired to nil in the third quarter of 2021, resulting in a loss of €1.5 million for us. In May 2022, ETA, a subsidiary of the Abylsen group, established a joint venture with DFI, a subcontractor that ETA works with on specific projects. ETA holds 50% of the shares of this joint venture for an amount of €25,000. The purpose of this investment is to reduce the amount of insurance expenses of the projects that ETA and DFI work on. No activity is planned for this joint venture until 2023. In June 2022, Abylsen acquired 35.1% additional shares in Greenworking for a consideration of €9.8 million and we currently hold 95.1% of the shares in Greenworking.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense is comprised of current tax and deferred tax. Current and deferred tax is recognized in profit or loss, except to the extent that it relates to items recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity. The components of and the recognition policies for current tax and deferred tax are set out below: _Current tax_ Current tax is comprised of the current tax on profits for the year, as well as adjustments made in respect of prior years. The current tax charge is calculated on the basis of the tax laws that are enacted or substantially enacted at the reporting date in the countries where we operate and generate taxable income. Management periodically evaluates positions taken in our tax returns with regard to situations in which applicable tax regulations are subject to interpretation. It establishes provisions where appropriate on the basis of amounts expected to be paid to the relevant tax authority. _Deferred tax_ ----- Deferred tax is recognized in full, using the liability method, on temporary differences arising between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts in the Consolidated Financial Statements. Deferred tax liabilities are, however, not recognized if they arise from the initial recognition of goodwill. Deferred tax is also not accounted for if it arises from initial recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction other than a business combination that at the time of the transaction affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss. Deferred tax is determined using tax rates (and laws) that have been enacted or substantially enacted by the end of the reporting period and are expected to apply when the related deferred income tax asset is realized or the deferred tax liability is settled. Deferred tax primarily arises from the valuation of customer relationships and brand names and the allocation of amortization on them, as well as from fair value adjustments relating to the then existing senior facilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: For the nine months ended September 30,** **Change 2021** **2022 (€ in millions)** **(%)
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue increased by €584.1 million, or 40.1%, from €1,456.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to €2,040.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, primarily as a result of the acquisitions completed in 2021 and 2022 and due to favorable market conditions. On a Like-for-Like basis, our revenue growth was due to overall economic growth fueled by the scarcity of job candidates, while our EBITDA margin percentage slightly decreased, mainly in the engineering and consulting segment, due to investment in recruitment capacity and higher sickness ratio. On a Like-for-Like basis, our gross profit increased by €79.8 million, or 16.1%, from €495.5 million, for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €575.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, with the gross profit of our engineering and consulting segment increasing by €37.8 million, or 16.3%, from €232.0 million, for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €269.7 million for ----- the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and the gross profit of our specialized talent solutions segment increased by €42.8 million, or 16.3%, from €263.3 million, for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €306.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. On a Like-forLike basis, Gross Margin slightly decreased from 27.7% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to 27.4% for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, while Gross Margin for our engineering and consulting segment decreased from 33.9% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to 32.5% for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and Gross Margin for our specialized talent solutions segment increased from 23.8% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to 24.1% for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The engineering and consulting segment and the specialized talent solutions segment accounted for 39.8% and 60.3% of our revenue, respectively, for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The following table sets out our revenue split by segment for the periods indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: For the nine months ended September 30,** **Change 2021** **2022 (€ in millions)** **(%)
Subsubsection Text: Our impairment of goodwill increased to €13.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, from nil in the nine months ended September 30, 2021. This was due to an impairment test performed during the second quarter of 2022 given the rising interest rate in the current market, which we consider to be an impairment indicator. Pursuant to this impairment test, we identified a goodwill impairment in relation to the GRITT Powerhouse of €13.3 million, as the recoverable amount was €40.9 million compared to the carrying value of €54.2 million. We performed another impairment test during the third quarter of 2022 due to further increases in interest rates, which identified no additional impairments. We therefore recorded a goodwill impairment of €13.3 million for the nine months ending September 30, 2022, as we consider this change to have a long-term impact.

The average tax rate is significantly impacted by the losses incurred in our corporate segment for which no deferred tax asset is recorded and the tax ruling that Accent requested in 2021 relating to the cross-charge from Accent to other operational entities within the Group. While the tax ruling is still pending, the implications that could result from it have been retroactively reflected in the fiscal results for 2020 as presented in the 2021 financial statements. This adjustment has resulted in a different tax base for 2020, which has been reflected in the tax-related line items in the income statement for 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Excludes the corporate segment and intragroup eliminations, which amounted to less than 1%. _Engineering and consulting_ Revenue for the engineering and consulting segment (excluding the corporate segment and intragroup eliminations) decreased by 8.3%, from €566.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €519.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily the result of the decrease in demand for highly skilled professionals across sectors as recruitment came to a halt during the Covid19 pandemic, which led to less consultants on our payroll primarily in Abylsen, GRITT and Continu Professionals. This was partially offset by the increased employment in Redmore, as the banking and insurance sectors were relatively less affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, and the increased chargeability due to higher utilization as a result of remote working arrangements, which resulted in a reduction of sick leave. _Specialized talent solutions_ ----- Revenue for the specialized talent solutions segment (excluding the corporate segment and intragroup eliminations) decreased by 8.3%, from €1,175.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,078.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily the result of businesses closing down in our primary markets, particularly in the second quarter of 2020, due to the restrictive measures that governments imposed in response to Covid-19, which reduced recruitment needs for the sectors on which the specialized talent solutions segment predominantly focuses. Accent and NOWJOBS were particularly severely impacted, as all of Accent’s branches were closed by the end of March 2020 as a precautionary measure and due to NOWJOBS’s exposure to the leisure and horeca sectors. Foreign job candidates were also more reluctant to relocate during the early stages of the Covid-19 pandemic. _Revenue by geographical location_ The following table sets out our revenue split by geographical location for the periods indicated. Revenue from our operations in Belgium decreased from €672.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €552.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to decreased demand in our services by our clients as staffing needs declined due to the economic impact of Covid-19. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal cash requirements consist of investments in acquisitions, capital expenditures, servicing financial indebtedness, payroll costs and paying taxes. Our principal sources of liquidity are cash flows from operating activities and financing cash flows from drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility, availability under the Delayed Draw Term Facility and committed and uncommitted lines. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is subject to certain conditions. See “Description of Other Indebtedness.” Our ability to generate operating cash flows depends on operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” We believe that, based on our current level of operations as reflected in its results of operations for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, cash flows from operating activities, cash on hand and the availability of borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility and committed and uncommitted lines will be sufficient to fund operations and capital expenditures and to debt service for at least the next twelve months. The ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends and make other payments to us may be restricted by, among other things, the amount of distributable reserves and legal prohibitions on such payments or otherwise distributing funds to us, including for the purpose of servicing debt. Losses or other events could further reduce the net equity and distributable reserves of our subsidiaries. In 2020 and 2021, we undertook a number of measures to preserve our liquidity during the Covid-19 pandemic, including managing our costs of services, where possible, by placing consultants or temporary workers on temporary unemployment or similar schemes (depending on available government assistance in each of our markets) in order to keep our workforce intact to the extent possible, so as to be able to place these candidates back on customer assignment once customers resumed hiring. Expenses were reduced by placing internal staff on temporary unemployment where revenue necessitated this, for example in branches that were inactive because the sector had closed (such as the retail non-food and horeca segments). In Accent, this was done as of March 18, 2020, the first day this was allowed by the authorities. In Abylsen, internal staff were not put on temporary unemployment, thereby permitting them to remain close to those consultants that were still at the customer, allowing us to continue to detect further opportunities with those customers that were still active during the first lock-down. Further, marketing expenses and other expenses were reduced to the minimum required in 2020, while also being retooled in an effort to draw interest, such as webinars we organized for customers to explain the impact of government measures. Management also reduced capital expenditures compared to recent prior years in order to protect cash levels during Covid-19 and ----- as a precautionary measure also drew on its Existing Revolving Credit Facility in March 2020, which was subsequently repaid in June 2020. The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes will be used as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.”

Subsection Title: For the nine months For the year ended December 31,** **ended September 30, 2019** **2020** **2021** **2021** **2022 (€ in millions)
Subsubsection Text: Our resilience is further supported by the cash protective nature of our working capital dynamics. Our working capital largely consists of receivables (client billings) and payables (job candidate wages, social security, etc.) tied to individual job candidate placements. For each job candidate placement, the receivable is higher than the payable with the difference roughly representing the bill-pay spread or gross margin embedded in the client service agreement and job candidate agreements. This means that (all else being equal) when we place fewer job candidates, our working capital declines, resulting in a positive cash balance offsetting the loss of post-tax cash profit. Usually in the last quarter of the year, our working capital shows a decrease, which is reflected as cash inflow in the cashflow statement. This is because usually in the second and third quarters of the year working capital is at its highest due to ramp-up of sales growth in receivables and high payables that tend to occur during this period, such as holiday payments, accident insurance, and employers liability insurance. The working capital dynamics and corresponding downside protection for our cash flows are also evident in our recent performance during the Covid-19 pandemic. In 2020, we had a positive change in working capital, while in 2019 and 2021 we had a negative change in working capital. This demonstrates the counter cyclical nature of our working capital profile which typically unwinds during periods of economic downturn, thereby generating larger cash inflow. For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, our change in working capital as a percentage of revenue was (1.1)%, 4.2% and (0.1)%, respectively. Working capital changes amounted to negative €66.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, compared to negative €18.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily impacted by the timing of payments of wages and salaries and VAT. Working capital changes amounted to negative €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to €67.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the increased usage of the factoring program at Accent and GRITT. In addition, working capital was impacted by the Covid19 pandemic which led to a decline in sales, as well as by the factoring program we launched at TIMEPARTNER. In June 2021, we also launched factoring programs at Continu Professionals and Covebo, but these were offset by increased sales during the year as economies revived in 2021. Working capital changes amounted to €67.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to negative €18.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the increased usage of the factoring program at Accent and GRITT. In addition, working capital was impacted by the Covid ----- 19 pandemic which led to a decline in sales, as well as by the factoring program we launched at TIMEPARTNER. _Invoicing_ In order to minimize our credit risk, we follow practices in relation to the issuance and timing of invoices to customers. In the specialized talent solutions segment, invoicing is typically done on a weekly basis to customers, with payment terms ranging from zero up to 60 days, but with a majority on a 30 day payment term. Customers with no credit history or very small customers receive a zero or seven day credit, allowing us to closely monitor payment behavior, and to withhold rendering services (i.e., people at work) if a payment is not made when due. In the engineering & consulting segment, customers are on average typically somewhat larger SMEs or are large companies such as financial, transportation or industrial firms. In this segment, invoicing cycles are most often on a monthly basis, with payment terms between 30 to 60 days, or in France, up to 90 days. It should be noted that the company has a credit insurance policy in place covering all Group entities, up to a limit of €250.0 million.

MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We entered into factoring agreements with banks during the periods under review, under which trade receivables of certain entities within the Group are transferred to the factors. These entities are part of Accent Group and GRITT, and the factoring arrangements involve ING, Belfius and KBC Bank. As the ----- factor assumes the payment risk and credit under the factoring agreement, this agreement from January 1, 2019 has been accounted for as a non-recourse agreement. During 2020, we implemented a commercial finance agreement in respect of factoring in TIMEPARTNER and during 2021, we implemented a commercial finance agreement in respect of factoring in Continu Professionals and Covebo in a total amount equal to €100.0 million. avanti had a commercial finance agreement in place on the date of acquisition. As both the late payment risk and credit risk have been substantially transferred to the counterparty, this agreement has been accounted for as a non-recourse agreement as the continuing involvement is considered insignificant. As of December 31, 2021, €106.4 million accounts receivable has been transferred to the factor which has been deducted from the open trade receivables as per December 31, 2021. As of September 30, 2022, a further €37.7 million is recorded as other receivable and comprises the difference between the gross trade receivable sold and the amount received from the factoring company (as of September 30, 2022, 90% for Accent and GRITT, 90% for TIMEPARTNER, 80% for Continu Professionals, 70% for Covebo and 90% for avanti). In addition, SOLCOM had a factoring contract in place as of the date of acquisition, which was terminated on June 30, 2022. SOLCOM was integrated into the Group’s factoring agreement on June 30, 2022. Pursuant to our credit insurance, the maximum amount we can borrow under our factoring agreements is €250.0 million. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have €51.0 million committed for our Belgian contracts (Accent Group and GRITT). The maximum amount we can borrow under our non-Belgian contracts is limited by the amount provided under our credit insurance (as reduced by the amount committed under the Belgian contracts). As of September 30, 2022, we had used €79.0 million under these contracts. We expect to continue to engage in factoring in line with the Group’s existing factoring agreements following the Transactions. With the exception of the above, we have not engaged in any material off-balance sheet financing arrangements during the periods under review.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: _Foreign exchange risk_ Our exposure to foreign exchange risk is very limited as our operations are essentially denominated in euro. Therefore, the impact of fluctuations of these currencies of +/-10% is considered as immaterial. ----- _Interest rate risk_ Our interest rate risk arises from long-term borrowings. Borrowings issued at variable rates expose our cash flow to an interest rate risk which is offset by the interest rate caps. On an as adjusted basis for the Offering, most of our indebtedness will consists of the Notes and borrowings under the Facilities and the Bridge Facility. The Notes will be issued at, and following the Conversion Date, the Bridge Facility will bear, a fixed interest rate. The Facilities bear, and prior to the Conversion Date the Bridge Facility bears, variable interest rates, which for loans denominated in euros is essentially fixed when the reference interest rate is below zero, due to the interest rate floor. Following the Acquisition Closing Date, we entered into hedging instruments covering approximately 50% of the Facilities at the level of the Issuer to hedge interest rate risk exposure under the Facilities, and we plan to enter into additional hedging agreements to cover 75% to 100% of the Facilities to hedge our interest rate risk exposure. The floating rate on the borrowings under the Facilities will be entirely accounted for at amortized cost, and therefore the impact of changes in the market interest rate on the fair value of these floating rate borrowings at the closing date will have no impact on the income statement or on the equity. The Group does not apply hedge accounting. EURIBOR floating rate borrowings which are not covered by the swaps are subject to interest rate risk.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our credit risk mainly arises from credit exposures to customers, including outstanding receivables, as well as from cash and cash equivalents, favorable derivative financial instruments, and deposits with banks and financial institutions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: We have no significant concentrations of credit risk other than that for ordinary debtors. We have policies to ensure that the services are provided to customers with an appropriate credit history. Credit risk is managed locally by each subgroup (brand) and certain companies have credit insurance in place. Credit risk mainly arises as credit exposures to customers, including outstanding receivables. The credit quality of customers, considering the financial position of customers, past experience and other factors, is closely assessed by the credit department on a regular basis. During 2020, a credit insurance program was set-up throughout the Group to enable us to have control over open receivables during the challenging Covid-19 pandemic. Individual risk limits are set based on internal or external ratings in accordance with limits set by the finance committee. The utilization of credit limits is regularly monitored. Management does not expect any losses from non-performance by our counterparties. _Impairment of financial assets_ We have three types of financial assets that are subject to the expected credit loss model: - trade receivables for sales of services; - contract assets resulting from project services in progress; and - debt investments carried at amortized cost. While cash and cash equivalents are also subject to the impairment requirements of IFRS 9, there was no identified impairment loss. _Trade receivables_ ----- We apply the IFRS 9 simplified approach to measure expected credit losses which uses a lifetime expected loss allowance for all trade receivables. To measure the expected credit losses, trade receivables and contract assets have been grouped based on shared credit risk characteristics and the days past due. The expected loss rates are based on the payment profiles of sales over a period of 36 months before each reporting year-end, and the corresponding historical credit losses experienced within this period. The historical loss rates are adjusted to reflect current and forward-looking information on macroeconomic factors affecting the ability of the customers to settle the receivables. Forward-looking information has been considered in assessing the Expected Credit Loss impairment under IFRS 9, taken into consideration the possible downside resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic. This did not result in a significant impact on the Expected Credit Loss model assumptions. Trade receivables and project related receivables are written off when there is no reasonable expectation of recovery. Indicators that there is no reasonable expectation of recovery include, among others, the failure of a debtor to engage in a repayment plan with us, and a failure to make contractual payments for a period of greater than 120 days past due. Several factors are considered in assessing the likelihood of impairment which is assessed on a case-by-case basis. Impairment losses on trade receivables and contract assets are presented as net impairment losses within operating profit. Subsequent recoveries of amounts previously written off are credited against the same line item. We first apply the policy relating to impairment of the trade receivables under the incurred loss model, and then, for the rest of receivables which are not provided for, we apply the expected credit loss model, and recognize an additional provision. As of December 31, 2021, 78% of our trade receivables were less than one month old, 13% were between one month and two months old and the remaining 8% were between two months and one year or two or more years old. As of December 31, 2021, 97% of the trade receivables were not impaired, while 3% were impaired. As of December 31, 2021, trade receivables of €36.8 million (December 31, 2020: €40.4 million, December 31, 2019: €56.9 million) were past due but not impaired. These receivables are expected to be recovered and have not been provided for because they relate to well-known customers and they are strictly followed up by the credit department. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our activities expose us to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including limited foreign exchange risk, cash flow and fair value interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. Our overall risk management program focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on our financial performance. Our objective is to identify, quantify, manage and then monitor events or actions that could lead to financial losses. We use derivative financial instruments to hedge certain interest risk exposures. In particular, we protect the variable interest rate on loans via the use of caps that limit the exposure to fluctuations of EURIBOR. Risk management is carried out by our treasury department. Group’s treasury identifies, evaluates and hedges financial risks with approval from the Board of Directors. See note 4.1 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.

Subsubsection Text: Prudent liquidity risk management implies maintaining sufficient cash, the availability of funding through an adequate amount of committed credit facilities and use of trade supplier credit terms. ----- Cash flow forecasting is performed in our operating entities and aggregated by the Group treasury. Group treasury monitors rolling forecasts of our liquidity requirements to ensure we have sufficient cash to meet operational needs while maintaining sufficient headroom on our undrawn committed borrowing facilities at all times so that we do not breach borrowing limits or covenants (where applicable) on any of our borrowing facilities. Such forecasting takes into consideration our debt financing plans, covenant compliance, compliance with internal balance sheet ratio targets and, if applicable, external regulatory or legal requirements. We also use factoring agreements with certain banks in order to obtain early access to cash flows. See also “—Liquidity and Capital Resources— _Overview” above._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations that management believes is relevant to an assessment and understanding of our historical consolidated financial position and results of operations. All historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of House of HR and its subsidiaries. Accordingly, all references to “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of historical financial information in this Offering Memorandum are to House of HR and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and the section in this Offering Memorandum titled “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” The following discussion and analysis contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including, without limitation, those set forth in “Forward- Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.”_

Subsection Title: Overview of the Staffing Solutions Industry
Subsubsection Text: We are a diversified human resources solutions provider serving clients located primarily in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands through ten business units. We operate through two distinct segments: engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions. Our engineering and consulting segment is focused on supplying clients with high-skilled white-collar consultants and mid to highskilled professionals to meet clients’ specialized needs in a variety of end-markets including financial, industrial and construction end-markets. Through this segment, we also staff one to three-year construction projects, mainly through secondment or time and materials contracts. Our specialized talent solutions typically supplies a small number of high demand mid-and lower skilled blue-collar and white-collar workers to clients for specialized positions on a temporary basis. We source our candidates both from our primary markets and also increasingly from our international recruitment network. Across both segments, in addition to the positive secular trends supporting the whole staffing solutions industry, the diversity of our clients’ end-markets and geographic markets supports our business resiliency and outlook. Staffing solutions providers fall into one of three categories: mono-specialists, multi-specialists and generalists. A specialty in this sense is a combination of at least two out of three types of expertise: (i) functional expertise, or a focus on a specific skill level or specific job functions (such as lawyers, engineers, low-skilled blue-collar workers); (ii) industrial expertise, a focus on a specific end-market (such as food production or construction); and (iii) local expertise, a focus on a given region or city. Mono- and multi-specialists (which only differ from each other based on the number of specialties they serve) provide a focus on a given specialty with a dedicated sales force, specific processes and tailored value proposition focused typically on smaller volumes per client and a possible focus on a specific client size. Generalists, on the other hand serve a broad range of activities, clients, contract sizes and contract types with generalist sales forces, similar processes and offer less tailored solutions to a wide range of clients.

Subsection Title: Staffing Solutions Industry Size and Outlook
Subsubsection Text: The total market size for the staffing market in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and France was approximately €95 billion in revenue in 2019. After dropping to approximately €81 billion in 2020 due to the pandemic, the market recovered in 2021, totaling approximately €94 billion (the “Total Market”). These four key geographic markets are characterized by high average salaries, low unemployment and a high demand for scarcity-driven profiles and are well developed and mature in the temporary staffing and consulting fields. As a result of these trends, the number of temporary workers in these markets has increased significantly over the last decade. Our Total Market reflects the type of staffing markets for which we provide services in our primary geographies on a country basis, but it does not reflect the ----- narrower type of job candidates that many of our business units recruit and supply to clients or the specific end-market niches on which they concentrate. _Source: Staffing Industry Analysts (Global Staffing Industry Market Estimates and Forecast November 2022; Largest Staffing Firms in Belgium 2022; Largest Staffing Firms in the Netherlands and Market Overview (December 2021); Largest Staffing Firms in Germany (December 2021), Largest Staffing Firms in France and Market Overview (December 2021))_ As shown above, the staffing market in the countries in which we operate are expected to grow from €94 million in aggregate revenue for 2021 at a rate of 5% per annum to a total of €107 billion in aggregate revenue by 2024 in the absence of a downturn in the broader economy. We believe that such growth is to be expected in the future, driven by long-term structural changes in the employment market of each of our core geographic markets as well as a regulatory environment that allows for flexible staffing services.

Subsection Title: Short-Term Outlook in our key geographies
Subsubsection Text: Governments in each of our key markets are expecting the economic rebound to continue beyond 2021. As such, in 2022, Belgium real GDP is expected to grow by 2.8%, France real GDP by 2.6 %, Germany real GDP by 1.6% and the Netherlands real GDP by 4.6%, according to the European Commission forecasts from November 2022 (see table below). With regard to the staffing industry, recovery periods after a crisis usually favor temporary work and outsourcing as companies look to start scaling up their workforce while limiting the weight on their cost base. It is especially true in countries such as the key markets in which we operate in which the permanent workers are more protected, limiting companies’ flexibility. According to Staffing Industry Analysts, a global advisor on staffing and workforce solutions, the staffing market will experience strong rebound post Covid-19 pandemic. The table below shows SIA estimates of the actual year-on-year change in staffing revenue in 2020 and 2021, and how it is expected to grow in 2022, 2023 and 2024 for each of our key markets. ----- _Source: European Commission and Staffing Industry Analysts (Global Staffing Industry Market Estimates and Forecast November 2022)_

The most common situations in which temporary staffing is authorized: (i) as a replacement for a permanent worker; (ii) during temporary increase of work; (iii) execution of unusual work; (iv) ensuring artistic performance; and (v) in order to employ the job candidate as a permanent worker (insertion _professionnelle/instroom)._ In the following cases, recourse to temporary work is also prohibited or limited: - It is forbidden to resort to temporary employment for the replacement of an employee when the suspension of the performance of the employment contract of the permanent employee is due to a lack of work for economic reasons or in case of bad weather conditions - It is possible that restrictions on recourse to agency work are foreseen under collective or sectoral or company agreements - Temporary employment is still not allowed in certain public sectors - It is forbidden to resort to temporary work when a strike or lockout is in progress in an enterprise, and a temporary employment agency is prohibited from sending temporary workers to or keeping them at work in an enterprise that is in such a situation - When the user has not obtained permission from the union _Permits or other authorizations_ In order to engage in temporary staffing, a staffing services provider is required to obtain and maintain mandatory permits from each relevant regional authority within Belgium, which may have different eligibility requirements and conditions. A staffing services provider must obtain a permit from each region in which it wants to operate, even if its registered office is located in a different region in Belgium. Each region also has specific rules to allow, under certain conditions, a staffing services provider which already has a certification in one of the three regions of Belgium and wants to extend its activity nationally, to automatically get the same permit in the other regions. Permits for temporary staffing are given for an indefinite period or a definite period. _Contractual framework_ The employment of a temporary employee at a client requires the conclusion of: ----- - a commercial agreement between the staffing services provider and the client that must be put in place in writing within seven days from the commencement day of the temporary employee’s employment; - an employment agreement between the staffing services provider and the temporary employee that must be in writing and must, at a minimum, contain certain mandatory term; and - the intent to enter into an employment contract for temporary work between the staffing services provider and the temporary employee. The maximum duration of the temporary staffing and the applicable procedure to follow both vary according to the applicable scenario. _Employment terms and compensation_ The compensation of a job candidate may not be less than the compensation to which such job candidate would have been entitled had such job candidate been a regular permanent employee of the client. During the period of temporary agency work, the job candidate has the same rights as permanent employees with respect to access to the infrastructure and services of the client, unless different treatment is objectively reasonable. Furthermore, the rules on working time that apply to the client also apply to the job candidate, unless a specific exception is provided. _Termination_ In general, if an employment agreement between the staffing services provider and the temporary employee is terminated by either party, the non-terminating party is entitled to a termination compensation unless such termination is made in the case of force majeure. In the case the staffing services provider is the terminating party, no termination compensation is due if the termination is attributable to the client, and provided that the staffing solutions provider redeploys the dismissed job candidate to another client for the remaining period of the terminated agreement under identical working conditions and with an identical salary. No termination compensation is due to the temporary employee should he refuses such redeployment. Certain specific termination requirements need to be complied with in case the temporary employee is employed to replace a permanent employee. _Liability for damages_ Under Belgian law, only the client may be liable to a third party for damage suffered by such third party caused by a fault of the temporary employee in the course of performing his activities for the client. _Fines, penalties and other enforcements_ Civil, administrative and/or criminal penalties may be imposed in case of a breach of the prohibition of secondment, including breach of the abovementioned conditions to conduct temporary staffing activities: - potential nullity of the employment agreement between the employee and employer (or the staffing solutions provider); - the client and the job candidate are deemed to have entered into an employment agreement for an indefinite duration. However, the job candidate concerned may terminate this indefinite contract at any time, without notice and without paying the client or the actual employer any compensation. The job candidate may exercise this termination right up to the date on which their service to the client is scheduled to end; - the staffing solutions provider and the job candidate are deemed to have entered into an employment agreement for an indefinite duration. However, the job candidate concerned may ----- terminate this indefinite contract, without notice or any compensation, within seven days of commencing employment; - the staffing solutions provider and the client are jointly liable for the payment of the social security contributions, salary and benefits arising from the new employment agreement; - the client is liable for any damage caused by the job candidate (based on article 1384 of the Belgian Civil Code); - administrative or criminal fines may be imposed on the staffing solutions provider and on the client, as well as an operating ban. Fines are multiplied by the number of job candidates involved (maximum up to 100). _Health and safety obligations_ The client is responsible for the implementation of all rules on health and safety at the workplace and the welfare of a job candidate during the period in which he works for the client, as the client exercises authority over the job candidate is therefore deemed the actual employer during this period and. As a result, the client is required to comply with the welfare legislation for the job candidate, such as preparing workstation records, ensuring proper on-boarding process, making suitable personal protective equipment available and conducting investigation into any material accidents at work. The client must also otherwise guarantee the same level of protection of a job candidate in terms of health of safety, as guaranteed to its regular permanent employees. Before a job candidate starts working for a client, the client must provide the staffing solutions provider with all necessary information on the required professional qualifications and conditions for the job, as well as on the specific features of the work position. The staffing solutions provider, for its part, takes care of the occupational accident insurance and prior health surveillance of the temporary worker if the client’s job sheet requires it. The staffing solutions provider is thus responsible for prior health surveillance and also for mandatory vaccinations and has a role in maternity protection. Other health and safety obligations generally lie with the client, but in the case of authorized secondment of staff, such obligations remain with the staffing solutions provider (who are effectively employers) in accordance with the instructions relating to health and safety issues set out in services agreements.

Whereas most of our business is conducted in the regulatory framework outlined above, we are subject to certain additional regulation based on the specific nature of the services we provide in each jurisdiction. Below we describe certain features of the relevant laws and regulations that apply to these services. _Temporary outsourcing of employees_ Certain of our Powerhouses also conduct consulting and secondment staffing (“temporary outsourcing”) activities in Belgium. As with temporary staffing, temporary outsourcing is not considered as prohibited secondment when a number of strict legal rules are met. An agreement must be signed between a contractor (which would be the staffing solutions provider) and a client to provide a certain service, perform a certain task or work on a specific project, rather than the provision of staff (which could be considered a prohibited secondment), including a detailed list of the instructions which the client may give to the temporary staff. Clients may indeed give instructions to the temporary staff, provided that instructions, subject to certain exceptions, (a) are defined in a written agreement between the consulting agency (in our case, the staffing solutions provider) and the client, the instructions do not ----- erode the staffing company’s authority over its staff, and are communicated to the client’s works council; or (b) relate to the client’s health and safety obligations. _Temporary outsourcing of self-employed workers_ Belgian law also allows for outsourcing self-employed workers or freelancers only when no party exercises an employer’s authority over the worker. If the parties (incorrectly) qualify their relationship as an independent relationship rather than an employment relationship, this can result in specific liabilities for the party that is considered to be the employer in the event of a re-characterization of the self-employed relationship into an employment relationship. Such a determination is made based on all factual circumstances including the following four main criteria: the will of the parties as expressed in the agreement, the level of freedom to organize working time, the level of freedom to organize work, and the level of hierarchical control. For specific sectors (such as construction, transport, cleaning, security and surveillance and agriculture), certain legal presumptions apply. Re-qualification criteria for Belgium are set out in a Program Act of December 27, 2006 and as well as in case law. _Search and selection services_ The staffing solutions provider may also use its pool of job candidates to provide recruitment services and also arrange for initial placements. Regional authorities may have different eligibility requirements and conditions to conduct search and selections services.

The below graph, based on data from Federgon, the Belgian federation of staffing agencies, illustrates the year-on-year growth evolution of the number of hours worked daily by temporary agency workers, seasonally and calendar-basis adjusted data, in Belgium starting January 2020. _Source: Federgon_ The temporary hours worked experienced a strong decline in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, followed by a sharp rebound in April 2021, to then come back to a more flattish state. The temporary work sector in Belgium showed an extraordinary capacity for resilience in 2020. In March and April 2020, during the first confinement, the sector experienced a gigantic decline, with a loss of almost half of its volume of activity. The sector then gradually recovered over the months. In Belgium there was a total decline of 15.2% in 2020. Belgium had its peak levels in temporary work in April 2021 (59.9%), with the increase in the number of hours worked daily by temporary agency workers was driven by the rise in activity in the service voucher sector. _Source: World Bank_ ----- _Source: Eurostat, as of the fourth quarter of each year, unless stated_ In Belgium, in line with the rest of our key geographies, we can see a tight labor market with increasing demand due to macro-economic uncertainty and labor scarcity. Belgium unemployment rate has been growing since its lowest value in 2019 (5.4%), although it still was relatively low at 6.4% in 2021, below the last 10 years average of 7.1%. In the second quarter of 2022, there were no less than 213,822 vacancies in Belgium (an increase of 24% compared to the second quarter of 2021) and reaching its historical peak levels according to Eurostat. According to SIA, Belgium staffing revenue was €8.6 billion in 2021 and is expected to increase by 4% in 2022 and 6% in 2023. In Belgium, secondment of staff is prohibited, except in specific cases provided by law. Secondment of staff is defined as when an employer “lends out” its employees to a third party for the services of these employees, and that the third party exercises part of the employer’s authority over such employees. The compliance obligations regarding welfare at work, however, remain with the employer and not the third party. The third party generally does not assume the full authority of the employer over the employees on secondment, and any authority the third party has over the employees will have to be expressly specified in a written agreement executed between the employer and the third party, and any such contractual authority will have to be exercised according to the provisions in the written agreement and generally does not erode the employer’s authority over its employee in any way. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the client can give instructions relating to health and safety issues to the employees concerned. ----- Exceptions to this general prohibition include: temporary staffing (also called “temporary agency work”) and other specific situations such as permitted posting for a limited time, posting within the framework of an employment pathway recognized by the region, posting as part of an employer grouping and specific posting in the public sector. In the case of temporary staffing, a job candidate (the employee, also called “interim worker”) is hired by a staffing services provider (the employer) with the intention of being put at the disposal of a client of such staffing services provider. The staffing solutions provider remains the sole legal employer, while transferring the exercise of the actual employer’s authority to the client during the temporary assignment (i.e., the client will give instructions to the job candidate with regard to the work to be carried out). Conditions to the recruiting of job candidates for the purpose of putting them at the disposal of a client are strictly defined and the working conditions of such job candidates are required by law to be similar to the working conditions of the permanent employees of the client executing the same job. Temporary staffing is mainly regulated by the Act of July 24, 1987 on Temporary Work, Interim Work and Secondment of Employees to Users (as amended) (the “Act on Temporary Work”), which implements the Temporary Agency Work Directive. Specific rules on temporary staffing apply in some sectors, such as the construction sector.

In France, the loan of a job candidate (worker) to a client is strictly regulated under the French Labor Code.
