Except in certain limited circumstances such as temporary staffing (portage salarial; which requires specific accreditation) or temporary work agencies, loaning workers to a client may only be provided on a not-for-profit basis; any costs invoiced by the staffing solutions provider to the client beyond the employee’s salary, social security charges and professional expenses is prohibited. Additionally, such arrangements require an amendment in the employment contract between the staffing solutions provider and employee, an inter-company agreement between the client and the staffing solutions provider, and the consultation and consent of the relevant works councils. _Permits or other authorizations_ Staffing solutions providers using the contractual framework described below do not require any permit or authorization for their business in France, other than standard registrations applicable to every company operating in France with its own employees. _Contractual framework_ Staffing solutions providers may offer consultants or job candidates to a client on a temporary and forprofit basis under the framework of a services agreement (contrat de prestation de services), given certain conditions. A qualifying services agreement encompasses temporary services provided to a client specific to a certain project, involving specialized skills, techniques, or know-how. Additionally, for workers to be provided on a for-profit basis under a services agreement, their labor must be closely related to the main purpose or project of the services agreement and be included within the broader services being provided by the staffing solutions provider to the client. Key factors as to whether a for-profit staffing under a services agreement complies with the regulatory requirements are the following: - Specific know-how of the service provider: the services must require specialized skills or knowhow not existing within the client. ----- - Authority over job candidates: even if the services must be performed in coordination with the management of the client, the service provider must retain authority over the job candidates assigned to a client. - Equipment to carry out the work: the services provider must have and use its own equipment, such as gloves, shoes, glasses and safety harness, to carry out the work, and the client must not lend the equipment necessary to provide the agreed services. _Employment terms and compensation_ Compensation: must be calculated on a flat-fee basis and may not be calculated on an hourly rate basis, as this would suggest that the provision of services is limited to the provision of labor. _Termination_ Termination of employment agreements is governed by standard rules and regulations applicable to every company operating in France with its own employees. If the staffing solutions provider has entered into an indefinite-term employment agreement with the job candidate, the employment contract can be terminated by the staffing solutions provider for real and serious cause at any time provided that the applicable notice period is complied with. The staffing solutions provider and the job candidate can also enter into a mutual termination agreement, which would then be ratified by the labor authorities. Finally, the job candidate may also resign from their position provided that the applicable notice period is complied with. If the staffing solutions provider has entered into a fixed-term employment contract with the job candidate, the employment contract can only be prematurely terminated (1) if the parties so agree, (2) in case of gross misconduct, (3) in case of force majeure, (4) if the employee is declared unfit to work by the occupational doctor, or (5) if the employee has found an indefinite-term employment. In any other cases, the employment contract runs its course until its initially-set termination date. _Liability for damages_ Under French law, the client is liable for all damages done to a third party, on the worksite or during work. However, staffing solutions providers remain liable for costs related to injuries caused by occupational accidents suffered by its in-house employees in the course of their work. _Fines, penalties or other enforcements_ If the abovementioned contractual framework is not complied with, the services agreement could be qualified as an illicit loan of workers or the criminal offence of bargaining, for which the client and the staffing solutions providers (including their respective legal representatives) can be held criminally liable. Penalties for such violations can carry a maximum fine of €375,000 and other potential penalties for a client or staffing solutions provider, and a maximum fine of €75,000 or a maximum prison sentence of five years for the legal representatives of the client or service provider. _Health and safety obligations_ As job candidates are officially assigned to and working on the client’s premises, the client must comply with labor and workplace regulations with respect to assigned job candidates, such as health and safety regulations. In this respect, if protection equipment must be worn by the job candidates, such equipment must be provided by the staffing solutions providers. Obligations relating to occupational medical surveillance are also the responsibility of the staffing solutions providers. -----

The chart below shows the evolution of the France Staffing market, based on data from SIA, compared to Abylsen, based on company information. While the France Staffing market has grown at a 1.8% CAGR over the 2008-2021 period, it can be observed Abylsen has outperformed the French Staffing market growing at a 14.1% CAGR. Abylsen’s remarkable organic growth is driven by its positioning within the engineering and consulting sector, which demonstrates House of HR resilience through-the-cycle but also during downturns. While the France Staffing market had negative growth during the global financial crisis (0.7)% CAGR 20082011) and the Covid-19 pandemic ((4.6)% CAGR 2019-2021), Abylsen managed to outperform the market growing at 31.9% and 0.1%. ----- _Source: SIA and Company information Source: World Bank_ The unemployment rate in France has had a declining trend since 2015, compressing from 10.4% to reach 8.1% in 2021. 2020 and 2021 have presented the lowest unemployment rates since 2009 according to the World Bank, and the trend is expected to continue decreasing in the upcoming years. While the French market saw its combined revenue drop sharply in 2020 (a decrease of 23%) according to SIA, the 50 largest firms outperformed the market as their combined revenue decreased by 19%, compared to 2019. They expect further consolidation happening in this market, primarily benefiting national groups, competing together to become the largest homespun staffing group. Despite French economic growth rate being downgraded due to supply chain difficulties and the energy shocks stemming from the war in Ukraine, SIA expects positive forward momentum after speaking with several players in the market. Permanent placement is particularly strong. Data from SIA shows that temporary work turnover increased 13% in February 2022 YoY, and the number of hours worked increased by 10.5%. According to SIA data, the size of the French market was €30.4 billion in 2021, up 19% from €25.6 billion in 2020. In 2020 there were approximately 2,000 staffing firms in France, according to SIA. The French staffing market is expected to increase by 6% in 2022 and 1% in 2023 according to SIA. ----- The description below sets out the current statutory framework governing our operations in France.

Dutch law defines a “temporary agency agreement” as a special type of employment agreement under article 7:690 of the Dutch Civil Code (“DCC”) whereby the employee is made available by the staffing solutions provider (the employer) to a third party (the client) in the context of the employer’s business activities, to perform work under the management and supervision of the third party. In effect, the law states that the relationship between a staffing services provider and a temporary agency worker qualifies as an employment agreement. In principle, there is no requirement for an agreement between the client and the temporary employee. Under the current definition, as interpreted by the Dutch Supreme Court, both the traditional forms of temporary agency work as well as payrolling qualify as temporary agency work. However, for payrolling, there is a separate legal and contractual framework, as set out below under “Payrolling”. _Permits or other authorizations_ The SNA quality mark (SNA-keurmerk) is an accreditation for staffing solutions providers. This quality mark is provided by the foundation Stichting Normering en Arbeid on the basis of two NEN standards: NEN 4400-1 for Dutch companies and NEN 4400-2 for foreign companies. Although not mandatory for staffing solutions providers to obtain the SNA quality mark, it is important in practice. _Contractual framework_ In case of a general temporary agency agreement, the staffing solutions provider has more flexibility in framing the contractual relationship with the job candidate, including the possibility of applying more fixed term contracts and of terminating the contract if the client retracts the assignment. On the other hand, in case of a secondment or consultancy agreement, the staffing solutions providers generally have an indefinite term contract with the job candidate, and such contract cannot be terminated even if the client retracts the assignment. ----- In addition to Dutch employment law, the largest temporary staffing organization in industry (the “ABU”) and the largest Dutch trade unions have agreed on a collective labor agreement for the temporary employment agency industry (the “ABU CLA”). The current ABU CLA for 2021 to 2023 was declared contractually binding for the sector as of August 25, 2022, which applies to all staffing solutions providers that fall within its scope—irrespective of whether a staffing solutions provider is a member of the ABU. In effect, the ABU CLA provides that, over three phases, as temporary agency workers are employed for longer periods of time, the temporary agency worker gradually becomes entitled to more job security and secondary benefits, such as a pension and training. There is also another collective labor agreement for staffing solutions providers known as the NBBU CLA. The NBBU CLA is not declared generally binding and only applies to staffing solutions providers who are a member of NBBU, another employers’ organization for the industry. Staffing solutions providers who are a member of NBBU, are explicitly excluded from the scope of the ABU CLA. Although they are formally still two different CLAs, the current ABU CLA and NBBU CLA contain substantively the same employment terms and conditions. In general, the DCC imposes restrictions on (i) the number of successive fixed term employment agreements that the employer (in this case, staffing solutions provider) can enter into with an employee and (ii) the total duration of such fixed term employment agreements. If an employer enters into more than three successive fixed term employment agreements, or if the total duration of the successive fixed term employment agreements is more than three years, the last fixed employment agreement is converted into an indefinite term employment agreement by operation of law. This rule is referred to as the statutory “chain rule” (ketenregeling). When an employment agreement qualifies as a temporary agency agreement, this has significant implications for the statutory possibilities to maintain a ‘flexible’ employment relationship. By way of a collective labor agreement, it is possible to deviate even further from the chain rule as follows: (i) The maximum number of successive fixed term employment agreements is six and the maximum total duration of such fixed term employment agreements is three years. In addition, the ABU CLA provides that the exemption from the chain rule for temporary agency agreements is extended from 26 weeks to 52 weeks of employment. During the exemption period, it is possible to enter into an indefinite number of fixed term employment agreements, and the number and duration of the fixed term employment agreements during this period do not count toward the maximum total number and duration. (ii) In practice, the above means that a temporary agency agreement can be a “flexible” employment relationship for a total of four years, with the first disapplying the chain rule and with a temporary employment clause (as described below) and the next three years with up to six fixed term employment agreements. (iii) Further, it is possible to agree on a written provision whereby the employment agreement between the employee and the staffing solutions provider terminates by operation of law if the posting of the employee at the client ends at the request of the client. This provision is referred to as the “temporary employment clause” (uitzendbeding). The ABU CLA provides that such provision is valid during the first 52 weeks instead of 26 weeks of employment. _Employment terms and compensation_ An employee that is made available to a client is in principle entitled to receive the same basic employment terms and conditions as the employees of the client working in the same or equivalent positions (article 8 of the Placement of Personnel by Intermediaries Act). The basic employment terms and conditions include salary and other compensation, working hours and vacation entitlement. The ABU CLA validly limits the number of compensatory elements that need to be applied. Variable ----- compensation, for example, is excluded. Limited exceptions apply for a so-called “allocation group” (i.e., persons appointed by the government as having a “distance to the labor market” and persons without a basic qualification who will follow qualifying training via the staffing solutions provider). These employees receive wages determined by the staffing solutions provider in accordance with the ABU CLA. Furthermore, after one year of employment on the basis of a so-called ‘on-call’ agreement (in short, without a fixed number of working hours), temporary agency workers (and other on-call employees) should be offered a fixed number of working hours that is the average of their working hours over the last twelve months. In addition, in case of an ‘on-call’ agreement, employers are required to pay full compensation if an assignment is altered within four days prior to commencement. _Termination_ A staffing solutions provider may terminate an employment agreement in principle (i) if the posting of the employee with the client ends within the term of the temporary employment clause, if contractually provided for, (ii) against the end of the employment agreement, subject to an advance notice of one month or (iii) with permission from the cantonal court. In general, if an employer wishes to terminate a fixed term employment agreement before the end of its term or an indefinite term employment agreement, it must show that it has a lawful ground for termination and that the employee cannot be redeployed in another suitable position within the group within a reasonable period of time. Employees, including temporary workers, are entitled to a transitional payment upon termination of employment at the employer’s initiative (which includes the non-renewal of a fixed term employment agreement at the employer’s initiative). _Liability for damages_ Typically, liability towards a client for damage suffered by that client as a result of fault of its temporary agency workers is borne by the client. Occasionally, however, a staffing solutions provider may be liable for such damage. _Fines, penalties or other enforcements_ The law provides specific penalties for non-compliance with the labor law, and the Dutch Labor Inspectorate enforces fines and penalties in relation to any violations of the labor law. Under the Foreign Nationals Employment Act, an employer is obligated to ensure its employees are allowed to work in the Netherlands. If a foreign employee works in the country without a valid permit, the employer risks a fine. A fine can also be imposed if there is no valid registration in the trade register of the staffing services provider in accordance with the Work Allocation by Intermediaries Act. An employer is also obligated to adhere to the work hours requirements set out in the Working Hours Act, and any violation of this law may result in a fine. In addition, the Dutch Labor Inspectorate also enforces the application of the “wage correlation norm”. This norm prescribes that minimum standards and wage components should be applied to temporary agency workers on par with regular employees in comparable positions. _Health and safety obligations_ The staffing solutions provider is obliged to assure that it receives, and makes available, a hazard identification and risk assessment (risico-inventarisatie en—evaluatie) from the client. Furthermore, the staffing solutions provider is obliged to inform the temporary agency worker of the risks at the workplace. In the event of non-compliance with these obligations, the staffing solutions provider may be liable towards its temporary agency workers for damages as a result of inadequate working conditions at the workplace. The temporary agency workers can also bring a claim for damages against ----- the relevant client, so the temporary agency workers may, at their discretion, make a claim against the staffing solutions provider, the client or both.

Whereas most of our business is conducted in the regulatory framework outlined above, we are subject to certain additional regulation based on the specific nature of the services we provide in each jurisdiction. Below we describe certain features of the relevant laws and regulations that apply to these services. _Payrolling_ In the case of payrolling, the agency takes on the administrative and financial obligations for, but is not involved in the recruitment of, consultants. Furthermore, the consultants are (in principle) exclusively provided to one client. Although payrolling is formally considered a form of temporary agency work, there is a legal distinction between “regular” temporary agency agreements and payrolling agreements. Under the new legislation that entered into force on January 1, 2020, the rules regarding payrolling have been significantly amended. The ABU CLA does not apply to payrolling agreements anymore as of 1 January 2020 (with the exception of limited transitional arrangements). Payroll employees are entitled to all terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions (including certain pension entitlements as from January 1, 2021). The same rules relating to fixed term employment agreements and termination of employment agreements apply for payroll employees as for regular employees of the client. A temporary employment clause and the additional flexibility to enter into fixed term employment agreements as set out above are no longer applicable to payroll employees as of 1 January 2020. Specifically for payrolling, the Dismissal Regulation (Ontslagregeling) contains stricter rules for showing a reasonable ground for termination. For a payroll employer, the fact that the posting of an employee at the third party ends will not be a reasonable ground to terminate the employment agreement with such employee. Instead, the situation at the third party will be taken into account to determine whether a reasonable termination ground exists. _Outsourcing of self-employed workers_ We are subject to the Dutch law on deregulation of labor relations (Wet deregulering beoordeling _arbeidsrelaties) (the “DBA”). Pursuant to the DBA, different rules apply depending on whether the_ labor relation is an independent relationship or an employment relationship. For example, in the case of an employment relationship, the employer must withhold and pay payroll taxes. In addition, the employer must usually continue to pay wages during illness and vacations. A determination of whether a relationship is an employment relationship or an independent relationship is made based on all factual circumstances, including the following three main criteria for establishing an employment relationship: one party undertakes to (i) perform work personally (ii) under the supervision of the other party (iii) for remuneration. If the parties (incorrectly) qualify their relationship as an independent relationship rather than an employment relationship, this can result in specific liabilities for the party that is considered to be the employer in the event of a re-characterization of the self-employed relationship into an employment relationship. _Search and selection services_ Often, in addition to staffing services, staffing solutions providers also provide staff recruitment services to their commercial clients. The staffing solutions provider can use its pool of job candidates for their recruitment and also arrange for initial placements. Rendering recruitment services does not require an additional permit. ----- _Quality assurance_ We are subject to the professional standards mandated by the _Landelijk Kwaliteitsbureau CBM, a professional standards regulator that assesses and oversees quality requirements in relation to curatorship, guardianship and mentorship. In addition, a new quality framework has been proposed in 2021 by the Nederlandse Vereniging voor _Veiligheidskunde (the “NVVK”), a professional association actively involved in promoting safety_ standards. NVVK membership is a requirement for companies engaging in client contracts. Under this framework, two certifying organizations have been identified to carry out audit on NVVK members. The scope of the audit process, plan, procedures and reporting requirements are currently still being developed. _Data protection_ We are subject to data protection regulations, including the GDPR, in respect of employee personal data that we process. We occasionally process employee medical data.

The below graph, based on data from ABU, the Dutch Federation of Private Employment Agencies, illustrates the evolution of the total amount of hours worked by temporary workers in the Netherlands starting January 2020. _Source: ABU_ Following the loosening of restrictions in May 2020, the staffing industry in the Netherlands began recovering from June onwards and gradually narrowed the gap with 2019 levels. Since reaching its peak in mid-2021, the evolution of the total amount of hours worked by temporary workers in the Netherlands kept growing at a stable rate until December 2021, when it experienced a 14% decline, followed by a rebound of 3% in January 2022. _Source: World Bank_ ----- _Source: Eurostat, as of the fourth quarter of each year, unless stated_ In the Netherlands, the unemployment rate reached a 15-year low in 2019 (3.4%), slightly increasing to 4.0% in 2021, although still 1% below the past 15-year average (5.0%). Job vacancies is at its peak with approximately 450,000 vacancies in the third quarter of 2022. This current high level of vacancies offers House of HR additional protection in a downturn scenario. Based on data from the global financial crisis, a reduction of approximately 100,000 in job vacancies would still result in approximately 350,000 unfilled positions. The description below sets out the current statutory framework governing temporary staffing in the Netherlands.

Jurisdiction under AÜG is established where there is a connection to German territory; it thus regulates both domestic staffing as well as cross-border staffing, for example where job candidates are being assigned to Germany by foreign staffing solutions providers to perform services on German territory. _Permits or other authorizations_ In Germany, temporary staffing is generally impermissible without a valid permit from the relevant authorities. If the staffing solutions provider does not have the permit required, an employment relationship between the client and the job candidate will be assumed pursuant to the AÜG, commencing at the time at which the work is to commence as set forth in the agreement between the client and the staffing solutions provider, unless the job candidate objects and declares to the Federal Employment Agency a preference to stay with the staffing solutions provider. To protect the client, German law requires the staffing solutions provider to confirm in the agreement with the client that it has obtained the necessary permit. Procedurally, permits are typically granted for one-year terms, with the option to convert into an unlimited term permit following the grant of three consecutive one-year permits. This permit is specific to the staffing solutions provider. Permits may be denied, or revoked if already granted, for statutory reasons such as the unreliability of the staffing solutions provider, noncompliance with safety and health regulations, or non-compliance with the AÜG. _Contractual framework_ The general contractual framework is that a staffing solutions provider concludes an employment agreement with a job candidate and then places this job candidate with a client. No employment agreement is concluded between the job candidate and the client, but the client is granted the right to instruct and direct the job candidate based on an agreement between the staffing solutions provider and the client (“German Service Agreement”). Additionally, recent changes in the AÜG have imposed specific mandatory provisions in German Service Agreements, including, as mentioned, a representation that the aforementioned permit has been granted, a description of the parameters of the ----- services provided, a description of occupational qualifications, and details regarding working conditions, such as wages and benefits. The job candidates assigned under the engagement can either be named in the German Service Agreement itself or separately at a later stage with explicit reference to the German Service Contract. The German Service Agreement must explicitly be titled a “staffing agreement” (Arbeitnehmerüberlassungsvertrag) and must be signed by wet ink or a qualified electronic means signature before the job candidate commences at the client. Since the job candidate remains the staffing solutions provider’s permanent employee, the provider retains certain obligations from the employment relationship, such as paying the social security contributions. Moreover, the provider must inform its job candidates before each assignment that they will be placed as a temporary worker and provide a written copy of the essential contents of the assignment. Finally, the staffing solutions provider must involve its works council (if there is one) when the job candidate is hired and dismissed. All such job candidates, being full members of the staffing solutions provider’s staff, can vote in and run for works council elections. _Employment terms and compensation_ In order to emphasize the “temporary” nature of temporary staffing, the AÜG amendments provide that the same job candidate cannot be assigned to the same client for more than 18 consecutive months. A period of at least three months and one day where the job candidate is not employed at a given client can reset this maximum 18 month period. Exceptions to this maximum period are only possible by way of collective bargaining agreements of the client’s industrial sector or works council agreements on the basis of such collective bargaining agreements. Though the employment of the job candidate is temporary for the client, all such job candidates must typically remain employees of the staffing solutions provider under the German Act on Part-Time and Temporary Employment (Teilzeit- und Befristungsgesetz), which applies to all temporary employees in Germany. During the assignment, German law requires the main working conditions of the job candidate, including the compensation, to be the same as those of a comparable permanent employee. Compensation comprises everything the job candidate would have been entitled to, had such worker been hired directly by the client (equal pay), and includes, among other things, holiday pay, sick pay, allowances and benefits and must be paid by the staffing solutions provider as the employer. Therefore, the staffing solutions provider has the administrative burden to amend the job candidate’s compensation with every placement in line with on-site conditions. Derogations from the main working conditions are possible on the basis of a collective bargaining agreement. However, with regard to equal pay, the possibility of any derogation is limited, because all job candidates must receive compensation equal to that of the client’s comparable permanent workers after nine months. A longer derogation period can only be agreed by collective bargaining agreements granting a gradual increase of the candidate’s to the level of the permanent employees’ compensation within 15 months, beginning in the seventh week of the temporary employment. Derogations from equal pay are also never applicable with regard to job candidates who have been employed by the client (or its group) during the last six months preceding the placement. _Termination_ If the staffing solutions provider wishes to terminate a job candidate’s employment agreement after six months of employment with the staffing solutions provider, it must establish that (i) it has reasonable grounds for termination; (ii) the job candidate cannot be redeployed to another suitable position with the staffing solutions provider or with a client within a reasonable period of time; and if the termination is due to economic reasons, (iii) that termination of employment was the last option. Since the German legislator wants to ease the transition from temporary to permanent work, it is forbidden for the staffing solutions provider to agree on a commission fee with the job candidate if the job candidate concludes an employment contract with the client he has been placed with after his placement. However, the staffing solutions provider is allowed to invoice the client for a commission fee. ----- _Liability for damages_ Liability for damages can be provided for in the German Service Agreement between the staffing solutions provider and the client, so they may agree on a disclaimer of liability in favor of the staffing solutions provider as well as in favor of the client or they may limit the amount of liabilities to the extent covered by insurance. Generally, liability for the staffing solutions provider is limited to the selection of qualification (Auswahlverschulden). The job candidate is liable for breaches of duties towards the client and the staffing solutions provider on a sliding scale, being fully liable only when he has violated his duties intentionally. _Fines, penalties or other enforcements_ Neglecting or violating any of the abovementioned legal requirements can lead to different severe legal penalties, based on the nature and seriousness of the breach. If the staffing solutions provider has no permit, the German Service Agreement is not compliant with the formal requirements, or the maximum staffing period is exceeded, the employment agreement is deemed void and the job candidate is considered to be an employee of the client, unless the job candidate objects and declares to the Federal Employment Agency a preference to stay with the staffing solutions provider. In addition, not complying with the permit regulations may lead to a fine of up to €30,000 for each individual case. The same fine may be imposed when the maximum staffing period has been exceeded. Higher penalties (up to €500,000) may be imposed by the German authorities if the equal pay rules have been violated or if the client has used the job candidate as a replacement for an employee on strike. Penalties may result from misclassifications of job candidates as self-employed, for example when placing job candidates with a client as free contractors, consultants, secondees or other similar arrangements, when they are de facto employees placed under a staffing arrangement. False selfemployment may have severe consequences both in employment and social security law (for example, obligations to retroactively pay social security contributions for the employer and employee), tax law (liability for income tax). If the staffing solutions provider is found to have intentionally violated the law, it may also face criminal law penalties. There have not yet been many interpretive decisions of the Federal Labor Court of the 2017 amendment of the AÜG and many details are still in dispute. _Health and safety obligations_ Job candidates officially assigned to and working for the client are fully integrated into the client’s organization; as a result, the client must comply with labor and workplace regulations, including any health and safety regulations with respect to those assigned job candidates. Both the staffing solutions provider and the client are responsible for the overall well-being of the job candidate including the job candidate’s physical and mental health, (such as by supervising working times and rest periods, protecting against unfair treatment and sexual harassment), personal data and (if applicable) his private working material. The client is required to inform job candidates prior to their assignment of any specific qualifications and professional skills they need to possess. It is the client’s obligation to inform the job candidate about dangers the job candidate may face at assignment as well as explain safety measures.

Whereas most of our business is conducted in the regulatory framework outlined above, we are subject to certain additional regulation based on the specific nature of the services we provide in each jurisdiction. Below we describe certain features of the relevant laws and regulations that apply to these specialized services. ----- _Construction Industry_ Providing staffing services in the construction industry is generally prohibited by law, although it is possible for a staffing solutions provider who is active in the construction industry to obtain a specific permit. _Meat Industry_ Regulations relating to the meat industry has become stricter since 2021, and providing staffing services in this industry is now allowed only through collective bargain agreement, and it comes with various other limitations depending on the number of job candidates working at clients. _Search and Selection Services_ Often, in addition to staffing services, staffing solutions providers also provide staff recruitment services to their commercial clients. The staffing solutions provider can use its pool of job candidates for their recruitment and also arrange for initial placements. Rendering recruitment services does not require an additional permit, but the staffing solutions provider requires a prior trade registration (Gewerbeanmeldung) for such services.

The below graph, based on data from Statistik der Bundesagentur für Arbeit, illustrates the evolution of the number of temporary workers in Germany, which has been generally increasing since the beginning of the century. _Source: Statistik der Bundesagentur für Arbeit_ During the financial crisis of 2008, the number of temporary workers decreased substantially to reach 580,000 in April 2009 (year-over-year decrease of 24.0%), although it recovered promptly with a yearover-year growth of 23.9% in April 2010. Similarly, temporary workers also declined down during the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020, followed by a recovery in the beginning of 2021, with the number of temporary workers now being higher than pre-Covid-19 pandemic levels. The staffing market has since recovered from the Covid-19 pandemic, and since the lifting of the restrictions, the number of job registrations has then consistently increased. Although Germany has been relatively effective in managing the pandemic, the country's sizeable manufacturing sector is highly export-oriented and exposed to both supply-chain disruption and shrinking global demand. As a result, SIA estimates that total German staffing market revenue fell by 10% in 2020. Nevertheless, Germany has experienced substantial growth in 2021 (12%), which is generally set to continue at a more subdued rate in 2022 (5%) and continuing a decline into 2023 (4%) according to SIA. According to the German Federal Employment Agency, there were approximately 850,000 temporary workers in Sep 2022, a year-on-year increase of 1%, although still down 21% from the preCovid-19 pandemic peak in November 2017. ----- _Source: World Bank Source: Eurostat, as of the fourth quarter of each year, unless stated_ Amongst the four key geographies, Germany has experienced the largest decline in unemployment rates. From 8.7% in 2007, it reached 3.5% in 2021. Job vacancies have almost tripled since 2007, growing from approximately 600,000 to 1.8 million in the third quarter of 2022 according to Eurostat. In Germany, temporary staffing is regulated by the Act on Staffing (Arbeitnehmeru¨berlassungsgesetz) (“AÜG”), which has been substantially amended over the years, most recently in 2017. The focus of the 2017 amendment was to strengthen permanent employment; as a result, a maximum period for temporary staffing has been introduced and formal requirements have been tightened up as has the equal pay principle.

Demand for the types of solutions we provide has increased and is expected to continue growing in the future, once markets have recovered from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, due to a number of positive secular trends: _Aging populations. As the population of our target markets ages and workers exit the labor pool, there_ has been an increase in competition among employers to fill the gaps left behind. This has left an opening for staffing intermediaries, especially those like our Group that have a proven track record of identifying and matching the right candidates to the right jobs, to fill these vacant positions with qualified talent. Additionally, a scarcity of talent for certain roles is driving wages up, which in turn can increase the pricing power of staffing firms for the solutions and staffing we provide. _Technological changes. In recent years, candidates are increasingly turning to online job boards when_ seeking out a position, particularly through traffic generated by mobile devices. At the same time, clients expect more efficient services at a lower cost that can only be delivered through the use of digital tools. We have also seen an increase in the number of passive job seekers who apply through targeted advertisements on social media when they were not actively searching for a position at the time. The market has also experienced the development of new platforms, such as Uber Works in the United States, which, however, announced in May 2020 the closure of their operations in light of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to their official press release. Such platforms may be considered competitors, since ----- they sometimes are able to attract people directly to be employed for them via freelance or independent status. Nevertheless, such platforms lack a human touch in the services they provide, and authorities in different countries monitor fair treatment of workers by these platforms and are looking to ensure that there is no unfair competition with other forms of labor. Such monitoring is especially common in the EU, where regulation and labor unions are stronger than in other countries. Career mobility and the need to re-skill._ Millennial workers, especially highly skilled ones, are increasingly mobile and seeking a varied career path, driving the need for re-skilling. This re-skilling can be provided through both formal and on-the-job training that is typically provided as part of temporary work agreements. _Diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility. As the diversity trend becomes mainstream_ across clients, service providers have an opportunity to provide increasing value to their clients by tapping into broad, international pools of candidates. _Increased premium on quality of life. It is increasingly difficult to find qualified candidates to fill some_ roles that offer long hours and difficult conditions, as younger generations of workers are placing a fairly large premium on happiness in their personal and professional lives. This has contributed to a supply and demand gap in certain end-markets and as a result, staffing solutions providers with a more flexible and agile organization and the ability to source and place candidates successfully, are in greater demand. _Outsourcing and offshoring. Financial pressures on companies, especially the small- to medium-sized_ enterprises (“SMEs”), have incentivized them to outsource many of their non-core functions. Further, due to accelerated business rhythms, companies are increasingly looking to obtain immediately available resources. This has led to an increased need for temporary staffing and outsourced support that can be provided rapidly on short notice. _Better economics. Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower_ job security has been a driver of demand in the recent years. As a result of these secular trends, both employers and workers increasingly turn towards flexible staffing models, driving demand for extended workforce solutions. According to an external consultant analysis, in Belgium, Netherlands and France, the number of workers that are part of the extended workforce (i.e., contractors and other freelancers) has grown from 2016 to 2021 at a CAGR of 3.9%, 2.5% and 4.4%, respectively. These growth rates are above those registered in the total working population, which over the same period has grown at a CAGR of 1.0% in Belgium, 1.3% in the Netherlands and 0.4% in France. This is also evidenced by the growth in penetration of the extended workforce as part of the total workforce, with penetration rates in 2021 ranging from 7.2% in France to 10.2% in the Netherlands. _Source: External consultant analysis. [1] % of total working population_ -----

We operate primarily in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands in a variety of specialties with a combined total market of approximately €94 billion in revenue as of 2021. We expect our Total Market to grow at a rate of approximately 5% per annum in revenues to an estimated €107 billion by 2024, a growth rate above that of the broader staffing solutions industry, driven by a variety of favorable end-market dynamics leading to increases in outsourcing and billing rates. We operate through ten business units in two segments: engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions. The discussion below focuses on the key factors affecting each of our business units.

Abylsen is an engineering and consulting Powerhouse headquartered in France, with operations in France, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Italy and Luxembourg. Abylsen operates in a competitive but fragmented market, where it is a relatively small company which challenges primarily large global consulting or mid-sized global companies or brands, as well as regional companies or brands. _End-market overview and drivers_ Historically, growth in Abylsen’s Addressable Market has been driven by companies’ spending on research and development. It is expected that, once markets have recovered from the Covid-19 pandemic, such spending will increase again going forwards and will be the key driver of growth in Abylsen’s Addressable Market, as end-markets reliant on research and development (such as the automotive, energy, pharmaceutical and aerospace industries) respond and adapt to changing technologies for their sustained growth. Additional factors such as increased outsourcing penetration (France is already one of the most mature countries for outsourcing of research and development) and increasing billing rates (moderate due to pre-existing difficulties in sourcing engineers in France) are likely to further drive market growth in the future. According to external consultant analysis, Abylsen’s addressable market is expected to grow at low to mid-single digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ According to external consultant analysis, competition in Abylsen’s Addressable Market includes a lot of players but is highly fragmented, with the four largest players capturing less than 30% of the market in 2021. According to external consultant analysis, the market is defined by three types of competitors: (i) large global consulting firms (including Capgemini Engineering (formerly Altran), Alten, Akka and Assystem), (ii) mid-size global/regional firms (such as Sii, MCA, agap2 and Davidson) and (iii) smaller regional/local firms. Abylsen falls into the mid-size global/regional category, with a smaller market share than the four large global consulting firms. Nevertheless, Abylsen has been growing faster and achieved a higher EBITDA margin than its larger competitors, reaching 17.5% in 2021, compared to competitors such as Alten, which had an EBITDA margin of 12.3%.

Redmore is a provider of specialized secondment and consulting services in our engineering and consulting segment headquartered in the Netherlands, with operations in the Netherlands, Poland and a newly opened international branch in Spain (Triple A – Risk Finance) and Portugal (ITDS). We typically provide consulting and secondment services to clients through job candidates with university degrees or applied university degrees who are predominantly but not exclusively on indefinite term contracts with us. Redmore and its boutiques operate primarily in the banking and insurance sectors, but also in the public sector and work with companies seeking financial staffing in enterprise recourse ----- planning (“ERP”) implementation, with competitors of a variety of sizes, including large global companies and the “Big Four” accountancy firms. _End-market overview and drivers_ Redmore’s Addressable Market consists mainly of three markets in the Netherlands: the market for secondment of financial specialists, the market for actuarial and risk consulting and the market for ERP/finance and control consulting (and excludes ITDS). In recent years, Redmore has also expanded its business into other European countries such as Poland and Belgium (15% of 2021 _Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue per management estimates) and to a lesser extent Germany, Luxembourg, Portugal and Spain (less than 3% of 2021 Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue per management estimates). Over the past 15 years an increase in secondment penetration in the market has been the main driver of growth in the Netherlands. Post Covid-19 pandemic, growth in Redmore’s specific client end-markets in the coming years is expected to be driven by an increasing need for specialist positions in the financial sector as a result of changing regulations, compliance, digitization and consolidation. According to external consultant analysis, Redmore’s addressable market is expected to grow at low to mid-single digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ Redmore competes with various entities in the financial services end-market including the big four accounting firms (namely, Deloitte, Ernst & Young, KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers), which accounted for approximately 40-50% of the market in 2021, as well as other professional services and consultancy firms. Although the competitive environment for each of Redmore’s niches is different, strong consolidation of the market in recent years has resulted in significant growth for both Redmore and its competitors. We believe that Redmore’s businesses are leaders in their respective Addressable Markets in terms of revenue. Redmore is built around five labels with each serving a specific niche: - _Talent&Pro focuses on secondments in the banking, insurance, pensions and actuarial end- markets. Talent&Pro is a significant player in the financial secondment market in the Netherlands, facing competition from a variety of other firms, including Brunel, which has a broad focus across IT, finance, engineering and law, Welten, which is specialized in candidate training with project based work, and Young Capital, which is a digital disruptor across the finance, sales, IT and marketing end-markets. - _Triple A_ focuses on financial consulting in actuarial and risk management, with actuarial consultancy firms, including Willis Tower Watson, Mercer, and Milliman, and the big four accounting firms as its most significant competitors. - _Profource_ focuses on finance staffing, ERP consulting and provides business process outsourcing services. As such, it maintains a unique market position which combines expertise in finance and ERP. It faces competition from the big four accounting firms, whose consulting departments include both finance and ERP, Eiffel, which is specialized in finance and legal staffing, focusing on the government sector, and DPA, which is focused on candidate training in the finance, IT and engineering end-markets. - _ITDS_ provides specialist consulting for insurance companies, pension funds and banks, focusing on risk management, digital transformation, and cost-saving programs. Competitors for ITDS are Accenture, Deloitte and Capgemini. ----- - _Vialegis primarily specializes in the legal staffing solutions market in Belgium, though it has developed activities in Spain, Luxembourg and Germany over recent years. Vialegis operates in two primary niches: (i) legal interim management and secondments and (ii) legal search and selection, both of which are relatively small and developing markets expected to grow rapidly in the future.

GRITT is a multi-specialist in the secondment and project management of technicians and engineers for the Belgian construction end-market. GRITT focuses on three distinct market niches each with its own specific drivers and competition: - _GRITT focuses on the secondment of engineers in Antwerp and, to a lesser extent, Flanders with a focus on the chemical, pharmaceutical and life sciences end-markets. GRITT’s market growth is driven by an increase in capital expenditures, a moderate increase in outsourcing and a moderate increase of billing rates relative to inflation. The market includes a lot of players with strong competition from certain larger Benelux competitors, such as STAR engineering as well as more specialized competition from Talenco. - _Logi-technic focuses on the secondment of technicians in East and West Flanders with a focus on recurring maintenance and facility management needs for industrial equipment in the food end-market. Logi-technic operates in a growing market due to a growing shortage of skilled technicians as a result of existing high employment rates in Flanders, driving billing rates higher as well as recurring business needs for maintenance of installed equipment. Such growth is expected to be seen in the future, once markets have recovered from the Covid-19 pandemic.

Continu Professionals is a specialist in finding white-collar secondment solutions for the engineering and construction markets in our engineering and consulting segment. It is headquartered in the Netherlands, with branches throughout the Netherlands, two branches in Belgium and a branch in Germany that was opened at the beginning of 2019. Continu Professionals provides secondment solutions to clients through job candidates who are planners, foremen, superintendents, technical designers, project managers, architects and a wide variety of engineers such as in manufacturing, infrastructure and construction (including specialization in social housing corporations) research and development, and mechanical. _End-market overview and drivers_ Continu serves the Dutch engineering and construction markets, which have experienced steady growth over the past several years. Continu’s Addressable Market consists of the staffing market for infrastructure, engineering and construction end-markets in the Netherlands, with a growing presence in Belgium and Germany. Post Covid-19 pandemic, growth in Continu’s Addressable Market is expected to be mainly driven by two factors: - growth among SMEs within engineering and construction that largely stems from infrastructure projects, which typically have long project durations and tend to have a predictable revenue stream; and - a continued shortage of mid to high-skilled engineers and technicians able to work on infrastructure and engineering projects, leading to increased outsourcing penetration and accounting, as the temporary to permanent model has been successful and desirable in an environment where the demand for permanent labor exceeds its supply. ----- According to external consultant analysis, Continu’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at midsingle digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ Continu benefits from a high level of expertise and broad national coverage, and is the top three player in its Addressable Market in terms of revenue. Its main competitors include: TMC, which is mostly focused on software and electrical engineering, Voort, which focuses on a similar specialty as Continu, and Brunel, which focuses on the oil and gas sector. _SOLCOM_ SOLCOM is a German specialist in contracting services covers primarily lucrative, highly specialized IT and engineering segments across various industries within the DACH region. SOLCOM mostly works with experienced freelancers only. SOLCOM facilitates and manages the process of matching clients with experienced freelancers throughout the contracting period. _End-market overview and drivers_ SOLCOM serves the German IT and engineering experts across all end industries, through qualified specialists and managers with expertise and experience in all sectors of IT and engineering. According to an external consultant analysis conducted in July 2021, the market is highly fragmented, where approximately 2,000 small players account for approximately 80% of the market, while the top 10 companies represent approximately the remaining 20%. SOLCOM’s end market is growing and resilient, driven by robust megatrends across all industries: - Increasing demand for contracting services in Germany driven by shortage of skilled workers, demographic change, increasing technological complexity and demand for digitalization - Complex legal status - Demographic change as an increasing challenge that House of HR is being able to manage through the expansion of internal divisions According to external consultant analysis, SOLCOM’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at mid to high single digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ Expert know-how providers can be segmented based on their geographical and segment coverage. SOLCOM is a national specialized expert know-how provider. SOLCOM’s main competitors are divided into two sub-categories: - nationwide non-specialized: Hays, Ferchau, Gulp, SThree, Allgeier, Robert Half, Brunel, WestHouse and Krongaard; and - Nationwide specialized (in IT): Etengo, Top Itservices, Neusta and Future Consulting

Cohedron is a Dutch full-service staffing provider specializing in the government and public sector with a goal to make a meaningful impact. With approximately 3,054 qualified specialists and over 30 years of experience, Cohedron supports and advises public authorities and non-profit organizations through its offering of outsourcing of processes and secondment of qualified specialists, as well as consultancy ----- to organizations and public authorities in areas such as debt counselling, budget management and administration to drive efficiencies and costs savings. _End-market overview and drivers_ Cohedron serves the Dutch public sector, on a market driven by robust mega-trends: - Population wide - Aging population - Rising inflation - Rising self-employment - Rising number of people needing support - Segment-specific - Rising healthcare expenditures - Housing shortage - Government transparency - Energy transition These drivers should foster customer demand due to the shift from a classical welfare state to a decentralized participation society, along with the increasing burden on municipalities increasing their need for specialized resources and integrated solutions. According to external consultant analysis, Cohedron’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at low to mid-single digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ The market is fragmented, but slightly consolidating mainly through M&A of leading market participants: - M&A of public specialist expected to continue (e.g., Wyzer combination of Langhenkel & Talenter in 2018, BMC acquisition by Randstad in 2017) - Consolidating municipality landscape Cohedron is positioned within the top three market participants, together with Maandag, which has lost market share due to volume-focused profile sourcing at the expense of quality and Randstad, still winning a lot of tenders due to its dedicated tender team and experience.

Our engineering and consulting segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals, Redmore, GRITT, SOLCOM and Cohedron Powerhouses, as well as IBB and AERO, which are Boutiques under TIMEPARTNER. Abylsen, Redmore, SOLCOM and Cohedron are the largest financial contributors to this segment. Powerhouses in this segment also generate revenue from France, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain, Italy, Switzerland and Belgium. The figures below show the split of our engineering and consulting segment’s sales by brand and by geographic market, respectively, for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Note: Figures are calculated on the basis of the business unit accounts for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Sales by brand are calculated on the basis of business unit accounts or subunits, in the case AERO and IBB. Sales by geographic market primarily allocate revenue from the business units accounts to the primary geographic market of that business unit, though some adjustments ----- for revenue generated in other geographies have been reflected when possible. As a result, the percentage of sales by geographic market will not align with figures provided in our Financial Statements. Our engineering and consulting segment is focused on recruiting highly skilled professionals to work in fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors and regulatory environments such as energy, pharmaceuticals, life sciences, construction, infrastructure, finance, legal, public affairs and technology, among others, and also assists clients with the search and selection of the right candidate. The job candidate placements by the Powerhouses in this segment are typically medium- to long-term. Unlike the specialized talent solutions segment which typically generates the majority of its sales from SME clients, the Powerhouses in our engineering and consulting segment are more mixed in the percentage of clients that generate sales. The job candidates in most of our engineering and consulting Powerhouses are indefinite employees on our payroll whether or not they are on assignment with a client. As a result, our engineering and consulting segment in particular carefully monitors the end date of all job candidates’ assignments and aims to line up the next assignment before their current ones come to an end. This monitoring seeks to minimize “bench time,” which is the time during which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed to a client assignment. Our bench time for 2021 was approximately 0.3%. As of September 30, 2022, our engineering and consulting segment served customers through a business unit network of 110 branches, with approximately 1,705 in-house full-time equivalent employees and 12,283 job candidates at work. The following table shows these and other key performance indicators for this segment for and as of the periods indicated:

Accent is a specialized staffing Powerhouse focused exclusively on the Belgian specialty market, with operations in Belgium and offices in Poland, Romania, Moldova and Portugal for the sourcing of job candidates from its international recruiting network. Accent operates in a competitive and consolidated market where it challenges larger global staffing solutions companies or brands, as well as regional companies or brands. _End-market overview and drivers_ Post recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, growth in the Belgian staffing solutions industry will continue to be largely driven by the tightening of the Belgian labor market as employment is growing faster than the active population, particularly in Flanders. This trend is expected to result in fewer job seekers per vacancy leading to a scarcity of candidates. As a result, demand has grown for companies such as ours that are able to provide appropriate qualified candidates to clients in need of staffing and this demand is expected to continue in the future. According to external consultant analysis, Accent’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at low single digit in the next five years. _Competitive landscape_ Accent was the fourth-largest staffing provider in terms of 2017 revenue within the Belgian total staffing market, behind the larger staffing firms of Randstad, Recruit and Adecco, each of which focuses on larger accounts, which are typically lower margins.

Covebo is a blue-collar specialized staffing Powerhouse. It is focused on the Dutch specialty blue-collar staffing market, with operations in the Netherlands, as well as its branches in Hungary, Lithuania, Spain, Poland and Romania, which are part of its international recruiting network. _End-market overview and drivers_ Covebo had an Addressable Market consisting of the staffing market in the Netherlands in the trade, engineering, logistics and construction end-markets. Structural growth in Covebo’s Addressable Market is due to a variety of factors, including: - underlying growth in the Dutch construction, engineering and logistics and food production end-markets; - growth due to the increasing penetration of temporary staffing as the demand for permanent labor exceeds its supply; and - increases in billing rates to correlate with salary increases within its clients’ end-markets. There is a general scarcity in the Dutch domestic workforce willing to work in these end-markets due to changing perceptions of working conditions and possible night shifts as a result of the increased premium on quality of life global trend, favoring companies like us with the ability to source candidates for these positions internationally. _Competitive landscape_ ----- Covebo competes with smaller, regional or local competitors and larger generalists. Regional peers include: Otto Workforce, a direct competitor and that has a similar end-market focus and sourcing strategy to Covebo, though it is smaller in geographical scope; and Olympia, which is a mid-sized firm, larger than Covebo, serving most end-markets throughout the Netherlands. Smaller competitors, such as VDB, Sherpa and McDOIT, typically compete on smaller assignments but find it difficult to match Covebo on price as they provide candidates in lower volumes. The larger generalists, such as Randstad and Adecco compete heavily in volume driven projects, yet find it difficult to serve the small-volume, specialized niches where we excel and do not offer a full service package or training. According to external consultant analysis, Covebo’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at low to mid-single digit in the next five years.

TIMEPARTNER specializes in the staffing of high-demand blue-collar workers in Germany and offers tailor-made and integrated flexible HR-solutions in the field of temporary staffing, personnel placement, provision of temporary workers and on-site management. In June 2021, we acquired avanti, which complements TIMEPARTNER’s service portfolio by adding a presence in the medical and healthcare segment. In addition, Zaquensis, previously a Powerhouse in our legacy general staffing segment, is now part of the TIMEPARTNER operation following the partial merger between TIMEPARTNER and Zaquensis in the second quarter of 2021. _German general staffing market drivers_ In the future, it is expected that growth in this market will be driven by an increase in the number of hours worked and overall temporary staffing penetration as decreasing unemployment and a shortage of low-skilled blue-collar workers will force companies to seek out alternatives to source qualified candidates. Billing rates are also expected to increase driven by the increase in minimum wages for temporary workers established as a result of regulatory reform. According to external consultant analysis, TIMEPARTNER’s Addressable Market is expected to remain flat in the next five years.

On March 3, 2022, we acquired TMI, our new Powerhouse in our specialized talent solutions segment. TMI specializes in providing staffing service for the healthcare sector in the Netherlands, assisting with the recruitment of candidates for healthcare providers such as hospitals, public care institutions, ambulance staff and nursing homes. TMI also supplies temporary staff, intermediates for freelancers, and offers flexible jobs. Their job candidates usually include doctors, nursing staff, psychologists, and pharmacists. _End-market overview and drivers_ TMI is active in the attractive and growing Dutch healthcare staffing market which benefits from longterm healthcare trends where demand for healthcare professionals is high and ever-increasing. According to an external analysis, TMI’s focus markets are (size of total healthcare workforce being approximately 1.4 million employees): - nursing, care and home care (representing approximately 470,000 employees in 2020); - hospitals and other expert care & university medical centers (representing approximately 300,000 employees in 2020); - disabled care & youth care (representing approximately 200,000 employees in 2020); and ----- - mental healthcare (representing approximately 100,000 employees in 2020). Continued shortages of healthcare personnel are expected to last until 2030, driven by Netherland’s aging population and aging healthcare workforce: - Demand for healthcare and cure until 2030 is expected to increase due to the aging Dutch population: - Older than 55: 37% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR increase of 1.6% (2016-30)). - Between 35 and 55: 24% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR decrease of 0.7% (2016-30)). - Younger than 35: 40% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR increase of 2016- 0.2% (2016-30)). - The Dutch healthcare workforce is expected to grow older with a CAGR increase of 4% for population above 55 (2010-30). According to external consultant analysis, TMI’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at mid to high single digit in the next five years. -----

Our specialized talent solutions segment includes our operating companies Accent, Covebo, TimePartner and TMI (acquired in early 2022) which cover the short-term employment market for high demand mid-skilled blue-collar workers in Belgium and the Netherlands, respectively. Both of these geographic end-markets have seen significant growth over the past years, as long term trends in the staffing solutions industry combined with a tightening labor market have increased demand for service providers like us to fill the need for specialized workers. Growth in the future will continue to be largely ----- driven by growing economies in both regions and end-markets in which House of HR’s Powerhouses provide services, as well as a large and growing gap between the demand for certain specialized positions and the supply of candidates willing to perform these jobs. Source: Company information, external consultant analysis. Note: People at work excludes StaffMe and LD Personalvermittlung as integration is ongoing; 2020 People at work impacted by Covid-19. Price analysis excludes TMI, Cohedron, Bis people, LD Personalvermittlung, StaffMe, Fid, Agium and ABMI. Sickness impacts our number of job candidates at work. The following chart shows the percentage of our job candidates that were sick at the times indicated therein. We will typically enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate and a service agreement with the client. The employment agreement is often entered into with the job candidate in connection with us entering into a service agreement with the client. In these cases, the employment agreement is for the duration of a particular client assignment, which duration will vary a great deal among our business units due to the nature of the services offered and will also be impacted by the nature of the services required by the client. In a number of our business units, in particular those in our engineering and consulting segment, the employment agreement will often be an indefinite employment agreement and for a longer duration than the service agreement with the client as a result of regulatory reasons or to facilitate recruiting job candidates. ----- Nearly all of the service agreements into which we enter with clients are time and materials service agreements, which means we are compensated under the contract for the services and materials provided by our job candidates. A small number of the service agreements we enter into with clients are projectoriented, which means we are compensated under the agreement only when our job candidates deliver the project in accordance with the specifications in the agreement. When we have a time and materials service agreement with a client, we typically bill the client for the services performed by the job candidate and pay the salary and the applicable associated benefits, fees and costs, such as social security, of the job candidate. The difference between what we bill our clients and what we pay as salary, benefits and associated costs to the job candidates is referred to as the “billpay spread,” which is a key driver of our Group’s profitability. Our business units are organized around a variety of staffing models which have varying degrees of specialization and scarcity, which impacts the bill-pay spread. We focus on providing best-in-class service, matching excellence and investing in digital initiatives to enhance our service offering as well as to automate processes and reduce costs to maximize the bill-pay spread. Other elements that are part of our business model include a focus on SME clients (who often lack in-house staff who can perform the staffing services that we provide), providing training to our job candidates and including non-solicitation or minimum fees for a particular period for job candidates in relation to the client for which they are staffed. For further information about the pricing of our job candidates in our service agreements with clients, see “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key factors affecting our results of operations.”_ The nature of the employment agreement into which we enter with job candidates and its duration (whether it is an open-ended contract for the length of an assignment or an indefinite contract that is in place whether or not the job candidate is on an assignment) will depend primarily upon the regulatory environment in which our business units operate and the type of contract needed to attract, recruit and retain job candidates. The nature of the employment agreement will also impact the termination and notice periods. Indefinite contracts typically provide for three to six month notice periods for us to terminate the employment agreement (except in Germany where terminations can happen sooner, and labor durations are also typically shorter). The flexibility of open-ended contracts typically allows us to enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate in connection with an assignment with a client and the notice periods in the service agreement will be aligned with the notice period in the employment agreement. On the other hand, as a result of the indefinite employment agreements, we experience “bench time,” which is the time for which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed to a client assignment, for our job candidates with indefinite contracts. We carefully monitor the end date of all such job candidates’ assignments and aim to line up the next assignment before their current one comes to an end to minimize bench time. By minimizing a job candidate’s bench time, we aim to ensure job candidates are being utilized on billable matters and generating revenue since we will be responsible for the costs associated with employing them whether or not they are on assignment with a client. In our engineering and consulting segment, employment agreements with job candidates are typically indefinite due to the regulatory environment of the countries in which our business units in this staffing segment operate or in order to attract and retain job candidates to fill staffing shortages. In certain Powerhouses, such as Redmore, the employment agreement approach also facilitates longer and more specialized training for job candidates and deepens the relationship between ourselves and these job candidates. Within this segment, we also utilize a number of freelance job candidates (approximately 36% of job candidates at work as of September 30, 2022), primarily in the SOLCOM business, but also in the Abylsen, Continu Professionals, GRITT and Redmore Powerhouses, whom we screen and match with clients but who do not become our employees. In our specialized talent solutions segment, due to the countries in which our business units in this segment offer services and our ability to attract and recruit job candidates, we typically use fixed-term contracts with job candidates, except for our operations in Germany, where we generally enter into an indefinite employment agreement with a job candidate due to regulations on temporary staffing there. As a result, our specialized talent solutions segment also faces bench time risk with respect to job candidates in Germany. The bench time risk in the specialized talent solutions segment is, however, typically less than that in the engineering and ----- consulting segment due to the shorter periods of services typically associated with these job candidates and consequently the typically shorter notice periods required for our job candidates in this segment. Our specialized talent solutions segment is comprised of our Accent, Covebo, TIMEPARTNER (with the exception of IBB and AERO, which are part of our engineering and consulting segment) and TMI Powerhouses, with operations in Belgium, Germany, Portugal and the Netherlands, as well as branches ----- in countries that form part of their international recruiting networks. In addition, following the acquisitions of LD Personalvermittlun, we are in the process of establishing a new Powerhouse, House of Care Talents Germany, which will focus on the placements of physicians and nurses to clinics or hospitals. Our specialized talent solutions segment supplies specialized staffing to companies in certain sectors, including construction, retail and finance, among others and includes general temporary agencies delivering candidates to clients in a fast and flexible way when they are shorthanded. The figures below show the split of our specialized talent solutions segment’s sales by brand and by geographic market, respectively, for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Note: Figures are calculated on the basis of the business unit accounts for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Sales by brand calculated on the basis of business unit accounts. Sales by geographic market primarily allocate revenue from the business units accounts to the primary geographic market of that business unit, though some adjustments for revenue generated in other geographies have been reflected when possible. As a result, the percentage of sales by geographic market will not align with figures provided in our Financial Statements. Our business units in this segment typically supplies specialized staffing to clients from a diversified group of end-markets, including construction, retail and finance, among others, and includes general temporary agencies delivering candidates to clients in a fast and flexible way. The job candidate placements by the business units in this segment are typically short to medium-term. As of September 30, 2022, our specialized talent solutions segment served customers through its business units’ networks of 632 branches, with 2,958 in-house full-time equivalent employees and 60,012 job candidates at work. The following table shows these and other key financial performance indicators and operating metrics for this segment for and as of the periods indicated:

We are a leading provider of HR solutions in key European staffing markets, offering end-to-end temporary recruiting and outsourcing services. We supply specialized and niche staffing to primarily small and medium-sized enterprise (“SME”) clients in a diversified range of end-markets. We offer and tailor our services to the staffing needs of our clients through our engineering and consulting segment and specialized talent solutions segment, which are comprised of a well-developed portfolio of ten specialized business units, which we call Powerhouses, across various countries. We also offer digital recruiting through our dedicated platforms, using our digital tools, including, NOWJOBS, SWOP and Gighouse app, targeting low-skilled, high-volume markets with significant roll-out potential. Since our founding, we have expanded from a presence in only Belgium to more than 10 countries in Europe. Corresponding to our geographic expansion, we have also become more diversified in the endmarkets we serve, primarily through our acquisitions in recent years, which provide us with staffing capabilities in additional areas such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, life sciences, government and public administration and technology. As of September 30, 2022, we had 72,296 job candidates at work and approximately 40,858 productive people at work (meaning the number of our job candidates adjusted to reflect a 38 hour per week workweek) and 4,734 in-house full-time equivalent employees. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we had 31,456 unique clients, our Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue was €2,770.0 million and our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA was €330.5 million. Our engineering and consulting segment represents 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. This segment supplies staffing of highly-skilled professionals, such as engineering consultants and financial and insurance specialists, to fill specialized roles in a variety of end-markets, such as financial, industrial, logistics, infrastructure, public administration and construction, and, more recently, fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors such as energy, telecommunications, pharmaceuticals and technology. This segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals, Redmore, GRITT, Cohedron and SOLCOM Powerhouses and has the broadest geographic footprint, with its primary operations in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany.
