----- Our Group is strategically committed to mobile-based recruiting solutions to reach a larger pool of potential candidates and increase user engagement. We have several live projects, including the following mobile apps: - **_SWOP and SWOP Recruiter: Inspired by Tinder, SWOP provides a mobile platform for job candidates to “swipe right” to indicate interest on job opportunities they wish to pursue. SWOP was downloaded 17,596 times in 2019, 46,540 times in 2020 and 14,753 times in 2021. SWOP has enabled the placement of 60.75 job candidates per month on average as of September 30, 2022. The app was updated in early 2020 in order to include not only Accent or Ctrl-F vacancies, but also include vacancies that are aggregated from other company websites, thus allowing it to show approximately 60,000 vacancies (of which approximately 23,000 come from Accent) in the Belgian market and 72,000 vacancies in the Dutch market as of October 2022. Candidates swiping on non-Accent vacancies are also contacted in order to help provide them with the necessary support if they do wish so. In May 2021, we launched SWOP Recruiter, which consists of a free digital platform that helps Belgian SMEs with the day-to-day management of their vacancies. The application is currently linked to our SWOP application, and includes a job board multi-poster tool that allows SMEs to post vacancies simultaneously on multiple platforms. - **_NOWJOBS: NOWJOBS is a mobile platform aimed at reaching student job candidates and for flexible jobs (such as short-term part-time jobs), historically a difficult market to serve due to low margins. By implementing a mobile, app-based platform, NOWJOBS has matched over 3,100 active companies with more than 30,800 job candidates in 2021 on a low cost basis for our Accent Powerhouse. NOWJOBS was launched in the Netherlands in late 2019 and in France in 2021. We also recently launched NOWJOBS in Germany in June 2022. Since NOWJOBS mostly services the entertainment, hospitality and retail segment, it was heavily impacted during the lockdown period during the Covid-19 pandemic, especially in the second quarter of 2020; however, it still managed to reach a revenue in 2020 that was only 8.4% below its 2019 revenue. It has complemented its offering now also towards food retail and food production companies, as well as home delivery models, such as Take-Away.com and Hello Fresh. We acquired StaffMe in July 2022, a French digital platform focusing on student employment and which is primarily active in the retail, health event and hospitality sectors, supplementing our NOWJOBS offering. Through this acquisition, we also acquired the other companies of the StaffMe group, including the StaffMe Academy, the first training organization for young entrepreneurs, and the Accelerator, a program of integration through selfemployment for those who are far from employment. NOWJOBS will operate under the StaffMe brand in France given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country. - **_Gighouse: Gighouse is a mobile app designed to reach freelance or independent job candidates and match them with clients. We add value by screening the freelancers or independent job candidates to check their qualifications and experience to provide a narrower pool of suitable options for clients. We also monitor the customer assignments to ensure freelance job candidates are assigned to legitimate projects. - **_FYGI:_** FYGI is a mobile platform that connects freelance recruiters to Covebo’s staffing network and job candidate pool on a commission basis. FYGI focuses on providing freelance recruiters access to a larger pool of potential job candidates than they would independently be able to access in order to fill permanent positions. Additionally, we have a full team dedicated to creating a Group framework and data platform for each Powerhouse to develop tailored mobile solutions for its end-markets. We have also developed CV Creator, a service that allows job seekers to create professional résumés quickly and easily. CV Creator is available as a free web service. We developed together with the Ghent University the MySkillz tools, through which job candidates can perform tests and get insights about ----- themselves. One of such tests is ‘Who am I,’ which allows job candidates to better understand how they function in their professional lives. Another test is ‘Who do I want to work for,’ which helps to indicate the types of companies that fit best for a particular candidate. We are also developing a client version of the ‘Who do I want to work for’ test, which indicates the type of job candidates that fit best with a particular team leader, and the ‘My brains’ test which attempts to indicate the intelligence level of a job candidate within their education level.

Through our investment in Happy Recruiter, we developed Dora, a recruitment robot, to leverage chatbot technologies to perform recruitment services. Recruiters get a fully customizable chatbot colleague that screens and communicates with job candidates located anywhere around the clock. Dora speaks seven languages and can work side-by-side with live recruitment team as the first line of interactions with job candidates. Dora is capable of reengaging existing job candidates on any marketing channel, including website, database, social media channel, job board and applicant tracking system. Dora held approximately 63,000 interviews in 2021. This technology helps find passive and active job candidates and creates efficiency in the reaching and screening process.

Matching candidates to open positions is a critical component to our business and we are developing solutions to optimize the matching processes using data analysis and AI. Such matching technology projects focus on improving the quality of the data, including by encouraging individuals to update their information directly on our platforms and mobile applications. Additionally, we are developing and experimenting with AI-enabled speech-to-text tools, including for the MyAccent app, an app that is connected with Google Assistant (for instance via smartphone or Google Home) to engage in a job search. By converting the job candidate’s speech into text on such platforms, we will be able to develop and test methods to automatically detect job candidates’ skills, interests and personality traits and to better prepare our job candidates for interviews for consultant positions, so we can then more efficiently and effectively match job candidates to appropriate job opportunities. These initiatives aim to increase the quality and efficiency of matching and to identify skill set needs in order to develop appropriate training. Together with the Ghent University, we developed soft skills testing to allow candidates to discover their personal preferences as to the type of companies they wish to work for or as to their own personality.

We develop digital initiatives with a dual purpose: (i) to support growth initiatives for our operations by enabling us to reach additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner, and (ii) to introduce cost efficiencies to our processes to remain competitive against technological developments. By producing tools for our business units to meet business needs where no applicable tool exists, we aim to disrupt the existing staffing market and to expand our market share by developing new solutions or end-markets. Our digital initiatives are typically not directly revenue-generating, with the exception of SWOP Recruiter, NOWJOBS and Gighouse, but instead indirectly contribute to revenue generation by assisting us with identifying additional job candidates or matching them with clients. Such initiatives can also help us reduce our expenses by automating or introducing other time efficiencies into certain time-intensive aspects of the recruiting lifecycle. Once a digital initiative has been developed and tested, it is typically launched by one of our Powerhouses. Any revenue generated by the digital initiative, whether directly or indirectly, would be accounted for as part of the revenue of the staffing unit to which the Powerhouse belongs. During 2021, we centralized all our digital assets in House of Invest, creating one platform to meet current needs and invest in new needs as they arise. This enabled us to further invest in our digital roadmap and internationalize our digital initiatives. The main purpose of House of Invest is to roll out the digital initiatives across all House of HR Powerhouses and Boutiques and to capitalize on a centralized knowledge base. House of Invest now owns NOWJOBS, Gighouse, SWOP and SWOP Recruiter, Continu-Connect, CV creator and My Talents (Softskillz), holds minority ownerships in Dora and Ariad (a traditional digital marketing staffing company) and a majority ownership in Book’u. For the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue from digital solutions amounted to 2.6% of total revenue, compared to 1.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. We strive to keep our digital development team lean and operationally independent, which we believe promotes an entrepreneurial, start-up-like culture within the team. Re-usability of our developments is key, so applications can be exchanged across different geographies and our operating companies. We have in the past and expect in the future to use acquisitions as another means to acquire additional digital technologies that will complement our digital initiatives strategy or instill a more rapid growth of our sales through the digital platforms, particularly NOWJOBS. Currently, we are developing a CDP to consolidate all candidate data and leverage this data to gain better access to job candidates and improve our matching capabilities. We also invest in AI tools to improve matching accuracy. Our philosophy for job applications is “mobile-first,” meaning we are developing our digital platforms in a way that clients and job candidates can match easily on mobile phones.

We use an initial set of criteria to identify targets. These criteria examine the historic growth, geographic location, staffing segments, growth and margin prospects, end-market specialization and cultural fit to investigate M&A opportunities. Targets that are determined not to fit the selection criteria are eliminated from consideration. Our criteria include: - **_Geographic location: We look for targets in countries that have a stable economy with low employment, high salary level, high temporary staff penetration, a stable regulatory environment and supply and demand mismatch for skilled labor. Our current key areas of focus include countries where we are already present, particularly Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France and Switzerland, as well as new geographic or other development areas, including Austria, the Nordic countries and targets in other countries where the target offers digital technology that complements our strategy. - **_Staffing segment: We look for targets in both our engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions segments. By targeting the same staffing segments as our Powerhouses, we can reinforce their expertise areas or geographic coverage through bolt-on acquisitions. We can also look at new areas of expertise or areas in which we want to grow more extensively, such as the healthcare, life science, IT sectors and the digital, financial and strategic consulting profiles. - **_Growth and margin prospects: We seek targets where we see above-market growth and margin prospects. To that end, we look for targets (1) offering specialist services, focusing on attractive specialties, which we believe drive higher price points for services (see “—End-market _Specialization” below), (2) having competitive positioning with a high relative market share_ and demonstrated track record and experience and (3) displaying operational excellence with well-structured commercial processes, lean cost structures and entrepreneurial ability. - **_End-market specialization: We look for targets that are staffing end-markets with significant levels of job shortages. Currently, the core end-markets we believe face such shortages include engineering, financial services, IT, pharmaceuticals, life sciences and healthcare. Furthermore, our current operations in Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands provide HR solutions that meet most of the top critical job shortages in those markets. We have identified nursing, healthcare life science, IT sectors and the digital, financial and strategic consulting profiles as areas where we still have expansion possibilities. These are specializations that we may develop to fill our specialization gaps and meet the critical job shortages in those geographic markets but also acquisitions may be one way to move into these end-market specializations. Expanding each Powerhouse across our core geographies is also part of our acquisition strategy. We also consider opportunistic acquisitions of targets that do not serve these end-markets, but which show high growth and margin prospects. - **_Cultural fit: We look for targets that have like-minded management teams. Since our Group operates in a people business, finding targets that are a good cultural fit is critical. We also generally invite the active members of the management teams to stay on board after an acquisition. ----- - **_Valuation: Historically, we have acquired bolt-on acquisitions in the range of 5x to 8x, and platform acquisitions in the range of 8x to 9x LTM EBITDA.

Our structured process helps us identify opportunities, investigate and assess the targets that meet our selection criteria and support the target company once it has been acquired. Three levels of our organization are involved in deal sourcing: our central Group (especially our M&A Department, which includes M&A analysts and an M&A legal counsel), our Powerhouses, and our shareholders. Each level evaluates opportunities through the rubric of our selection criteria. Opportunities identified which meet the selection criteria are considered on a weekly basis via the M&A team and are then evaluated by our investment committee and an opportunities file is maintained. Our investment committee includes representatives from each of the three constituencies (our central Group, our operating companies, and certain of our shareholders). To further assess an opportunity that meets our selection criteria and undertake due diligence, we typically try to have a brief meeting with management or advisors before we sign a non-binding indicative offer letter and then undertake due diligence on the target, including meeting with its founders and management team, and prepare a short file that summarizes our assessment of the target company, its market and its key financial and other metrics. The investment committee will evaluate the opportunities and, if recommended, they are presented to our Board for a go/no go decision. Opportunities may be approved or rejected, or the Board may recommend that more time needs to be taken for further assessment. If approved, we will submit a binding offer and determine which entity in the Group will acquire the target and discuss the target operating model. Typically for deals that are closely related to one of our Powerhouses, the acquisition will be undertaken by that Powerhouse, with deals less closely related or very large being acquired at the central Group level. The assessment process from initial sourcing to closing takes an average of six to nine months to complete. Once a deal closes, our central support team assists acquired companies. The central team provides performance support by sharing best practices, financial guidelines and reporting templates and assists with regulatory compliance issues. The time required to integrate the target into our Group varies depending on the size of the target, but typically takes six to nine months from closing. Financial integration is prioritized and is typically completed within 90 days of closing.

Subsubsection Title: Our value proposition for target company owners
Subsubsection Text: We believe our approach to M&A has created an attractive value proposition for company owners at target companies which have contributed to our M&A track record. We believe four aspects of our M&A approach contribute to our appeal to targets and our track record at closing transactions where we have submitted a binding offer: - **_Financial incentives: As part of our M&A approach, we generally either offer our management team and individual platform or bolt-on managers a local minority investment (typically for smaller acquisitions that may need to continue on a standalone basis), and/or we will offer ordinary shares, often combined with access to the Management Incentive Plan (“MIP”), which is linked to the performance of their respective companies. This equity type of ownership allows us to continue to align the incentives of those at the Powerhouse level with both the performance of our Group and their individual Powerhouse. Typically for smaller acquisitions, we may continue to acquire only a stake in the target company, but immediately include a mechanism to roll over shares at group level, exchanging local shares for ordinary and MIP. - **_Operational freedom:_** For platform acquisitions that are broadening our base of services offered, we typically offer target companies the option of retaining their full autonomy at the level of their entities’ operations. We also typically preserve the brand identity of the acquired companies, which are not consumed into the House of HR brand or the brand of any Powerhouse. Bolt-on acquisitions may retain less operational autonomy, depending on the ----- nature of the acquisition and how it is integrated into our Group, but we also typically preserve their identity and branding. - **_Support on critical issues:_** Companies joining the Group benefit from support on complex regulatory and compliance topics from our central teams, and IT security and financing and financial reporting immediately begin to integrate. These companies are also provided with access to our foreign staffing recruiting network and experience, our digital platforms (though they may require adaptation and implementation for their local markets) and the possibility of accessing our credit lines at a Group level. - **_Our reputation: We are a leading company for specialized HR solutions with a strong Organic Growth track record and a reputation for operational excellence and quality. We also have a track record of successful acquisitions.

The following current M&A activity has recently been taken or is being undertaken by the Group, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum: - We recently completed the acquisitions of: (a) Agium on October 7, 2022, which is a bolt-on acquisition of a Dutch company specialized in deploying skilled professionals to support companies in their day-to-day finance and control processes and implementation of structure changes and is expected to operate under our Redmore Powerhouse; (b) Job Raccoon on November 14, 2022, in an asset deal to supplement our TIMEPARTNER Powerhouse; and - In addition, on October 25, 2022, we signed the Put Option Agreement to acquire the French company ABMI, a consulting and engineering services group operating mainly in three engineering segments: (i) product design and industrialization, (ii) industrial processes and (iii) industrial facilities (e.g., nuclear and railway infrastructures). The put option may be exercised by the sellers upon completion of the information and consultation of the relevant employee representative bodies to which the offer has been submitted and we are awaiting for written confirmation of approval. The acquisition is expected to be completed in December 2022, subject to the put option being exercised by the sellers, regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions. Following the acquisition of ABMI, we expect to combine ABMI with Abylsen in order to create a new Powerhouse, ABY Engineering. We also have a number of other potential targets in our pipeline for 2022: we have submitted one nonbinding offer, we are currently reviewing the investment memorandum for one target and we have made non-committal contact for several other targets. We have also lost out on nine potential acquisition opportunities in 2022. These targets were identified and selected in line with our selection criteria and our M&A strategy.

M&A has been a key strategic pillar to strengthen our Group, reinforce our market positions, enter new market segments and countries, achieve above-market growth and profitability and reinforce the offerings of our Powerhouses. Since 2015, we have added the Abylsen, Covebo, Continu Professionals, TIMEPARTNER (including Zaquensis), Redmore (including Vialegis), GRITT (formerly the TEC Alliance Group), Cohedron, SOLCOM and TMI Powerhouses to the Group, as well as acquired minority stakes in multiple companies. Beginning in 2018, we have also been focusing on bolt-on acquisitions to enhance the platforms of our existing Powerhouses, including most recently signing the purchase agreements for the bolt-on acquisitions in the Netherlands, France and Germany. Bolt-on acquisitions allow our Powerhouses to either expand geographically or gain expertise in a certain endmarket or job profiles. While the growth of our Addressable Market slowed down during the Covid-19 pandemic, the economies in our primary markets have fully recovered in 2021, and according to SIA, our Addressable Market is expected to grow at an annual rate of approximately 5% from 2021 to 2023. We believe that we are poised to continue growing at or above the industry average growth rate in the future. See “—Our History” and “—Our Strategies—Continue to target accretive acquisition _opportunities to achieve European leadership.” for further information about our history and our current_ M&A strategy, respectively. We have built and follow a structured process to assess M&A opportunities, from deal sourcing to support for newly acquired companies, which are supported by our in-house capabilities. We also ----- believe our approach to M&A has created an attractive value proposition for company owners at target companies who wish to continue to develop their businesses while being supported by a larger group and contributed to our success in closing M&A opportunities that we identify. Our typical selection criteria, M&A assessment and integration process, value proposition and our current M&A activity, are described further below.

We have properties located strategically across the markets in which we operate. As of September 30, 2022, we had 1,110 property leases, which includes our headquarters, our business units’ branch office networks in the host countries we serve, our international recruiting network’s recruiting offices where we source foreign job candidates, as well as our leases for housing that we provide to certain in-house employees or job candidates. The location and breadth of our business units’ branch networks vary by business unit and geographic location, but generally support our candidate recruiting and client-facing services. ----- Our Group’s headquarters are currently located in Roeselare, Belgium (the “Headquarters”). The property at our Headquarters has three components: (1) the land on which the office buildings are located; (2) the land on which the parking lot is located; and (3) the office buildings built on the land. We have a 50% ownership interest over both the land for the office buildings and the land for the parking lots. The other owner of such land is Pro-Serve Software en Advies BVBA (“Pro-Serve”). With respect to the office buildings built on our land, the builder of our office building, Fortis Lease NV (“Fortis”), owns the building right to the building and we lease it from Fortis, along with other lessees. At the end of the building right period on April 1, 2030, ownership of the building will pass to ourselves and Pro-Serve without any additional expense. This building will be used solely by Accent beginning from January 1, 2023 for its central support services. Our Group’s headquarters are expected to move to the Netherlands in connection with the timing of the Acquisition, while the supporting services units are expected to move to Kortrijk, Belgium, by the third quarter of 2023, with the lease agreement already finalized. See also “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.”
The breakdown of our annual average of full-time equivalent employees (which includes job candidates at work) on a segmental basis and at the Group level as of the periods indicated was as follows:

_Employee compensation_ Up to 50% of the total compensation of our business unit managers, branch managers, sales consultants, and recruitment consultants is variable and linked to performance: - **_Business unit management: The performance targets for business unit managers are generally tied to business unit level KPIs, such as business unit EBITDA, EBITDA growth, new clients, people at work and productivity. Additionally, managers at the business unit level are often entitled to participate in equity compensation schemes at the Group level, which links their compensation to our performance as a whole. - **_Branch managers: The performance targets for branch managers are generally tied to branch level KPIs, such as new clients, people at work and productivity. Branch managers are compensated with bonus cash incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often impacts promotion decisions. Some of the most successful, long-serving branch managers may also gain access to the MIP. - **_Sales consultants: The performance targets for sales consultants are generally tied to individual sales KPIs, such as the number of daily sales, customer calls, customer visits, customer offers, prospects offers, new customers, and total active customers. Sales consultants are compensated with bonus cash incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often impacts promotion decisions. Additionally, top performing sales consultants may have the opportunity to open new branches. - **_Recruitment consultants: The performance targets for recruitment consultants are generally tied to individual recruiting KPIs, such as the number of candidate calls, candidate interviews, and successful placements. Recruitment consultants are compensated with bonus cash incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often impacts promotion decisions. ----- Additionally, the top performing recruitment consultants may have the opportunity to open new branches. Additionally, managers at the Group level receive substantial performance-based compensation. We believe that our emphasis on performance-based compensation contributes to an entrepreneurial culture throughout the Group and aligns the incentives of our business unit-level employees with that of the central Group.

We use a variety of trade names, trademarks (including for word, figurative and combined marks) and domain names in our business. Due to the Group’s acquisition history and organizational approach, the Group’s intellectual property portfolio is mainly held, maintained and monitored by our business units or their subsidiary undertakings at the local level. The Group’s intellectual property portfolio includes trademarks and domain names primarily registered in Benelux and the EU, as well as other registrations to cover certain other local jurisdictions where one of our business units or its subsidiary undertakings operate. We do not market our services under a House of HR brand but, instead our Powerhouses have their own brands which are used to market their specialized services. As a result, the most important trademarks and domain registrations to our business are those associated with the brand names of our Powerhouses: - **_Abylsen, which uses the Abylsen, Pharmacos, Greenworking, Belgatech, Mykelson, ETA and PI brands; - **_Accent, which uses the Accent Jobs, Accent Construct, Gighouse, NOWJOBS, Jobroad, Sixie and Ctrl-F brands; - **_Cohedron,_** which uses the Cohedron, Plangroep, Plangroep Financiële Services, Wyzer, Argonaut, Zorg-Lokaal, Future Communication, Vanberkel Professionals, Vijverberg Interimjuristen, Sira Consulting, Sqiq and Human Capital Group brands; - **_Continu Professionals, which uses the Continu Professionals and Solyne brands; - **_Covebo, which uses the Covebo, VNOM, Eurojob, FYGI, PRAN, Effect and FID brands; - **_GRITT, which uses the Tec and Logi-technic brands; - **_Redmore, which uses the Talent&Pro, Triple A – Risk Finance, Profource, ITDS, Vialegis, and Agium brands; - **_SOLCOM, which uses the SOLCOM brand; - **_TIMEPARTNER,_** which uses the TIMEPARTNER, IBB, AERO HighProfessionals, LD Personalvermittlung and avanti brands; and - **_TMI, which uses the TMI brand. In addition, following the ABMI acquisition we will also use the ABMI trademark and brand. During 2021, we centralized all our digital assets and the corresponding intellectual property rights in House of Invest, which now owns NOWJOBS, Gighouse, SWOP and SWOP Recruiter, ContinuConnect, CV creator and My Talents (Softskillz), and holds minority ownerships in Dora and Ariad (a traditional digital marketing staffing company) and a majority ownership in Book’u. See “—Digital _Initiatives.”_ ----- In addition, certain of our Powerhouses use proprietary software applications which have been developed or acquired by us. We rely on a combination of trade secrets, copyrights and trademarks, as well as contractual protections to establish and protect our intellectual property rights and our proprietary technology within such applications. While none of these applications is currently material to our business, we expect that they will become more important to our operations as our digital initiatives grow and become more embedded into our HR solutions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal Matters and the Regulatory Environment—Our business _may suffer if we cannot continue to license or enforce the intellectual property rights on which our business depends or if we are subject to claims of intellectual property infringement.”_

Our marketing teams operate on both the Group and local business unit level. Our Group’s marketing efforts are led by our Group’s chief marketing officer and chief digital officer. Each of our Powerhouses typically has its own chief executive officer and/or marketing manager lead its local marketing initiatives. The role of our Group chief marketing officer is to facilitate the two-way exchange of information and best practices and to oversee press and public relations on a Group level and the development of thought leadership strategies. Our Group chief digital officer is responsible for guiding and training our local business units and for integrating the Group’s experience in digital recruiting strategies into the practices of our business units. Our marketing team’s primary focus is to efficiently attract new job candidates and clients for our business units. Each of our local business units also focuses on building brand awareness of its particular service offering. We apply a four-channel approach to marketing: - **_Our Own Websites: Our Powerhouses’ and Boutiques’ own websites are a key aspect of our marketing strategy. We use them to attract active jobseekers. Our Group marketing team provides trainings on search engine optimization to enhance our ability to use the websites for marketing and sourcing job candidates and clients. - **_Commercial Job Boards:_** We also make use of commercial job boards, but are gradually shifting away from them and rely increasingly on the digital initiatives that we have been investing in, such as search engine and social media marketing, which includes connecting our jobsites to Google’s application programming interface. - **_Social Media: We believe that social media is an important channel to reach out and source passive jobseekers. Social media platforms such as LinkedIn, Facebook, Instagram and TikTok are core advertising platforms in our recruiting and targeted advertising strategy, especially given the structural shortage of skilled workers in the current market. Every Boutique has its own social media presence to cater to the job candidates and communities in the respective sectors that they focus on. - **_Digital Innovation:_** Our strategy is to constantly look out for new innovation ideas and technologies that we can leverage to improve our recruitment efficiency. This strategy has led to the development of many successful tools, apps and digital platforms, such as SWOP, NOWJOBS, Gighouse, Book’u and many others. We believe that these tools provide us with a competitive edge and help to keep our recruiting strategy future-proof. See “—Digital _Initiatives” for further information._ We seek to maximize our total return on marketing spend by frequently analyzing and adjusting our budget and chosen advertising channels to those that are most effective. -----

We operate in countries with numerous data security and privacy laws. Our IT systems and processes are critical to our business operations and strategy, and it is therefore imperative that we maintain policies and procedures to comply with such laws, such as GDPR. Our Group’s IT professionals implement systems (AI-based security monitoring and dual-back solutions) and practices to protect against the loss of sensitive or confidential information, for example through running penetration and vulnerability testing on a periodic basis. Additionally, our Group’s IT professionals run awareness campaigns aimed at embedding protection and security of information into our operational business culture.

Our Group has undertaken several integration initiatives aimed at driving synergies across Powerhouses and their constituent entities and creating efficiencies from economies of scale. We also maintain a set of IT guidelines that relies on a mandatory/recommended/allowed (“MRA”) framework, which enables ----- operational flexibility for our Powerhouses while maintaining commonality across the Group where critical. Under the MRA process, our IT managers discuss and identify a list of mandatory, recommended and allowed applications, processes and technologies on a Group-wide basis. Mandatory items include, for instance, a common email platform, Office 365, a disaster recovery plan and securityrelated software, such as password vault and spam, multi-factor authentication and phishing protection. This MRA process aims to lower operational costs, improve price negotiation positions, enhance specialized IT knowledge and support available across our Group and facilitate synergies across Powerhouses. It also assists our Powerhouses with staying attuned to modern applications and software advancements. Under the revised Group guidelines, local servers are no longer allowed and must be transitioned as soon as possible to our central cloud server on Microsoft Azure. Powerhouses are required to use at a minimum a Tier 3 data center (which is a data center that provides redundancy, dual-powered servers, network links and other IT components) until such transition is complete. We are aiming to complete the consolidation of our data centers on the cloud for the entire Group. Migration to the cloud by our Belgium data centers has been completed and full migration of production servers towards Azure was completed in the first quarter of 2021. In addition, an updated data and cyber security program has been rolled out throughout the Group. As part of our data strategy, a project to create a CDP to enhance candidate user experience in Belgium was launched in 2022.

We continue to improve and innovate our IT platforms, both within Powerhouses and across the Group. We have one central unit for the Group which centralizes our digital expertise and competence. This central unit focuses on how to digitize and deploy artificial intelligence (“AI”) in our core business and experiments with new technologies. See“—Digital Initiatives” for further information.

Our Group’s IT capital expenditure budget for the year ended December 31, 2022 is approximately €21.0 million. Our IT expenditure has increased in recent years in connection with our digital initiatives strategy and the growing size of our operations, though we believe that our level of IT expenditure is still below the industry average for the professional services sector due to our lower expenses for the development of technology as a result of our targeted combination of in-house resources and off-theshelf IT solutions. Furthermore, we have created a centralized and specialized development team, House of Invest, to develop reusable different applications for our Powerhouses. House of Invest is able to integrate and reuse certain concepts that were developed in the past when designing and developing new applications, which helps to lower our internal development cost. Among our Powerhouses, Accent has the largest concentration of our IT assets and employees, in large part due to Accent’s historical role as the original member of our Group and its development team for the MyTools application, a proprietary ERP platform that executes a wide range of functionalities supporting Accent’s business operations. Additionally, Accent’s IT staff also supports services that Accent provides to other Powerhouses and Boutiques. With respect to our other Powerhouses, Covebo also employs an internal IT team, with the remaining Powerhouses largely relying on the Group’s IT services or external IT service providers for their IT needs. These and other third parties that we use typically work alongside our Powerhouses or other Group entities under service level agreements, with appropriate relationship management. Our IT infrastructure is built around a clear cloud strategy based on a strong security layer. Our Group’s IT platform is organized around three pillars: data security and privacy; integration; and innovation. A description of each of these pillars is provided below: - **_Data security and privacy_** encompasses all processes and initiatives aimed at ensuring the security of our Group’s IT infrastructure, the prevention of the loss of sensitive or private data and relevant regulatory compliance. - **_Integration and infrastructure_** encompasses all efficiency and cost-related initiatives, including identifying Group-wide best practices and common infrastructure, software platforms and processes and security. All companies within the Group are part of our Central Active Directory, and all servers and infrastructure are hosted on Microsoft Azure, a cloud computing service. - **_Innovation encompasses the development of new technology and markets for the Group. All our development efforts and IP rights are centralized under House of Invest.

The principal risks that we insure against are directors’ and officers’ liability, cyber, general third-party liability, general professional liability, workers’ compensation (for Belgian entities only), motor thirdparty liability, travel and property damage, with all Powerhouses (except Cohedron and TMI) also holding credit insurance to protect their accounts receivables. We have consolidated our insurance programs on a Group-wide basis. General third-party liability, general professional liability, cyber, directors’ and officers’ liability and travel insurance programs are fully consolidated at the group level. Property damage and credit insurance are group programs open for our Powerhouses, meaning the Powerhouse can make use of our conditions and coverage under these programs subject to local requirements and needs. Apart from the Group insurance programs, a series of standalone policies have been put in place at the Powerhouses’ level, mostly covering operational risks, such as local motor liability, local workers’ compensation and other specific risks. We believe these insurance consolidation initiatives optimize our insurance coverage. We maintain insurance in such amounts and with such coverage and deductibles as we believe are adequate to cover the major risks of our business. We cannot, however, assure you that all losses and liabilities that we may incur would be recoverable. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—Our insurance policies may not be adequate to cover all the risks we face and, if we are no longer covered by our existing insurance, it may be difficult to obtain replacement insurance on acceptable terms or at all.”_

We have developed an enterprise risk management and internal audit framework that is able to assess and mitigate risks and offer value-added auditing by optimizing systems, processes and efficiencies. This has been formalized in a governance and control charter, which was signed by all Powerhouses. We have established a Group audit committee, whose role is to assist the Board in fulfilling its oversight responsibilities for financial reporting, internal controls, auditing and legal and regulatory compliance. ----- We also utilize an external and independent auditor, Ernst & Young, to execute a yearly audit plan that reviews the effectiveness of our internal controls and risk management policies and procedures. Additionally, we have implemented conflicts of interest management as well as major incident policies and procedures at the Group level. The Group also rolled out an internal code of conduct and a violence and harassment policy (coupled by a relevant e-learning program and an anonymous reporting tool) in 2021. The Group also expects to roll out a non-discrimination policy and a whistleblower policy during the course of 2022.

The sustainable profitable growth of our Company depends on the economic, environmental and social sustainability of the communities we live and work in. Accordingly, we have developed sustainability initiatives and embedded them into both our strategy and day-to-day activities across our Powerhouses. We monitor the impact of our environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) initiatives through targeted qualitative and quantitative KPIs, which yielded the following results in 2021: - _Staff turnover: 27.0% of in-house employees left the Group - _Sickness: 4.8% of absences due to sickness, accidents at work or unjustified absences - _Female ratio: 59.0% of employees, 45.5% of managers and 30.0% of the board of directors, respectively, were female - _Training:_ 91.1% of in-house employees received training, which amounted to 128,953 of training hours - _Sustainability rating:_ 63.2% of sales covered by EcoVadis’ sustainability rating, which measures the quality of a company’s sustainability management system through its policies, actions and results - _Digitalization: 2.6% of sales generated from digital solutions Our established and robust governance framework covers areas such as employee well-being, education, equality, climate and economic growth, and it does not only aim to involve our in-house employees, clients and job candidates, but also our shareholders and other stakeholders. Our ESG strategy framework has already been formalized in a charter, which we believe will guide us to achieve our targeted KPIs and comply with relevant ESG regulations. We are planning to start sharing consolidated reporting on the ESG KPIs from our Powerhouses on a quarterly basis with our ESG committee in 2022 to demonstrate our accountability. We seek to meet the applicable industry certification standards and aim to have all 10 of our Powerhouses become EcoVadis certified by the end of 2022. Our Powerhouses currently also implement at business unit level a broad range of ESG training initiatives, including hiring dedicated personnel to oversee the implementation of strategies and the launch of learning platforms. We partnered with an external third party to monitor and analyze our carbon dioxide emissions. In terms of carbon footprint assessment, we evaluated a total of 35.6 thousand tCO2 in 2021 (including 14.2 thousand, 3.6 thousand and 17.8 thousand of scopes 1, 2 and 3 emissions, respectively), an increase from a total of 27.2 thousand tCO2 evaluated in 2020 (including 11.3 thousand, 8.3 thousand and 7.6 thousand of scopes 1,2 and 3 emissions, respectively). Energy intensity (presented in GWh/€m revenues) changed from 3.2 in 2019 to 2.4 in 2020 and further to 2.8 in 2021 (i.e., a decrease of 13% from 2019 to 2021), and carbon intensity for scopes 1 and 2 emissions (presented in tCO2/€m revenues) changed from 9.3 in 2019 to 12.3 in 2020 and further to 7.8 in 2021 (i.e., a decrease of 16% from 2019 to 2021). We will continue to expand, refine and improve our strategy to fulfil our commitment to reduce carbon footprint and energy use. For example, we are switching to hybrid and electric vehicles for company cars and aims to continue to increase the use of sustainable cars in the future. In 2021, we ----- had a total fleet of 5,817 vehicles, of which 4.0% (1.8% in 2020) and 1.7% (0.8% in 2020) were hybrid cars and electric cars, respectively. We also encourage the use of bikes and public transportation. In addition to the existing individual diversity and inclusion policies of our Powerhouses, we are working to implement a framework at the Group level in 2022 to raise awareness of diversity and inclusion, which is anticipated to comprise targeted policy, training and reporting mechanisms to help eliminate workplace discrimination. Furthermore, we impose on our top management the responsibility to report on incidents of fraud, corruption and other serious misconduct and irregularities, and we are working on implementing other Group policies and initiatives to supplement our governance framework, including a conflict of interest policy, business ethics, customer satisfaction survey and customer grievance follow-up. For details on our various committees, including our ESG committee, see “Management.”

At any given time, we may be a party to legal proceedings or be subject to non-litigated claims arising out of the normal operations of our business, such as labor law-related claims. We are currently involved in one material legal proceeding. The founder and former Chief Executive Officer of one of our Powerhouses in France, who we dismissed for cause, brought two claims against us for €15.0 million alleging that he is entitled for additional monetary payment for certain shares that he owned in the French Powerhouse of which he was CEO and for certain shares he owned in House of HR. We believe that he is not entitled to such additional payment as a result of him having been dismissed for cause. An arbitration panel has heard the case and a decision is expected during the course of the first quarter of 2023. Should he prevail in his claim, an outcome that we consider unlikely, we could be liable to pay the full amount of his claim, although we estimate that our actual exposure would be substantially lower than this amount. We have not currently set aside provisions in respect of this litigation. Other than as described in this Offering Memorandum, we are not involved in any legal proceedings which, either individually or in the aggregate, are expected to have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. We note, however, that the outcome of legal proceedings can be extremely difficult to predict, and we offer no assurances in this regard. See “Risk _Factors—Legal, regulatory or other adversarial action, including employment-related claims, could have a material adverse effect on our business.”_ -----

The European staffing solutions industry is regulated. The applicable laws and regulations vary for each country. Staffing solutions providers are generally subject to one or more of the following types of government regulation: - regulation of the relationship between a staffing solutions provider and its job candidates; - regulation of the relationship between a staffing solutions provider and its clients; - registration, licensing, record keeping and reporting requirements; - substantive limitations on the provider’s operations; - health and safety regulations; and - data protection regulations. In most of the jurisdictions in which we operate, including Belgium, the Netherlands, France and Germany, staffing solutions providers are considered the legal employers of their temporary employees. In other jurisdictions, staffing solutions providers are not considered the direct legal employers of temporary employees, but they still have the legal responsibility to collect taxes and social security deductions and transmit such amounts to taxation authorities. Below we describe certain features of the relevant laws and regulations that apply in each of the countries in which we have significant operations. In addition to applicable national laws and regulations, Directive 2008/104/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 19, 2008 on temporary agency work (the “Temporary Agency Work Directive”) also regulates temporary agency work at the level of the European Union. The aim of the Temporary Agency Work Directive is notably to lay down a principle of nondiscrimination and equal treatment for job candidates in relation to the employees of the client as a general rule. It also sets clear limits to prohibitions and restrictions that may be imposed on the use of temporary agency work, while also setting common minimum standards for temporary agency work in the EU. The Temporary Agency Work Directive stipulates that basic working and employment conditions of job candidates shall be, for the duration of their assignment at a client, at least those that would apply if they had been recruited directly by the client to hold the same position. The Temporary Agency Work Directive allows member states to make exceptions to this principle of nondiscrimination in the cases of job candidates assigned on the basis of a permanent agreement and who continue to be paid in the time between assignments, and collective agreements and assignments derogating from the principle while respecting the overall protection of temporary agency workers. The Temporary Agency Work Directive has been transposed in national laws of the EU Member States.

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte _aansprakelijkheid) organized and existing under the laws of the Netherlands company, having its_ registered office at Strawinslylaan 1209, WTC Tower A, 12th floor, 1077 XX Amsterdam, The Netherlands, having its official seat in Amsterdam, and registered with the Trade and Company Register (Kamer van Koophandel) under number 86433792. The Issuer’s board of directors is currently composed of two directors, who can be contacted at the Issuer’s registered address. Certain details of the Issuer’s board of directors are as follows:

Subsubsection Title: Jurjen Van der Wiel was appointed as director of the Issuer on May 18, 2022. Mr. Van der Wiel joined
Subsubsection Text: Bain Capital Private Equity in 2009 and is a Managing Director and a member in its European Private Equity team. Prior to joining Bain Capital Private Equity, Mr. Van der Wiel worked at Bain & Company as a manager in the Amsterdam and Boston offices where he focused on large-scale transformations. Mr. Van der Wiel received his Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees in Mechanical Engineering from the Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands. The biography of Rika Coppens, who also serves as Chief Executive Officer of House of HR, is presented below.

Subsubsection Title: Rika Coppens is the Chief Executive Officer of House of HR since 2017 and currently also serves as
Subsubsection Text: managing director of House of HR and as permanent representative of House of HR on the board of directors of certain of House of HR’s direct and indirect subsidiaries. She also serves as a managing director at FFW BVBA and a non-executive board member for the Colruyt Group, La Lorraine Bakery Group and Euronext BV via her role as managing director at FFW BVBA. Before joining the Company, Ms. Coppens held senior positions at the EFR Group where she was the chief executive officer between 2015 and 2017 and the chief financial officer between 2010 and 2014. She also served as an independent ----- director and member of the audit committee of Realdolmen from May 2017 to September 2018. Ms. Coppens received her Master’s degree from KU Leuven in 1996.

Subsubsection Title: Leen Geirnaerdt is the Chief Financial Officer of House of HR since October 2022. She currently also
Subsubsection Text: serves as a non-executive board member of DEME Group NV and of H. Essers NV. Prior to joining House of HR, Mrs. Geirnaerdt was CFO at bpost group from 2019 to 2021 and CFO of USG People / Recruit Global Staffing from 2010 to 2019. Prior to that she held several management positions at USG People Belgium (Shared Service Center) and worked as a group controller for Solvus Resource Group. She started her career at PwC Audit, where she worked for six years. Mrs. Geirnaerdt received her Master’s degree in Applied Economics from the Antwerp University (UFSIA) in 1996.

Subsubsection Title: Thomas Martens is the Head of Legal (Group) of House of HR and currently also serves as managing
Subsubsection Text: director of Intellex BV. Before joining House of HR, Mr. Martens was a lawyer at Laga from 2006 to 2014. Mr. Martens received his Master of Laws degree from the University of Ghent in 2005 and his Master’s degree in European Labor Studies from the University College Dublin in 2006.

Subsubsection Title: Wilbert Ingels is the Chief Information Officer of House of HR. He also serves on the board of directors
Subsubsection Text: of Macadam. Before joining House of HR, Mr. Ingels was the Chief Information Officer at Isabel from September 2014 until August 2016. Between 2008 and 2014, Mr. Ingels founded and acted as the Chief Technology Officer for Racktivity NV, Chief Operating Officer for Awingu NV, Chief Executive Officer for OpenMotics BV and Chief Operating Officer for Dacentec NV. He also served as the Chief Executive Officer for Cloudfounders NV from 2008 until August 2016. Mr. Ingels received his Master’s degree in Engineering and Electronics from University of Brussels in 1991.

Subsubsection Title: Abdel Bencheikh is the Chief Risk and Sustainability Officer of House of HR. Before joining House
Subsubsection Text: of HR, he was the Chief Risk and Compliance Officer of Natixis AM between 1999 and 2015. Mr. Bencheikh received his PhD in Particle Physics from Université Blaise Pascal in 1992 and his advanced studies degree in Finance and Banking Management from Université Aix-Marseille in 1997.

Subsubsection Title: Lieven Van Nieuwenhuyze is the Chief Digital Officer and Public Affairs of House of HR. Mr. Van
Subsubsection Text: Nieuwenhuyze also served as on the board of directors of Accent Group NV from 2016 until May 2019. Before joining House of HR, Mr. Van Nieuwenhuyze was an e-marketing executive at USG People NV between 2010 and 2012. He also served as the general manager at USG Professionals NV between 2012 and 2015. Mr. Van Nieuwenhuyze received his Master’s degree in labor and organizational psychology from KU Leuven in 2000, his post-academic degree in e-business from the University of Ghent in 2005 and completed a post-academic course in ‘User centered design-usability’ from KU Leuven in 2008.

Subsubsection Title: Victoria Hemelaer is the Chief Marketing Officer of House of HR. Before joining House of HR in
Subsubsection Text: October 2020, she worked as the Product and Marketing Director for Europe at Deceuninck in Belgium since January 2019. From 2012 until the end of 2018 she worked for Mohawk Industries in Europe and USA in product, marketing and global business development. Mrs. Hemelaer received her Master’s degree in Law at the University of Ghent in 2006 and obtained a Master’s degree in General Management in 2007 at the Vlerick Business School.

Subsubsection Title: Bas ten Hove is the Succession Manager at House of HR. Before joining House of HR in June 2022,
Subsubsection Text: Mr. ten Hove was a Human Resources Manager at Deloitte from 1998 to 2006, as well as served in several international human resources leadership positions at General Electric in the Healthcare and Wind Industry from 2006 until May 2022. Mr. ten Hove received his Master’s degree in Human Resources at the Tilburg University in 1996.

Subsubsection Title: Saar Demeyer is the Group Executive Management Assistant and HR advisor of House of HR. Mrs.
Subsubsection Text: Demeyer has been part of the management team of Accent since 2014. She started as a Sales Consultant for Accent in 2012. Before joining House of HR, Mrs. Demeyer served as a Sales and Management Assistant at Boplan between 2011 and 2012. She also served as a Sales and Management Assistant at Van Maele NV between 2007 and 2011. Mrs. Demeyer received her Bachelor’s degree in Business and ----- Corporate Communications from University College West-Flanders in 2006. She received a postgraduate degree from University College Ghent in 2007.

Rika Coppens ............................................................................................ 50 Director Jurjen Van der Wiel .................................................................................. 45 Director Set forth below is biographical information for each of the directors of the Issuer. Rika Coppens ................................................ 50 Chief Executive Officer Leen Geirnaerdt............................................. 48 Chief Financial Officer Thomas Martens ........................................... 41 Head of Legal (Group) Wilbert Ingels ............................................... 53 Chief Information Officer Abdel Bencheikh .......................................... 59 Chief Risk and Sustainability Officer Lieven Van Nieuwenhuyze.......................... 46 Chief Digital Officer and Public Affairs Victoria Hemelaer ......................................... 39 Chief Marketing Officer Bas ten Hove ................................................. 52 Succession Manager Saar Demeyer ................................................ 38 Group Executive Management Assistant Set forth below is biographical information for each of the members of the Executive Committee of House of HR.

The Executive Committee advises on all of the operational and financial aspects of House of HR’s business and meets every month. The following table sets forth certain information regarding the members of the Executive Committee, including their ages as of the date of this Offering Memorandum.

The Audit Committee is currently comprised of Aurelien Dorkel, a Director of Naxicap, Youssef Salha, a Principal at Bain Capital, Leen Geirnaerdt, and Astrid Heireman, a representative of Finfactory BV acting as Chairman, with Abdel Bencheikh acting as the secretary of this committee. Rika Coppens is a permanent invitee of the committee. The Audit Committee meets at least four times a year. The Audit Committee advises the board of directors of House of HR in respect of its responsibility for ensuring that the financial reports, when taken as a whole, are fair, balanced and understandable and provides the information necessary for shareholders to assess the Group’s position, performance, business model and strategy. In addition, while the board has ultimate responsibility for maintaining a robust framework of internal controls and risk management and for overseeing, reviewing and ensuring the effectiveness of our risk management and internal control systems, it has delegated the monitoring and review of this framework to the Audit Committee. House of HR also has a governance and control charter signed by all Powerhouses in its Group, and has implemented a conflicts of interest management system, as well as major incident policies and procedures at the Group level.

The People Committee is currently comprised of Christophe Jacobs van Merlen, Matthias Boyer Chammard, Conny Vandendriessche, Eric Aveillan, Rika Coppens, and Bas ten Hove. The People Committee meets twice a year. The People Committee is responsible for considering and making recommendations to the board of directors of House of HR on the general policy on executive and senior management remuneration, overall remuneration packages for executive directors, and the design and operation of our share incentive plans.

The Investment Committee is currently comprised of Rika Coppens, Leen Geirnaerdt. Jeroen Ekkel, Jan-Willem Dijkstra, Edwin van den Elst, Henk Buitink, Noël de Vries, Roger Lothmann, Florian Massaux, Anouk Lagae, Diederik Sohier, Oliver Koch, John van de Veen, Gert Bouw, Philippe Jadoul, and Conny Vandendriessche. The Investment Committee meets twice a year. The Investment Committee is responsible for considering M&A opportunities and value creation, including through investments in digital initiatives or other strategic growth areas.

The Innovation Committee is currently comprised of Daniël Masata, an advisor to the Board of Directors of House of HR, Rika Coppens, Wilbert Ingels, Lieven Van Nieuwenhuyze, Marc Thibaut and Arjen de Boer, the CEO of ITDS. The Innovation Committee meets four times a year. The Innovation Committee is responsible for developing innovation initiatives in the Group, as well as monitoring the evolutions of general technological advancements, new perceptions and insights and formulate plans and initiatives for the Group to respond and adapt accordingly. -----

The ESG Committee is currently comprised of Rika Coppens, Conny Vandendriessche, Anouk Lagae (Chief Executive Officer of Accent), Florian Massaux (Chief Executive Officer of Accent), Roger Lothmann (Chief Executive Officer of TIMEPARTNER), Jurjen Van De Wiele and Edwin van den Elst (Chief Executive Officer of Redmore), with Abdel Bencheikh acting as the ESG Committee’s secretary and Leen Geirnaerdt participating as an observer and Edwin van den Elst acting as Chairman. The ESG Committee meets four times in a year. The ESG Committee assists the board of directors of House of HR in fulfilling its responsibilities with regard to ESG matters in areas such as environmental, health and safety; corporate social responsibility; sustainability; philanthropy; corporate governance; reputation; diversity, equity and inclusion; community issues; and other public policy matters relevant to House of HR. The ESG committee assists the board of directors and the Powerhouses of House of HR by setting general strategies, priorities and objectives relating to ESG matters and developing, implementing and monitoring the relevant initiatives and policies based on that such strategies, priorities and objectives. -----

The current board of directors of House of HR has formed a number of supervisory committees to assist in certain matters, such as audit and risk; ESG; and remuneration and nomination of candidates for different positions within the Group. We also plan to establish new committees.

There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if such developments had been taken into account. See “Forward-looking Statements.”_

Bain Capital is a leading global private investment firm that advises and manages capital across several asset classes, including private equity, public equity, fixed income and credit, venture capital and real estate investments across multiple sectors, industries and geographies. Since its inception in 1984, it has made private equity investments in more than 1,300 companies and currently has approximately $160 billion in assets under management. Collectively, more than 10% of Bain’s private equity funds’ commitments come from its professionals. Bain Capital has over 650 investment professionals worldwide spread throughout its global network in Europe, Asia and North America, with a depth of expertise in key vertical industries including healthcare, consumer/retail, financial and business services, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital has investors from across the world that include sovereign wealth funds, public pension funds, foundations, insurance companies, family offices, high net worth individuals and funds of funds. Headquartered in Boston, Bain Capital has over 1,500 team members across 23 offices worldwide, including in Chicago, Dublin, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, Lisbon, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Melbourne, Mumbai, Munich, New York, Palo Alto, San Francisco, Seoul, Shanghai, Singapore, Sydney and Tokyo. Bain Capital has a strong track record of investing in the business services space with over 50 current or past investments. Bain Capital has invested in businesses in the staffing and engineering consulting services, including Quest, a leading global engineering services provider, MSX International, a BPO company focused on technical staffing solutions and managed services, Inetum, an IT services provider in France, and Engineering, an IT systems and services provider in Italy, as well as other investments in the business services space, including Autodistribution and Bravida. -----

House of HR is a public limited company (naamloze vennootschap) incorporated under the laws of Belgium. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, House of HR is fully owned by the Issuer. The Issuer is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte _aansprakelijkheid) organized and existing under the laws of the Netherlands, registered with the trade_ register under number 86433792, and a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Holdco, a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) organized and existing under the laws of the Netherlands. The Issuer and Holdco are part of a corporate structure that was established to complete the Transactions. See “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.” As of the Acquisition Closing Date (excluding the impact of the ABMI Acquisition), Bain Capital indirectly held approximately 55.0% of the share capital of the Issuer, Naxicap Partners and Mrs. Vandendriessche indirectly held approximately 21.2% of the share capital of the Issuer, and management (and other minority) shareholders indirectly held approximately 23.8% of the share capital of the Issuer (plus MIP Securities). See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Management Incentive Plan.” On the Acquisition Closing Date, the shareholders of Holdco entered into a shareholders’ agreement.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: On the Acquisition Closing Date, we established the structure for a management equity participation program pursuant to which certain managers of the Group will be able to acquire, subscribe for or otherwise receive MIP Securities and such managers have entered into certain customary documentation (the “Management Incentive Plan”). In connection with the Acquisition, we settled our previous long-term incentive plan at the House of HR level.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: On November 4, 2022, House of HR entered into a management service agreement pursuant to which an entity controlled by Conny Vandendriessche receives annual compensation for, among other things, the promotion of the interests and business of the Group, and will be compensated for certain expenses (such as networking events, VOKA memberships, etc.). Each of Bain Capital and Naxicap (as long as it is holding at least 5% of the ordinary shares and fixed-return preferred shares issued by Holdco on a fully diluted basis) will be entitled to invoice portfolio monitoring fees as well as ad hoc fees for work performed in connection with exceptional assignments such as acquisitions and refinancings. -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, the Issuer entered into a Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement with dated as of October 30, 2022, among others, J.P. Morgan SE, Barclays Bank Ireland PLC, Belfius Bank NV, Coöperative Rabobank U.A., ING Belgium SA/NV, Mizuho Bank Europe N.V. and Société Générale as mandated lead arrangers, J.P. Morgan SE as agent and Elavon Financial Services DAC as security agent (“Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement”). The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement provides for (i) a senior term loan facility in a principal amount of €1,020,000,000 (“Facility B”), (ii) a senior delayed draw term facility in a principal amount of €125,000,000 (“Delayed Draw Term Facility”) and (iii) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of €250,000,000 (the “Revolving Credit Facility”) (Facility B, the Delayed Draw Term Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility are collectively referred to as the “Original Senior Credit Facilities” for the purposes of this description). Incremental facilities may also be established under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement from time to time (including by way of an increase to any existing facilities or the establishment of new facilities) (“Incremental Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Original Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Facility B and the Delayed Draw Term Facility may be utilized by the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility (the “Term Facility Borrowers”). The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the “RCF Borrowers”), in EUR, GBP and USD and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market and freely convertible into EUR (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities (on a bilateral and/or fronted basis).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: All amounts borrowed under Facility B shall be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards (including by way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Senior Secured Group or Company Group), refinancing any interim Facility B if drawn and otherwise applied in or towards (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing consideration paid or payable in connection with the Acquisition (including any purchase price adjustments); (ii) financing or refinancing other related amounts, including fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Acquisition, the Transaction and/or the Transaction Documents (“Transaction Costs”); (iii) refinancing or otherwise discharging certain indebtedness of the Company together with its subsidiaries (the “Company Group”) and paying any breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing and/or acquisition (the “Refinancing”); (iv) for any other purpose contemplated by the tax structure memorandum and the funds flow statement; and/or (v) to the extent not applied for a purpose set out in sub-paragraphs (i) to (iv) above, financing or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group (including, for the avoidance of doubt, any cash over funding). ----- All amounts borrowed under the Delayed Draw Term Facility shall be applied in or towards refinancing any interim delayed draw facility if drawn and otherwise applied in or towards (directly or indirectly): (i) financing, refinancing, funding, refunding or prefunding of any permitted acquisitions (including any earn-out in relation thereto) and investments of the Senior Secured Group and, in each case, any fees, costs and/or expenses in relation thereto; (ii) bridging to target cash for any permitted acquisition and investments; and/or (iii) financing, refinancing, replacing, cash collateralizing, back-stopping or discharging financial indebtedness of any acquisition target and paying any related breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such financing, refinancing replacing, cash collateralising, back-stopping or discharging, The Revolving Credit Facility shall be applied in or towards (including by way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Group or Target Group) refinancing any interim revolving facility if drawn and otherwise applied (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group; (ii) the backstop or provision of cash cover in respect of any existing ancillary facilities, guarantees, indemnities, letters of credit, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements of the Company Group (if applicable) and financing or refinancing any other transactions contemplated by the Transaction; and /or (iii) financing any other payments identified in, or for any other purpose contemplated by the funds flow statement or the tax structure memorandum or otherwise arising in connection with the Transaction, in each case, together with related fees, costs and expenses (and including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Facility B was fully utilized on the Acquisition Closing Date. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, €114.1 million has been drawn under the Delayed Draw Term Facility. It may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement to the date falling eighteen (18) months after (and excluding) the date on which the Acquisition Closing Date has occurred and the first utilization of Facility B has been made to complete the Acquisition (the “Closing Date”). The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement to (and including) the date falling 1 month prior to the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility. Utilizations of the Original Senior Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent. The Delayed Draw Term Facility: (i) includes an additional drawing condition that, on the Applicable Test Date, such loan under the Delayed Draw Term Facility (pro forma for the Incurrence thereof) constitutes Permitted Debt under paragraphs (i)(B), (i)(C) or (v)(B) of the definition of “Permitted _Debt” in the section entitled “Description of the Notes—Limitation on indebtedness”; and (ii) may not_ be utilized unless Facility B has been utilized (but for the avoidance of doubt, the Delayed Draw Term Facility may be utilised contemporaneously with Facility B, including on or prior to the Closing Date).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Original Senior Credit Facilities initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR or, (i) for loans denominated other than in Euro (other than loans denominated in sterling or US Dollars), the applicable IBOR; (ii) for loans denominated in sterling, SONIA, (iii) for loans denominated in US Dollars, Term SOFR, plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated senior secured net debt to consolidated pro forma EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement) (the “Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio”). ----- If the applicable benchmark rates are less than zero, the relevant rate shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Original Senior Credit Facilities. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. Such commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears (provided that the Issuer may elect that accrued commitment fee shall instead be paid on each Quarter Date or the last date of each Interest Period applicable to Facility B), on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment. Any letter of credit issued under the Revolving Credit Facility shall be subject to such issuing bank and fronting fees as may be agreed between the Company and the applicable issuing bank and a letter of credit fee equal to the margin that would have been applicable to a cash drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility in the applicable currency. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% per annum on the defaulted amount.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The loans made under Facility B and the Delayed Draw Term Facility will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the termination date of the Revolving Credit Facility, being the date falling six and a half years from the Closing Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions.
